<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.1.4
Submission of Radiographs<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Before any welds are repaired, the radiographs shall be submitted to the inspector with any information requested by
the inspector regarding the radiographic technique used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.1.5
Radiographic Standards<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Welds examined by radiography shall be judged as acceptable or unacceptable by the standards of Paragraph UW-
51(b) in Section VIII of the ASME  Code .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.1.6
Determination of Limits of Defective Welding<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>When a section of weld is shown by a radiograph to be unacceptable under the provisions of 8.1.5 or the limits of the
deficient welding are not defined by the radiograph, two spots adjacent to the section shall be examined by
radiography; however, if the original radiograph shows at least 75 mm (3 in.) of acceptable weld between the defect
and any one edge of the film, an additional radiograph need not be taken of the weld on that side of the defect. If the
weld at either of the adjacent sections fails to comply with the requirements of 8.1.5, additional spots shall be
examined until the limits of unacceptable welding are determined, or the erector may replace all of the welding
performed by the welder or welding operator on that joint. If the welding is replaced, the inspector shall have the
option of requiring that one radiograph be taken at any selected location on any other joint on which the same welder
or welding operator has welded. If any of these additional spots fail to comply with the requirements of 8.1.5, the limits
of unacceptable welding shall be determined as specified for the initial section.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.1.7
Repair of Defective Welds<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>8.1.7.1
Defects in welds shall be repaired by chipping or melting out the defects from one side or both sides of the
joint, as required, and rewelding. Only the cutting out of defective joints that is necessary to correct the defects is
required.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.1.7.2
All repaired welds in joints shall be checked by repeating the original examination procedure and by
repeating one of the testing methods of 7.3, subject to the approval of the Purchaser.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.1.8
Record of Radiographic Examination<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.1.8.1
The Manufacturer shall prepare a radiograph map showing the final location of all radiographs taken along
with the film identification marks.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.1.8.2
After the structure is completed, the films shall be the property of the Purchaser unless otherwise agreed
upon by the Purchaser and the Manufacturer.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_179>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
8-5<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.2 Magnetic Particle Examination<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.2.1  When magnetic particle examination is specified, the method of examination shall be in accordance with
Section V, Article 7, of the ASME  Code .<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>8.2.2  Magnetic particle examination shall be performed in accordance with a written procedure that is certified by
the Manufacturer to be in compliance with the applicable requirements of Section V of the ASME  Code .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.2.3  The Manufacturer shall determine that each magnetic particle examiner meets the following requirements.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) Has vision (with correction, if necessary) to be able to read a Jaeger Type 2 standard chart at a distance of not
less than 300 mm (12 in.) and is capable of distinguishing and differentiating contrast between the colors used.
Examiners shall be checked annually to ensure that they meet these requirements.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) Is competent in the technique of the magnetic particle examination method, including performing the examination
and interpreting and evaluating the results; however, where the examination method consists of more than one
operation, the examiner need only be qualified for one or more of the operations.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.2.4  Acceptance standards and the removal and repair of defects shall be in accordance with Section VIII, Annex
6, Paragraphs 6-3, 6-4, and 6-5, of the ASME  Code .<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.3 Ultrasonic Examination<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.3.1 Ultrasonic Examination in Lieu of Radiography<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>When ultrasonic examination is applied in order to fulfill the requirement of 7.3.2.1, the provisions of Annex U shall
apply.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.3.2 Ultrasonic Examination NOT in Lieu of Radiography<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.3.2.1  When the radiographic method is applied in order to fulfill the requirement of 7.3.2.1, then any ultrasonic
examination specified shall be in accordance with this section.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.3.2.2  The method of examination shall be in accordance with Section V, Article 4, of the ASME  Code .<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>8.3.2.3  Ultrasonic examination shall be performed in accordance with a written procedure that is certified by the
Manufacturer to be in compliance with the applicable requirements of Section V of the ASME  Code .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>8.3.2.4  Examiners who perform ultrasonic examinations under this section shall be qualified and certified by the
Manufacturers as meeting the requirements of certification as generally outlined in Level II or Level III of ASNT SNT-
TC-1A (including applicable supplements). Level-I personnel may be used if they are given written acceptance/
rejection criteria prepared by Level-II or Level-III personnel. In addition, all Level-I personnel shall be under the direct
supervision of Level-II or Level-III personnel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.3.2.5  Acceptance standards shall be agreed upon by the Purchaser and the Manufacturer.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.4 Liquid Penetrant Examination<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.4.1  When liquid penetrant examination is specified, the method of examination shall be in accordance with
Section V, Article 6, of the ASME  Code .<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>8.4.2  Liquid penetrant examination shall be performed in accordance with a written procedure that is certified by the
Manufacturer to be in compliance with the applicable requirements of Section V of the ASME  Code .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_180>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>8-6
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.4.3  The Manufacturer shall determine and certify that each liquid penetrant examiner meets the following
requirements.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) Has vision (with correction, if necessary) to enable him to read a Jaeger Type 2 standard chart at a distance of not
less than 300 mm (12 in.) and is capable of distinguishing and differentiating contrast between the colors used.
Examiners shall be checked annually to ensure that they meet these requirements.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) Is competent in the technique of the liquid penetrant examination method for which he is certified, including
making the examination and interpreting and evaluating the results; however, where the examination method
consists of more than one operation, the examiner may be certified as being qualified for one or more of the
operations.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.4.4  Acceptance standards and the removal and repair of defects shall be in accordance with Section VIII, Annex
8, Paragraphs 8-3, 8-4, and 8-5, of the ASME  Code .<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.5 Visual Examination<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.5.1  The Manufacturer shall determine and certify that each visual examiner meets the following requirements.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) Has vision (with correction, if necessary) to be able to read a Jaeger Type 2 standard chart at a distance of not
less than 300 mm (12 in.) and is capable of passing a color contrast test. Examiners shall be checked annually to
ensure that they meet this requirement; and<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) Is competent in the technique of the visual examination, including performing the examination and interpreting and
evaluating the results; however, where the examination method consists of more than one operation, the
examiner performing only a portion of the test need only be qualified for the portion that the examiner performs.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.5.2  A weld shall be acceptable by visual examination if the inspection shows the following.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) There are no crater cracks, other surface cracks or arc strikes in or adjacent to the welded joints.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) Maximum permissible undercut is 0.4 mm ( 1 / 64  in.) in depth for vertical butt joints, vertically oriented permanent
attachments, attachment welds for nozzles, manholes, flush-type openings, and the inside shell-to-bottom welds.
For horizontal butt joints, horizontally oriented permanent attachments, and annular-ring butt joints, the maximum
permissible undercut is 0.8 mm ( 1 / 32  in.) in depth.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) The frequency of surface porosity in the weld does not exceed one cluster (one or more pores) in any 100 mm
(4 in.) of length, and the diameter of each cluster does not exceed 2.5 mm ( 3 / 32  in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d) The reinforcement of the welds on all butt joints on each side of the plate shall not exceed the following
thicknesses:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Maximum Reinforcement Thickness<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>mm (in.)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Plate Thickness<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>mm (in.)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Vertical Joints
Horizontal Joints<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>≤  13 ( 1 / 2 )
2.5 ( 3 / 32 )
3 ( 1 / 8 )<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>> 13 ( 1 / 2 ) to 25 (1)
3 ( 1 / 8 )
5 ( 3 / 16 )<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>> 25 (1)
5 ( 3 / 16 )
6 ( 1 / 4 )<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_181>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
8-7<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The reinforcement need not be removed except to the extent that it exceeds the maximum acceptable thickness or
unless its removal is required by 8.1.3.4 for radiographic examination.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.5.3
A weld that fails to meet the criteria given in 8.5.1 shall be reworked before hydrostatic testing as follows:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) Any defects shall be removed by mechanical means or thermal gouging processes. Arc strikes discovered in or
adjacent to welded joints shall be repaired by grinding and rewelding as required. Arc strikes repaired by welding
shall be ground flush with the plate.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) Rewelding is required if the resulting thickness is less than the minimum required for design or hydrostatic test
conditions. All defects in areas thicker than the minimum shall be feathered to at least a 4:1 taper.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) The repair weld shall be visually examined for defects.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>DELETED<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.6
Vacuum Testing<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>8.6.1
Vacuum testing is performed using a testing box approximately 150 mm (6 in.) wide by 750 mm (30 in.) long
with a clear window in the top, which provides proper visibility to view the area under examination. During testing,
illumination shall be adequate for proper evaluation and interpretation of the test. The open bottom shall be sealed
against the tank surface by a suitable gasket. Connections, valves, lighting and gauges, as required, shall be
provided. A soap film solution or commercial leak detection solution, applicable to the conditions, shall be used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.6.2
Vacuum testing shall be performed in accordance with a written procedure prepared by the Manufacturer of
the tank. The procedure shall require:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) performing a visual examination of the bottom and welds prior to performing the vacuum-box test;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) verifying the condition of the vacuum box and its gasket seals;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) verifying that there is no quick bubble or spitting response to large leaks; and<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d) applying the film solution to a dry area, such that the area is thoroughly wetted and a minimum generation of
application bubbles occurs.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>8.6.3
A partial vacuum of 21 kPa (3 lbf/in. 2 , 6 in. Hg) to 35 kPa (5 lbf/in. 2 , 10 in Hg) gauge shall be used for the test.
If specified by the Purchaser, a second partial vacuum test of 56 kPa (8 lbf/in. 2 , 16 in. Hg) to 70 kPa (10 lbf/in. 2 ,
20 in. Hg) shall be performed for the detection of very small leaks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.6.4
The Manufacturer shall determine that each vacuum-box operator meets the following requirements:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) has vision (with correction, if necessary) to be able to read a Jaeger Type 2 standard chart at a distance of not less
than 300 mm (12 in.). Operators shall be checked annually to ensure that they meet this requirement; and<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) is competent in the technique of the vacuum-box testing, including performing the examination and interpreting
and evaluating the results; however, where the examination method consists of more than one operation, the
operator performing only a portion of the test need only be qualified for that portion the operator performs.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.6.5
The vacuum-box test shall have at least 50 mm (2 in.) overlap of previously viewed surface on each
application.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_182>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>8-8
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>8.6.6
The metal surface temperature limits shall be between 4 °C (40 °F) and 52 °C (125 °F), unless the film
solution is proven to work at temperatures outside these limits, either by testing or Manufacturer’s recommendations.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.6.7
A minimum light intensity of 1000 Lux (100 fc) at the point of examination is required during the application of
the examination and evaluation for leaks.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.6.8
The vacuum shall be maintained for the greater of either at least 5 seconds or the time required to view the
area under test.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>8.6.9
The presence of a through-thickness leak indicated by continuous formation or growth of a bubble(s) or foam,
produced by air passing through the thickness, is unacceptable. The presence of a large opening leak, indicated by a
quick bursting bubble or spitting response at the initial setting of the vacuum box is unacceptable. Leaks shall be
repaired and retested.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8.6.10
A record or report of the test including a statement addressing temperature and light intensity shall be
completed and furnished to the Purchaser upon request.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>8.6.11
As an alternate to vacuum-box testing, a suitable tracer gas and compatible detector can be used to test the
integrity of welded bottom joints for their entire length. Where tracer gas testing is employed as an alternate to
vacuum-box testing, it shall meet the following requirements:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) Tracer gas testing shall be performed in accordance with a written procedure which has been reviewed and
approved by the Purchaser and which shall address as a minimum: the type of equipment used, surface
cleanliness, type of tracer gas, test pressure, soil permeability, soil moisture content, satisfactory verification of the
extent of tracer gas permeation, and the method or technique to be used including scanning rate and probe
standoff distance.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) The technique shall be capable of detecting leakage of 1  ×  10 –4  Pa m 3 / s  (1  ×  10 –3  std cm 3 / s ) or smaller.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) The test system parameters (detector, gas, and system pressure, i.e., level of pressure under bottom) shall be
calibrated by placing the appropriate calibrated capillary leak, which will leak at a rate consistent with (b) above, in
a temporary or permanent fitting in the tank bottom away from the tracer gas pressurizing point. Alternatively, by
agreement between the Purchaser and the Manufacturer, the calibrated leak may be placed in a separate fitting
pressurized in accordance with the system parameters.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d) While testing for leaks in the welded bottom joints, system parameters shall be unchanged from those used during
calibration.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_183>>
<<HEADING level=3>>SECTION 9—WELDING PROCEDURE AND WELDER QUALIFICATIONS<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>9.1 Definitions<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In this standard, terms relating to welding shall be interpreted as defined in Section IX of the ASME  Code . Additional
terms are defined in 9.1.1 and 9.1.2.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>9.1.1  An angle joint is a joint between two members that intersect at an angle between 0 degrees (a butt joint) and
90 degrees (a corner joint).<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>9.1.2  Porosity refers to gas pockets or voids in metal.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>9.2 Qualification of Welding Procedures<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>9.2.1 General Requirements<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>9.2.1.1  The erection Manufacturer and the fabrication Manufacturer if other than the erection Manufacturer, shall
prepare welding procedure specifications and shall perform tests documented by procedure qualification records to
support the specifications, as required by Section IX of the ASME  Code  and any additional provisions of this
standard. If the Manufacturer is part of an organization that has, to the Purchaser’s satisfaction, established effective
operational control of the qualification of welding procedures and of welder performance for two or more companies of
different names, then separate welding procedure qualifications are not required, provided all other requirements of
9.2, 9.3, and Section IX of the ASME  Code  are met. Welding procedures for ladder and platform assemblies,
handrails, stairways, and other miscellaneous assemblies, but not their attachments to the tank, shall comply with
either AWS D1.1, AWS D1.6, or Section IX of the ASME  Code , including the use of standard WPSs.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>9.2.1.2  The welding procedures used shall produce weldments with the mechanical properties required by the
design.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>9.2.1.3  Material specifications listed in Section 4 of this standard but not included in Table QW-422 of Section IX of
the ASME  Code  shall be considered as P-No. 1 material with group numbers assigned as follows according to the
minimum tensile strength specified:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) less than 485 MPa (70 ksi)—Group 1;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) equal to or greater than 485 MPa (70 ksi) but less than 550 MPa (80 ksi)—Group 2;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) equal to or greater than 550 MPa (80 ksi)—Group 3.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Separate welding procedures and performance qualifications shall be conducted for A841M/A841 material.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>9.2.1.4  Welding variables (including supplementary essential variables when impact tests are required by 9.2.2), as
defined by QW-250 of Section IX of the ASME  Code , shall be used to determine the welding procedure specifications
and the procedure qualification records to be instituted. In addition, when impact tests of the heat-affected zone are
required, the heat-treated condition of the base material shall be a supplementary essential variable. Plates produced
by the controlled-rolled process are not to be considered as having received any heat treatment. If a protective
coating has been applied to weld edge preparations, the coating shall be included as an essential variable of the
welding procedure specification, as required by 7.2.1.9.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>9.2.2 Impact Tests<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>9.2.2.1  Impact tests for the qualification of welding procedures shall comply with the applicable provisions of 4.2.9
and shall be made at or below the design metal temperature.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>9-1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_184>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>9-2
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>9.2.2.2  When impact testing of a material is required by 4.2.9, 4.2.10, or 4.5.4 impact tests of the heat-affected zone
shall be made for all machine, automatic, and semiautomatic welding procedures.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>9.2.2.3  For all materials to be used at a design metal temperature below 10 °C (50 °F), the qualification of the
welding procedure for vertical joints shall include impact tests of the weld metal. If vertical joints are to be made by a
machine, automatic, or semiautomatic process, impact tests of the heat-affected zone shall also be made.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>9.2.2.4  When the design metal temperature is below –7 °C (20 °F), impact tests of the weld metal shall be made for
all procedures used for welding the components listed in 4.2.10.1, for welding attachments to these components, and
for fabricating shell nozzles and manholes from pipe and forgings listed in 4.5.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>9.2.2.5  Impact tests shall show minimum values for acceptance in accordance with 4.2.9.3 and the following:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) for P-No. 1, Group 1, materials—20 J (15 ft-lbf), average of three specimens;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) for P-No. 1, Group 2, materials—27 J (20 ft-lbf), average of three specimens;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) for P-No. 1, Group 3, materials—34 J (25 ft-lbf), average of three specimens.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>For shell plates thicker than 40 mm (1 1 / 2  in.), these values shall be increased by 7 J (5 ft-lbf) for each 13 mm ( 1 / 2  in.)
over 40 mm (1 1 / 2  in.). Interpolation is permitted.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>9.2.2.6  Weld-metal impact specimens shall be taken across the weld with one face substantially parallel to and
within 1.5 mm ( 1 / 16  in.) of the surface of the material. The notch shall be cut normal to the original material surface
and with the weld metal entirely within the fracture zone.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>9.2.2.7  Heat-affected-zone impact specimens shall be taken across the weld and as near the surface of the material
as is practicable. Each specimen shall be etched to locate the heat-affected zone, and the notch shall be cut
approximately normal to the original material surface and with as much heat-affected-zone material as possible
included in the fracture zone.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>9.2.2.8  Production welding shall conform to the qualified welding procedure, but production-weld test plates need
not be made.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>9.3 Qualification of Welders<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>9.3.1  The erection Manufacturer and the fabrication Manufacturer, if other than the erection Manufacturer, shall
conduct tests for all welders assigned to manual and semiautomatic welding and all welding operators assigned to
machine and automatic welding to demonstrate the welders’ and welding operators’ ability to make acceptable welds.
Tests conducted by one Manufacturer shall not qualify a welder or welding operator to do work for another
Manufacturer.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>9.3.2  The welders and welding operators who weld pressure parts and join nonpressure parts, such as all
permanent and temporary clips and lugs, to pressure parts shall be qualified in accordance with Section IX of the
ASME  Code .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>9.3.3  The records of the tests for qualifying welders and welding operators shall include the following.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) Each welder or welding operator shall be assigned an identifying number, letter, or symbol by the fabrication or
erection Manufacturer.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) The fabrication or erection Manufacturer shall maintain a record of the welders or welding operators employed
that shows the date and results of the tests for each welder or operator and the identifying mark assigned to each
welder or operator. This record shall be certified by the fabrication or erection Manufacturer and shall be
accessible to the inspector.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_185>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
9-3<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>9.4 Identification of Welded Joints<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The welder or welding operator’s identification mark shall be hand- or machine-stamped adjacent to and at intervals
not exceeding 1 m (3 ft) along the completed welds. In lieu of stamping, a record may be kept that identifies the
welder or welding operator employed for each welded joint; these records shall be accessible to the inspector. Roof
plate welds and flange-to-nozzle-neck welds do not require welder identification.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_186>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_187>>
<<HEADING level=3>>SECTION 10—MARKING<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>10.1 Nameplates<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>10.1.1  A tank made in accordance with this standard shall be identified by a nameplate similar to that shown in
Figure 10.1. The nameplate shall indicate, by means of letters and numerals not less than 4 mm ( 5 / 32  in.) high, the
following information:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>API STANDARD 650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>YEAR COMPLETED<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>ANNEX<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>EDITION<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>ADDENDUM NO.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOMINAL DIAMETER<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOMINAL HEIGHT<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>MAXIMUM CAPACITY<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>DESIGN LIQUID LEVEL<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>DESIGN SPECIFIC GRAVITY<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>DESIGN METAL TEMP.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>DESIGN PRESSURE<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>MAXIMUM DESIGN TEMP.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>MANUFACTURER’S SERIAL NO.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>STRESS RELIEF<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>PURCHASER’S TANK NO.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>INT. PRESS. COMB. FACTOR<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>EXT. PRESS. COMB. FACTOR<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>FABRICATED BY<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>ERECTED BY<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>SHELL COURSE
MATERIAL<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE  At the Purchaser’s request, or at the erection Manufacturer’s discretion, additional pertinent information may be
shown on the nameplate, and the size of the nameplate may be increased proportionately.
●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Figure 10.1—Manufacturer’s Nameplate<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) API Standard 650.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) The applicable Annex to API Standard 650.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) The year the tank was completed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d) The edition and the addendum number of API Standard 650.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e) The nominal diameter and nominal height, in meters (ft and in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
The maximum capacity (see 5.2.6.2), in m 3  (42-gallon barrels).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g) The design liquid level (see 5.6.3.2), in meters (ft and in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>10-1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_188>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>10-2
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h) The design specific gravity of the liquid.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>i)
The design pressure, which shall be shown as “atmospheric” unless Annex F or Annex V applies. If Annex V applies,
design pressure shall be shown as a negative number. If both Annex F and Annex V apply, the positive and negative
pressures shall be separated by a forward slash and shall be followed by consistent units of measurement.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>j)
The design metal temperature as described in 3.4 in °C (°F).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>k) The maximum design temperature, in °C (°F), which shall not exceed 93 °C (200 °F) except in cases where<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Annex M, S, X, or AL applies.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>l)
The name of the fabrication Manufacturer if other than the erection Manufacturer. The Manufacturer’s serial
number or contract number shall be from the erection Manufacturer.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>m) The material specification number for each shell course.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>n) When thermal stress-relief is performed to shell openings (nozzles, manholes, flush-type connections, and flush-
type cleanout fittings) in accordance with the requirements of 5.7.4, or when applied to an entire tank, the following
markings shall be used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1) Use “SR1” when only flush-type cleanout fittings and flush-type shell connections have been thermally stress-
relieved.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2) Use “SR2” when thermal stress-relief has been performed on flush-type cleanout fittings, flush-type shell
connections and all shell openings NPS 12 and greater in size in shell plates, insert plates, or thickened insert
plates of Groups I through IIIA.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3) Use “SR3” when thermal stress-relief has been performed on flush-type cleanout fittings, flush-type shell
connections and all shell openings greater than NPS 2 in. size in shell plates, insert plates, or thickened insert
plates of Groups IV through VI.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4) Use “SR4” when thermal stress-relief has been performed on all flush-type cleanout fittings, flush-type shell
connections and all shell openings.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5) Use “SR5” when the completed tank, including all shell openings and attachments, has been thermally stress-
relieved as a special requirement by the Purchaser.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>6) Use “NONE” when thermal stress-relief has not been performed on any tank appurtenances.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>o) The Purchaser’s tank number.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>p) The internal pressure combination factor,  F p .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>q) The external pressure combination factor,  F pe .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>10.1.2  The nameplate shall be attached to the tank shell adjacent to a manhole or to a manhole reinforcing plate
immediately above a manhole. A nameplate that is placed directly on the shell plate or reinforcing plate shall be
attached by continuous welding or brazing all around the nameplate. A nameplate that is riveted or otherwise
permanently attached to an auxiliary plate of ferrous material shall be attached to the tank shell plate or reinforcing
plate by continuous welding. The nameplate shall be of corrosion-resistant metal.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>10.1.3  When a tank is fabricated and erected by a single organization, that organization’s name shall appear on the
nameplate as both fabricator and erector.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>10.1.4  When a tank is fabricated by one organization and erected by another, the names of both organizations shall
appear on the nameplate, or separate nameplates shall be applied by each.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_189>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
10-3<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>10.2 Division of Responsibility<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Unless otherwise agreed upon, when a tank is fabricated by one Manufacturer and erected by another, the erection
Manufacturer shall be considered as having the primary responsibility. The erection Manufacturer shall make certain
that the materials used in the fabrication of the components and in the construction of the tank are in accordance with
all applicable requirements.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>10.3 Certification<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The Manufacturer shall certify to the Purchaser, by a letter such as that shown in Figure 10.2, that the tank has been
constructed in accordance with the applicable requirements of this standard. An as-built data sheet in accordance
with Annex L shall be attached to the certification letter.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE   At the Purchaser’s request or at the erection Manufacturer’s discretion, additional pertinent information may be shown on
the nameplate, and the size of the nameplate may be increased proportionately.
●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>MANUFACTURER’S CERTIFICATION FOR
A TANK BUILT TO API STANDARD 650<<HEADING_END>>

(name and address of Purchaser)
____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>We hereby certify that the tank constructed for you at ___________________________________________________
(location)
______________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>______________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>and described as follows: _________________________________________________________________________
(serial or contract number, diameter, height, capacity, floating or fixed roof)
______________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>meets all applicable requirements of API Standard 650, ______________ Edition, ______________ Revision, Annex<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>___________, dated ____________________, including the requirements for design, materials, fabrication, and erection.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The tank is further described on the attached as-built data sheet dated _________________________.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_190>>

<<PAGE_191>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Annex A
(normative)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Optional Design Basis for Small Tanks<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>This annex provides a number of design options requiring decisions by the Purchaser; standard requirements;
recommendations; and information that supplements the basic standard. This annex becomes a requirement only
when the Purchaser specifies an option covered by this annex or specifies the entire annex.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>A.1
Scope<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A.1.1
This Annex provides requirements for field-erected tanks of relatively small capacity in which the stressed
components have a nominal thickness of no more than 13 mm ( 1 / 2  in.). The stressed components include the shell
and reinforcing plates, shell reinforcing plates for flush-type cleanout fittings and flush-type shell connections, and
bottom plates that are welded to the shell. The nominal thickness limit of 13 mm ( 1 / 2  in.) does not apply to:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1) bottom plates not welded to the shell;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2) the bottom reinforcing plate of flush-type cleanouts and flush-type shell connections;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3) flanges and cover plates of flush-type cleanouts;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4) flush-type shell connection necks attached to shell and flanges and cover plates of flush-type shell connections;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5) nozzle and manhole necks, their flanges and cover plates;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>6) anchor bolt chair components and shell compression ring.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>A.1.2
This Annex is applicable only when specified by the Purchaser and is limited to design metal temperatures
above –30 °C (–20 °F) [above –40 °C (–40 °F) when killed, fine-grain material is used].<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>A.1.3
This Annex is applicable to any of the Section 4 materials, although the single allowable stress does not
provide any advantage to higher strength steels.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A.1.4
This Annex states only the requirements that differ from the basic rules in this standard. When differing
requirements are not stated, the basic rules must be followed; however, the overturning effect of a wind load should
be considered.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A.1.5
Typical sizes, capacities, and shell-plate thicknesses are listed in Tables A.1a through A.4b for a design in
accordance with A.4 (joint efficiency = 0.85; design specific gravity = 1.0; and corrosion allowance = 0).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>A.2
Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>A.2.1
Shell-plate materials shall not be more than 13 mm ( 1 / 2  in.) thick, as stated in A.1.1.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A.2.2
For stressed components, the Group-I and Group-II materials listed in Table 4.3a and Table 4.3b may be used
at a design metal temperature of –30 °C (–20 °F) or warmer but need not conform to the toughness requirements of
4.2.9, Figure 4.1, and 9.2.2. Group-III and Group-IIIA materials may be used at a design metal temperature of –40 °C
(–40 °F) or warmer and shall conform to impact requirements of 9.2.2.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A.2.3
Material used for shell nozzle and manhole necks and flanges shall conform to 4.5, 4.6, and Table 4.3a and
Table 4.3b but need not conform to the toughness requirements of 4.2.9, 4.5.5, and Figure 4.1.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A-1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_192>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A-2
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
A-3<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE  The nominal capacities given in this table were calculated using the following formula:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In USC units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>C  = 0.14 D 2 H<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>where<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>C  is the capacity of tank, 42-gal barrels;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>D   is the diameter of tank, in ft (see A.4.1);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H   is the height of tank, in ft (see A.4.1).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The capacities and diameters in italics (Columns 4 through 11) are the maximums for the tank heights given in the column heads, based on a
maximum permissible shell-plate thickness of  1 / 2  in., a maximum allowable design stress of 21,000 lbf/in. 2 , a joint efficiency of 0.85, and no
corrosion allowance (see A.4.1).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE  The nominal capacities given in this table were calculated using the following formula:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In SI units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>C  = 0.785 D 2 H<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>where<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>C  is the capacity of tank, in m 3 ;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>D   is the diameter of tank, in m (see A.4.1);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H   is the height of tank, in m (see A.4.1).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The capacities and diameters in italics (Columns 4 through 9) are the maximums for the tank heights given in the column heads, based on a
maximum permissible shell-plate thickness of 13 mm, a maximum allowable design stress of 145 MPa, a joint efficiency of 0.85, and no corrosion
allowance (see A.4.1).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>In USC units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>C  = 0.14 D 2 H<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>where<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>C
is the capacity of tank, 42-gal barrels;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>D
is the diameter of tank, in ft (see A.4.1);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H
is the height of tank, in ft (see A.4.1).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The capacities and diameters in italics (Columns 4 through 9) are the maximums for the tank heights given in the column heads, based on a
maximum permissible shell-plate thickness of  1 / 2  in., a maximum allowable design stress of 21,000 lbf/in. 2 , a joint efficiency of 0.85, and no
corrosion allowance (see A.4.1).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

| a Based on a maximum permissible shell-plate thickness of 1/2 in., a maximum allowable design stress of 21,000 lbf/in.2, a joint efficiency of |                                                        |          |          |          |          |          |          |          |            |
| 0.85, and no corrosion allowance.                                                                                                              |                                                        |          |          |          |          |          |          |          |            |
| NOTE The plate thicknesses shown in this table are based on a maximum allowable design stress of 21,000 lbf/in.2, a joint efficiency of 0.85,  |                                                        |          |          |          |          |          |          |          |            |
| and no corrosion allowance (see A.4.1).                                                                                                        |                                                        |          |          |          |          |          |          |          |            |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_200>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A-10
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A.2.4  Bottom reinforcing plates in flush-type cleanouts and flush-type shell connections, and flush-type fitting necks
attached to shell shall conform to toughness requirements of 4.2.9 and Figure 4.1 at design metal temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>A.3 Design<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>A.3.1  The maximum tensile stress before the joint efficiency factor is applied shall be 145 MPa (21,000 lbf/in. 2 ).<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>A.3.2  Stresses shall be computed on the assumption that the tank is filled with water (specific gravity = 1.0) or with
the liquid to be stored if it is heavier than water.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A.3.3  The tension in each ring shall be computed 300 mm (12 in.) above the centerline of the lower horizontal joint
of the course in question. When these stresses are computed, the tank diameter shall be taken as the nominal
diameter of the bottom course.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A.3.4  The joint efficiency factor shall be 0.85 with the spot radiography required by A.5.3. By agreement between
the Purchaser and the Manufacturer, the spot radiography may be omitted, and a joint efficiency factor of 0.70 shall
be used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>A.4 Thickness of Shell Plates<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>A.4.1  The nominal thicknesses of shell plates shall not be less than that computed from the stress on the vertical
joints, using the following formula:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In SI units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t

<<PARAGRAPH>>where<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t
is the nominal thickness, in mm (see 5.6.1.1);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>D
is the nominal diameter of the tank, in m (see 5.6.1.1, Note 1);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H
is the design liquid level, in m (see 5.6.3.2);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>G
is the design specific gravity of the liquid to be stored, as specified by the Purchaser. The design specific
gravity shall not be less than 1.0;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>●
14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>E
is the joint efficiency, which is either 0.85 or 0.70 (see A.3.4);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>CA

<<PARAGRAPH>>G

<<HEADING level=3>>●

<<PARAGRAPH>>E
is the joint efficiency, which is either 0.85 or 0.70 (see A.3.4);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>CA
is the corrosion allowance, in inches, as specified by the Purchaser (see 5.3.2).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A.4.2  The nominal thickness of shell plates (including shell extensions for floating roofs) shall not be less than that
listed in 5.6.1.1. The nominal thickness of shell plates refers to the tank shell as constructed. The nominal thicknesses
given in 5.6.1.1 are based on erection requirements.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>A.5 Tank Joints<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>A.5.1  Vertical and horizontal joints in the shell, bottom joints, shell-to-bottom joints, wind-girder joints, and roof and
top-angle joints shall conform to 5.1.5.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A.5.2  The requirements of 5.7.3 for the spacing of welds do not apply except for the requirement that the spacing
between the toes of welds around a connection shall not be less than 2 1 / 2  times the shell thickness at the connection
(i.e. dimension A, B, C, or E in Figure 5.6 shall not be less than 2 1 / 2  times the shell thickness).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A.5.3  When radiographic examination is required (joint efficiency = 0.85), the spot radiographs of vertical joints shall
conform to 8.1.2.2, Item a only, excluding the 10 mm ( 3 / 8  in.) shell-thickness limitation in Item a and excluding the
additional random spot radiograph required by Item a. The spot radiographs of horizontal joints shall conform to
8.1.2.3.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>A.6 Intermediate Wind Girders<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Calculations for and installation of intermediate wind girders are not required unless specified by the Purchaser.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>A.7 Shell Manholes and Nozzles<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>A.7.1  Except for other designs and shapes permitted by 5.7.1.2, shell manholes shall conform to 5.7.5, Figure 5.7a,
Figure 5.7b, and Tables 5.3a through 5.5b.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A.7.2  Shell nozzles and flanges shall conform to 5.7.6; Figure 5.7b, Figure 5.8, and Figure 5.10; and Tables 5.6a
through 5.8b. For regular type reinforced nozzles, minimum elevation dimension  H N  shown in column 8 of Table 5.6
may be reduced when specified by the Purchaser provided the minimum weld spacing of A.5.2 is maintained.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>A.7.3  The radiographic requirements of 5.7.3.4 do not apply.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>A.8 Flush-Type Cleanout Fittings<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>A.8.1  The details and dimensions of flush-type cleanout fittings shall conform to 5.7.7, Figure 5.12 and Figure 5.13,
and Tables 5.9a through 5.11b.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A.8.2  The provisions for stress relief specified in 5.7.4 and 5.7.7.3 are not required unless they are specified by the
Purchaser or unless any plate in the unit has a thickness greater than 16 mm ( 5 / 8  in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>A.9 Flush-Type Shell Connections<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>A.9.1  The details and dimensions of flush-type shell connections shall conform to 5.7.8, Figure 5.14, and Table
5.12a and Table 5.12b.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A.9.2  The provisions for stress relief specified in 5.7.4 and 5.7.8.3 are not required unless they are specified by the
Purchaser or unless any plate in the assembly has a thickness greater than 16 mm ( 5 / 8  in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_202>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_203>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Annex AL
(normative)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Aluminum Storage Tanks<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.1 Scope<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.1.1 Construction<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>This Annex provides material, design, fabrication, erection, and inspecting requirements for vertical, cylindrical,
aboveground, closed- and open top, welded aluminum storage tanks constructed of the alloys specified in AL.4.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.1.2 Requirements<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>This Annex states only the requirements that differ from the rules in this standard. For requirements not stated, follow
the rules of this standard.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.1.3 Temperature<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>This Annex applies for maximum design temperatures up to 200  ° C (400  ° F). Alloys 5083, 5086, 5154, 5183, 5254,
5356, 5456, 5556, and 5654 shall not be used if the maximum design temperature exceeds 65  ° C (150  ° F). Ambient
temperature tanks shall have a maximum design temperature of 40  ° C (100  ° F).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>For maximum design temperatures above 93  ° C (200  ° F) designers shall consider thermal stresses and fatigue.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.1.4 Units<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Use consistent units in this Annex’s equations. For example, in an equation, use inches for all lengths (stress in lb/in. 2<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>and tank diameter in inches) or use mm for all lengths (stress in N/mm 2  and tank diameter in mm).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.1.5 Nomenclature<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Variables used in this Annex have the following meanings:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A
=
area of the roof-to-shell joint determined using Figure F.2<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A 1
= 0.3 m (1 ft)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>CA   = corrosion allowance, as specified by the Purchaser (see 5.3.2)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>D
= nominal diameter of the tank (see 5.6.1.1)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>E
=
compressive modulus of elasticity (see Table AL.8a and Table AL.8b)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>E j
= joint efficiency, 1.0, 0.85, or 0.70 (see Table AL.2)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>F tu   = minimum tensile ultimate strength<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>F ty   = minimum tensile yield strength<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>G
=
design specific gravity of the stored liquid<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H
=
design liquid level (see 5.6.3.2)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>p h
= greater of 5.2.2 load combinations (e)(1) and (e)(2)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>AL-1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_204>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>AL-2
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S d
= allowable stress for the design condition (see Table AL.6a and Table AL.6b)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S t
= allowable stress for hydrostatic test condition (see Table AL.6a and Table AL.6b)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t b
= nominal thickness of the annular bottom plate<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t h
= nominal roof thickness<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t s
= nominal shell thickness<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W  = weight of the shell and any framing (but not roof plates) supported by the shell<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>γ w  = density of water<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>θ
= roof slope to horizontal at the shell<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>ρ h  = density of the roof plate<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<HEADING level=3>>AL.3 Definitions<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>For the purposes of this Annex, the following definition applies:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.3.1
aluminum
Aluminum and aluminum alloys.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.4 Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.4.1 General<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Alloys shall be selected from Table AL.1. Dimensional tolerances shall meet the material specifications given in AL.4.
Impact testing and toughness verification are not required.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.4.2 Sheet and Plate<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Sheet and plate shall meet ASTM B209 or B928. Tapered thickness plate may be used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.4.3 Rod, Bar, and Structural Shapes<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Rod, bar, and shapes shall meet ASTM B211, ASTM B221, or ASTM B308.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.4.4 Pipe and Tube<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Pipe and tube shall meet ASTM B210, ASTM B241, or ASTM B345.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>AL-4
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_209>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
AL-7<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.4.5 Forgings<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Forgings shall meet ASTM B247.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.4.6 Flanges<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.4.6.1 Aluminum<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Flanges shall meet ASTM B247 and be 6061-T6. Flange dimensions shall meet ASME B16.5 or B16.47.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.4.6.2 Composite Lap Joint Flanges<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>For composite lap joint flanges, the aluminum stub ends shall be one of the alloys listed in Table AL.1 for sheet and
plate or pipe and tube, and the steel, stainless steel, or galvanized steel flanges shall meet ASME B16.5.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.4.7 Bolting<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.4.7.1 Aluminum<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Aluminum bolts shall meet ASTM F468. Aluminum nuts shall meet ASTM F467. Bolts and nuts of 2024 alloy shall
have an anodic coating at least 0.005 mm [0.0002 in.] thick. Bolts shall not be welded. Aluminum threads tend to gall,
so aluminum threaded parts shall not be used where they must be reinstalled.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.4.7.2 Stainless Steel<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Stainless steel bolts shall meet ASTM F593 alloy group 1 or 2, or ASTM A193 B8. Stainless steel nuts shall meet
ASTM F594 alloy group 1 or 2 or ASTM A194 Grade 8.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.4.7.3 Carbon Steel<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Carbon steel bolts shall be galvanized.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.4.8 Welding Electrodes<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Welding electrodes shall meet AWS A5.10/A5.10M and shall be chosen in accordance with AWS D1.2.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.5 Design<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.5.1 Joints<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Joints shall be as prescribed in 5.1.5 unless otherwise specified below.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.5.1.1 Bottom Joints<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) Bottom plates under the shell thicker than 8 mm ( 5 / 16  in.) shall be butt welded.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)  Butt-Welded Bottom Joints . The butt welds may be made from both sides or from one side and shall have full
penetration and full fusion. In the latter case, a backing strip 5 mm ( 3 / 16  in.) or thicker, of an aluminum alloy
compatible with the bottom plate, shall be tacked to one of the plates, and the intersection joints of the strips shall
be welded with full penetration and full fusion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_210>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>AL-8
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.5.1.2 Roof and Top Angle Joints<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The moment of inertia of the top angle and contributing portion of the shell (see AL.5.5) shall equal or exceed that
provided by the sizes listed below:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In SI units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Diameter (m)
Size (mm)<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>D  < 11
65  ×  65  ×  6<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>11 <  D  < 18
65  ×  65  ×  8<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>18 <  D
75  ×  75  ×  10<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In USC units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Diameter (ft)
Size (in.)<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>D  < 35
2  1 / 2   ×  2  1 / 2   ×   1 / 4<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>35 <  D   ≤  61
2  1 / 2   ×  2  1 / 2   ×   5 / 16<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>61 <  D
3  ×  3  ×   3 / 8<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.5.2 Bottoms<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.5.2.1 Annular Bottom Plate Width<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Annular bottom plates shall have a radial width that meets the requirements of 5.5.2 except that the width must equal
or exceed:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2 t b
F ty
2 γ w GH
-----------------<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.5.2.2 Annular Bottom Plate Thickness<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The nominal thickness of annular bottom plates shall equal or exceed the requirements given in Table AL.4a and
Table AL.4b.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>AL-10
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.5.4 Shell Openings<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.5.4.1 Thermal Stress Relief<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Thermal stress relief requirements of 5.7.4 do not apply.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.5.4.2 Shell Manholes<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Shell manholes shall meet 5.7.5 except the following.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)  Cover Plate and Flange Thickness . The cover plate and flange thickness shall comply with Figure AL.1 and Figure
AL.2. As an alternative to Figure AL.1 and Figure AL.2, plate flanges may be designed in accordance with API 620
rules using the allowable stresses from Table AL.6a and Table AL.6b.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)  Neck Thickness . Where manhole neck thickness is controlled by thickness of the bolting flange (see note b of
Table 5.4a and Table 5.4b), the flange thickness determined in item 1 above shall be used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)  Weld Sizes : Fillet weld A shall comply with Table AL.9a and Table AL.9b.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.5.4.3 Nozzles<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Shell nozzles shall meet 5.7.6 except fillet weld A shall comply with Table AL.9a and Table AL.9b.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.5.4.4 Flush Type Cleanouts<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Flush-type cleanout fittings shall comply with Figure AL.1, Figure AL.2, and Figure AL.3.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>p

wind girders, the vertical distance between the intermediate wind girder and the top angle of the shell or
the top wind girder of an open-top tank;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 5  The design stress shall be the lesser of  1 / 3   of the minimum tensile strength, 0.8 of the minimum yield strength, the stress producing a
secondary creep rate of 0.1 % in 1000 hr, or 67 % of the average stress for rupture at the end of 100,000 hr.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 6  The allowable test stress shall be the lesser of  1 / 3  of the minimum tensile strength or 0.85 of the minimum yield strength at ambient
temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 4  Strengths are for the – O temper for all alloys except 6061, Alclad 6061, and 6063.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 5  The design stress shall be the lesser of  1 / 3  of the minimum tensile strength, 0.8 of the minimum yield strength, the stress producing a
secondary creep rate of 0.1 % in 1000 hr, or 67 % of the average stress for rupture at the end of 100,000 hr.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 6  The allowable test stress shall be the lesser of  1 / 3  of the minimum tensile strength or 0.85 of the minimum yield strength at ambient
temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<HEADING level=3>>A.5.5.2  Intermediate Wind Girders<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The height of the unstiffened shell shall not exceed:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H 1

<<PARAGRAPH>>where<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H 1
is the vertical distance between the intermediate wind girder and the top angle of the shell or the top
wind girder of an open-top tank;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t
is the nominal thickness, unless otherwise specified, of the top shell course;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>E MDT
is the modulus of elasticity at the maximum design temperature;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>E 40
is the modulus of elasticity at 40  ° C (100  ° F).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.5.6 Roofs<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.5.6.1 Structural Members<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The minimum nominal thickness of structural members shall be 4 mm (0.15 in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.5.6.2 Frangible Roofs<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Roofs required to be frangible shall meet the requirements of 5.10.2.6 except that the cross sectional area  A  of the
roof-to-shell joint shall not exceed 0.159 W /( F ty   tan θ ) where  F ty  = the greatest tensile yield strength of the materials in
the joint.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.5.6.3 Allowable Stresses<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Roofs shall be proportioned so that stresses from the load combinations specified in 5.10.2.1 do not exceed the
allowable stresses given in the  Aluminum Design Manual (ADM) Specification for Aluminum Structures—Allowable
Stress Design for building type structures.  Allowable stresses for ambient temperature service shall be calculated
using the minimum mechanical properties given in the ADM. Allowable stresses for elevated temperature service
shall be calculated using the minimum mechanical properties given in Table AL.8a and Table AL.8b. Section 5.10.3.4
does not apply.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.5.6.4 Supported Cone Roofs<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) The stresses determined from Figure AL.4 for dead load and dead and live loads for the thickness and span of
roof plates shall not exceed the allowable stresses given in Table AL.7a and Table AL.7b.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) The roof supporting structure shall be of 6061-T6 or 6063-T6 and proportioned so stresses do not exceed
allowable stresses. Dead load stresses for temperatures over 120  ° C (250  ° F) shall not exceed 25 % of allowable
stresses.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) Low cycle fatigue failures may occur at the roof-to-top-angle weld and at roof lap welds for roofs designed to the
minimum requirements of this standard when:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1) the internal pressure exceeds the weight of the roof plates; or<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2) tanks larger than 15 m (50 ft) in diameter are subjected to steady wind speeds of 40 to 50 km/hr (25 to 30 mph)
or greater.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_219>>

|                                                                                                                                                    |        | (dead + live load) | 9.6 | 9.6  | 9.6                     | 9.45 | 8.85 | 7.45 | 5.65 |
| NOTE For non-heat treatable alloys, allowable stresses for dead + live loads are the lesser of the yield strength, the stress producing a          |        |                    |     |      |                         |      |      |      |      |
| secondary creep rate of 0.1 % in 10,000 hr, 67 % of the average stress for rupture after 100,000 hr. For heat treatable alloys, allowable stresses |        |                    |     |      |                         |      |      |      |      |
| are 40 % of the minimum strength of groove welds.                                                                                                  |        |                    |     |      |                         |      |      |      |      |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
|    |    |    |    |    |    | = 400   |       |    |    |    |
|:---|:---|:---|:---|:---|:---|:--------|:------|:---|:---|:---|

<<HEADING level=3>>AL.5.6.7 Structurally Supported Aluminum Dome Roofs<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Structurally supported aluminum dome roofs shall meet Annex G.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_225>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
AL-23<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.6
Fabrication<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.6.1
Finish of Plate Edges<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>At least 3 mm ( 1 / 8  in.) shall be mechanically removed from edges of heat treatable alloys that have been plasma arc
cut. Oxygen cutting shall not be used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.6.2
Marking Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Marking materials shall not contain carbon or heavy metal compounds.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.7
Erection<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.7.1
Welding Methods<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Welding shall be gas metal arc welding, gas tungsten arc welding, plasma arc welding without using flux, or friction
stir welding. The welding may be performed by the manual, machine, automatic, or semiautomatic welding processes
according to procedures by welders or welding operators qualified in accordance with ASME Section IX or AWS D1.2.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.7.2
Preheating<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Parts to be welded shall not be preheated except to the extent needed to drive off moisture or bring base metal
temperature up to minimum welding temperature per 7.2.1.2.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.7.3
Plumbness<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The plumbness requirements shall be per 7.5.2 except the out-of-plumbness in any shell course shall not exceed the
flatness tolerance in ASTM B209M (B209).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.7.4
Storage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Aluminum parts shall not be stored in contact with one another when moisture is present. Aluminum shall not be
stored or erected in contact with carbon steel or the ground.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.7.5
Quality of Test Water<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>AL.7.5.1
The materials used in the construction of aluminum tanks and materials used for tank components that
may be subject to severe pitting, cracking, or rusting if they are exposed to contaminated test water for extended
periods of time. The Purchaser shall specify a minimum quality of test water that conforms to AL.7.5.1.1 through
AL.7.5.1.8.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.7.5.1.1
Water shall be substantially clean and clear.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.7.5.1.2
Water shall have no objectionable odor (i.e. no hydrogen sulfide).<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.7.5.1.3
Water pH shall be between 6 and 8.3.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.7.5.1.4
Water temperature shall be below 50 °C (120 °F).<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.7.5.1.5
Water mercury content shall be less than 0.005 ppm.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.7.5.1.6
Water copper content shall be less than 0.02 ppm.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_226>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>AL-24
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.7.5.1.7
Water shall have chloride content not exceeding 200 ppm.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.7.5.1.8
The water used to test the tank shall either:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1) be potable water with a free residual chlorine of at least 0.2 ppm, or<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2) be tested for harmful microorganism content and found acceptable in accordance with parameters set by the
owner.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.7.5.2
After the hydrostatic test is completed, the tank shall be promptly drained, cleaned, and dried.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.8
Examination of Welds<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.8.1
Liquid Penetrant Examination<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The following welds shall be examined by the liquid penetrant method before the hydrostatic test of the tank:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) shell opening reinforcement and structural attachment plates, excluding lightly loaded attachments, that intersect
a shell weld shall be examined for a distance of 150 mm (6 in.) on each side of the intersection and the butt weld
for a distance of 50 mm (2 in.) beyond the pad weld;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) all welds of openings in the shell that are not completely radiographed, including nozzle and manhole neck welds
and neck-to-flange welds;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) all butt-welded joints in tank shell and annular plate on which backing strips are to remain.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.8.2
Magnetic Particle Examination<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Section 8.2 does not apply.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.9
Welding Procedures and Welder Qualifications<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Weld procedures and welder qualifications shall meet Section 9 except that impact tests are not required.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.10
Marking<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.10.1
Material<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In addition to the requirements of Section 10, the bottom and roof alloys shall be shown on the nameplate.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.11
Foundations<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.11.1
Concrete<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Aluminum shall not be placed in direct contact with concrete.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.12
Internal Pressure<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>AL.12.1
General<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Annex F shall be met with the following exceptions.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>

<<HEADING level=3>>AL.14
