<<HEADING level=3>>F.3 Roof Details<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The details of the roof-to-shell junction shall be in accordance with Figure F.2, in which the participating area resisting
the compressive force is shaded with diagonal lines.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>F.4 Maximum Design Pressure and Test Procedure<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>F.4.1  The maximum design pressure,  P , for a tank that has been constructed or that has had its design details
established may be calculated from the following equation (subject to the limitations of  P max  in F.4.2):<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In SI units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>A

<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>F y
is the lowest minimum specified yield strength (modified for design temperature) of the materials in the
roof-to-shell junction, in MPa;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>is the angle between the roof and a horizontal plane at the roof-to-shell junction, in degrees;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>tan  θ
is the slope of the roof, expressed as a decimal quantity;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>D LR
is the nominal weight of roof plate plus any structural members attached to the roof plate, in N.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>F y

roof-to-shell junction, in lb/inch 2 ;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>is the angle between the roof and a horizontal plane at the roof-to-shell junction, in degrees;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>tan  θ

<<PARAGRAPH>>D LR

<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>F.4.2  For unanchored tanks, the maximum design pressure, limited by uplift at the base of the shell, shall not
exceed the value calculated from the following equations as applicable unless further limited by F.4.3:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
F-5<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>For unanchored fixed roof tanks except supported cone roof tanks, the maximum design pressure ( P max ) shall be the
minimum of (3) cases:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>where<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>D
is the tank diameter, m (ft);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>β
is the conversion factor: for SI = [8/(π  ×  1000)], for USC = [(8  ×  12)/(π  ×  62.4)];<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>F p
is the pressure combination factor, see 5.2.2;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>M DL
is moment about the shell-to-bottom joint from the nominal weight of the shell and roof structural
supported by the shell that is not attached to the roof plate, N  ×  m (ft  ×  lbf);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>M DLR  is the moment about the shell-to-bottom joint from the nominal weight of the roof plate plus any structural
components attached to the roof, N  ×  m (ft  ×  lbf);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>M F
is the moment about the shell-to-bottom joint from liquid weight per 5.11.2.3, N  ×  m (ft  ×  lbf);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>M w
is the overturning moment about the shell-to-bottom joint from horizontal plus vertical wind pressure,
N  ×  m (ft  ×  lbf);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>M ws
is the overturning moment about the shell-to-bottom joint from horizontal wind pressure, N  ×  m (ft  ×  lbf);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P max
is the maximum design pressure kPa (inches of water).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>F.4.3  As top angle size and roof slope decrease and tank diameter increases, the design pressure permitted by
F.4.1 and F.4.2 approaches the failure pressure of F.7 for the roof-to-shell junction. In order to provide a safe margin
between the maximum operating pressure and the calculated failure pressure, a suggested further limitation on the
maximum design pressure for tanks with a weak roof-to-shell attachment (frangible joint) is:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P max   ≤  0.8 P f<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>F.4.4  When the entire tank is completed, it shall be filled with water to the top angle or the design liquid level, and the
design internal air pressure shall be applied to the enclosed space above the water level and held for 15 minutes. The
air pressure shall then be reduced to one-half the design pressure, and all welded joints above the liquid level shall be
checked for leaks by means of a soap film, linseed oil, or another suitable material. Tank vents shall be tested during
or after this test.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_316>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>F-6
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>F.5 Required Compression Area at the Roof-to-Shell Junction<<HEADING_END>>

excluding corrosion allowance.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 2  Calculated thickness ( t ) of roof plates shall not be less than that required under 5.10.4 for supported cone or less than
that required under 5.10.5 for self-supporting cone roofs.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

umbrella roofs.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 3  An alternate analysis technique (such as finite element analysis) of the roof is acceptable, as long as the allowable
stresses and joint efficiencies referenced above are applied to define the minimum thickness. Notes 1 and 2 shall still apply.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>F.6.3   The rules in F.6.1 and F.6.2 cannot cover all details of tank roof design and construction. With the approval
of the Purchaser, the roof need not comply with F.6. The manufacturer shall provide a roof designed and
constructed to be as safe as otherwise provided for in this standard.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>F.7  Calculated Failure Pressure<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Failure of the roof-to-shell junction can be expected to occur when the stress in the compression ring area reaches
the yield point. On this basis, an approximate formula for the pressure at which failure of the top compression ring is
expected (using conservative effective areas) to occur can be expressed in terms of the design pressure permitted by
F.4.1, as follows:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In SI units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P f
1.6  P
0.000746  D  LR
D
2
---------------------------------<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>where<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P f
is the calculated minimum failure pressure, in kPa;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>D LR
is the nominal weight of roof plate plus any attached structural, in N.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In USC units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P  f
1.6  P
0.147  D  L R
D
2
------------------------<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>where<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P f
is the calculated minimum failure pressure, in inches of water;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>D LR
is the nominal weight of roof plate plus any attached structural, in lbf.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE     Experience with actual failures indicates that buckling of the roof-to-shell junction is localized and probably occurs when
the yield point of the material is exceeded in the compression area.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_319>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
F-9<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>F.8  Anchored Tanks with Design Pressures up to 18 kPa (2.5   psi) Gauge<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>F.8.1   The design of the anchorage and its attachment to the tank shall be a matter of agreement between the
Manufacturer and the Purchaser and shall meet the requirements of 5.12.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>F.8.2   The counterbalancing weight,   in addition to the requirements in 5.12, shall be designed so that the resistance
to uplift at the bottom of the shell will be the greatest of the following.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) The uplift produced by 1.5 times the design pressure of the corroded empty tank plus the uplift from the design
wind velocity on the tank.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) The uplift produced by 1.25 times the test pressure applied to the empty tank (with the nominal thicknesses).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) The uplift produced by 1.5 times the calculated failure pressure ( P f    in F.6) applied to the tank filled with the design
liquid. The effective weight of the liquid shall be limited to the inside projection of the ringwall (Annex B type) from
the tank shell. Friction between the soil and the ringwall may be included as resistance. When a footing is included
in the ringwall design, the effective weight of the soil may be included.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>F.8.3   After the tank is filled with water, the shell and the anchorage shall be visually inspected for tightness. Air
pressure of 1.25 times the design pressure shall be applied to the tank filled with water to the design liquid height. The
air pressure shall be reduced to the design pressure, and the tank shall be checked for tightness. In addition, all
seams above the water level shall be tested using a soap film or another material suitable for the detection of leaks.
After the test water has been emptied from the tank (and the tank is at atmospheric pressure), the anchorage shall be
checked for tightness. The design air pressure shall then be applied to the tank for a final check of the anchorage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_320>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_321>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Annex G
(normative)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Structurally-Supported Aluminum Dome Roofs<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.1 General<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.1.1 Purpose<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>This Annex establishes minimum criteria for the design, fabrication, and erection of structurally-supported aluminum
dome roofs. When this Annex is applicable, the requirements of 5.10 and the paragraphs in Annex F that deal with
roof design are superseded. All other requirements of API Standard 650 shall apply, except that the maximum design
temperature shall not exceed 90 °C (200 °F).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.1.2 Definition<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A structurally-supported aluminum dome roof is a fully triangulated aluminum space truss with the struts joined at
points arrayed on the surface of a sphere. Aluminum closure panels are firmly attached to the frame members. The
roof is attached to and supported by the tank at mounting points equally spaced around the perimeter of the tank.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.1.3 General Application<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.1.3.1 New Tanks<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>When this Annex is specified for a new tank, the tank shall be designed to support the aluminum dome roof. The roof
Manufacturer shall supply the magnitude and direction of all the forces acting on the tank as a result of the roof loads,
together with details of the roof-to-shell attachment. The tank shall be designed as an open-top tank, and its wind
girder shall meet the requirements of 5.9. The top of the tank shell shall be structurally suitable for attachment of the
dome roof structure. The tank Manufacturer and the foundation designer shall be responsible for designing the tank
and foundation, respectively, for the loads and moments transmitted from the roof, as provided by the roof
manufacturer. If the Purchaser specifies a roof with fixed supports, the supports shall be rigidly attached directly to the
tank and the top of the tank shall be designed to sustain the horizontal thrust transferred from the roof (see G.5.2).
The as-built minimum and maximum diameter at the top of the tank shall be reported to the roof manufacturer by the
Purchaser or the tank Manufacturer.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.1.3.2 Existing Tanks<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>When this Annex is specified for an aluminum dome roof to be added to an existing tank (with or without an existing
roof), the roof Manufacturer shall verify that the tank has sufficient strength to support a new roof and meet the
applicable requirements of Section 5.11. Information on the existing tank shall be provided by the Purchaser including
minimum tank shell course thicknesses, tank shell course heights, design corrosion allowance, and existing
anchorage details. The Purchaser shall specify the existing or new appurtenances to be accommodated by the roof
Manufacturer. The roof Manufacturer shall supply the values of the forces acting on the tank as a result of the roof
loads. The Purchaser shall verify the adequacy of the foundations. Unless otherwise specified, any reinforcement
required to enable the tank to support the roof shall be the responsibility of the Purchaser. The design and erection of
the roof shall accommodate the actual tank shape. The responsibility for determining the tank shape shall be
specified by the Purchaser. The existing tank shall be equipped with a wind girder that meets the requirements of 5.9
for an open-top tank.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.1.3.3 Existing Tank Data Sheet<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>When an aluminum dome is ordered for an existing tank, a data sheet shall be completed by the Purchaser (see
Figure G.1).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>G-1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<HEADING level=3>>Figure G.1—Data Sheet for a Structurally-Supported Aluminum Dome Added to an Existing Tank<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_323>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
G-3<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.1.4 Special Features<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.1.4.1 Self-Supporting Structure<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The aluminum dome roof shall be supported only from the rim of the tank. The design of the connection between the
roof and the tank rim shall allow for thermal expansion. A minimum temperature range of ±70 °C (120 °F) shall be
used for design unless a wider range is specified by the Purchaser.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.1.4.2 Finish<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Unless otherwise specified, the aluminum dome roof materials shall have a mill finish.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.1.4.3 Maintenance and Inspection<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The roof Manufacturer shall provide a maintenance and inspection manual for roof items that may require
maintenance, periodic inspection, or both.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.1.4.4 Jurisdictional Requirements<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The Purchaser is required to provide all applicable jurisdictional requirements that apply to the aluminum dome roof
(see 1.3).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.2 Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.2.1 General<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Materials furnished to meet the requirements of this Annex shall be new. A complete material specification shall be
submitted by the roof Manufacturer for approval by the Purchaser. The materials shall be compatible with the product
specified to be stored in the tank and the surrounding environment. No aluminum alloy with a magnesium content
greater than 3 % shall be used when the maximum design temperature exceeds 65 °C (150 °F). Properties and
tolerances of aluminum alloys shall conform to  Aluminum Standards and Data , as published by the Aluminum
Association (Washington, D.C.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.2.2 Structural Frame<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Structural frame members shall be fabricated from 6061-T6 or a recognized alloy with properties established by the
Aluminum Association, Inc.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.2.3 Roof Panels<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Roof panels shall be fabricated from Series 3000 or 5000 aluminum with a minimum nominal thickness of 1.20 mm
(0.050 in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.2.4 Bolts and Fasteners<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Fasteners shall be of 7075-T73 aluminum, 2024-T4 aluminum, austenitic stainless steel, or other materials as agreed
to by the Purchaser. Only stainless steel fasteners shall be used to attach aluminum to steel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.2.5 Sealant and Gasket Material<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>G.2.5.1  Sealants shall be silicone or urea urethane compounds that conform to Federal Spec TT-S-00230C unless
another material is required for compatibility with stored materials. Sealants shall remain flexible over a temperature<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_324>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>G-4
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>range of –60 °C to +150 °C (–80 °F to +300 °F) without tearing, cracking, or becoming brittle. Elongation, tensile
strength, hardness, and adhesion shall not change significantly with aging or exposure to ozone, ultraviolet light, or
vapors from the product stored in the tank.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>G.2.5.2  Preformed gasket material shall be Neoprene, silicone, Buna-N, urea urethane, or EPDM elastomer
meeting ASTM C509 or Federal Spec ZZ-R-765C unless another material is required for compatibility with stored
materials.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.2.6 Skylight Panels<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Skylight panels shall be clear acrylic or polycarbonate with a minimum nominal thickness of 6 mm (0.25 in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.3 Allowable Stresses<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.3.1 Aluminum Structural Members<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Aluminum structural members and connections shall be designed in accordance with the  Aluminum Design Manual ,
as published by the Aluminum Association, Inc. (Washington, D.C.), except as modified by this Annex.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.3.2 Aluminum Panels<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Aluminum panels shall be designed in accordance with S pecifications for Aluminum Sheet Metal Work in Building
Construction , as published by the Aluminum Association, Inc. (Washington, D.C.) and this Annex. Attachment
fasteners shall not penetrate both the panel and the flange of the structural member.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.3.3 Bolts and Fasteners<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.3.3.1  The maximum stress in bolts and fasteners for any design condition shall not exceed the allowable stress
given in Table G.1a and Table G.1b.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.3.3.2  The hole diameter for a fastener shall not exceed the diameter of the fastener plus 1.5 mm ( 1 / 16  in.).<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Table G.1a—Bolts and Fasteners (SI)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Allowable Tensile Stress a,b
Allowable Shear Stress a,b,c<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>(MPa)
(MPa)<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Austenitic stainless steel d
172
124<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Austenitic stainless steel e
234
172<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2024-T4 aluminum
182
109<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>7075-T73 aluminum
201
120<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a
The root-of-thread area shall be used to calculate the strength of threaded parts.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b
For seismic loads, these values may be increased by one-third.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c
If the thread area is completely out of the shear area, the cross-sectional area of the shank may be used
to determine the allowable shear load.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d
For bolts with a minimum tensile strength of 620 MPa.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e
For bolts with a minimum tensile strength of 860 MPa.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f
For fasteners not shown, design shall be in accordance with the  Aluminum Design Manual , as published
by the Aluminum Association, Inc. (Washington, D.C.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<HEADING level=3>>G.4
Design<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.4.1
Design Principles<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>G.4.1.1
The roof framing system shall be designed as a three-dimensional space frame or truss with membrane
covering (roof panels) providing loads along the length of the individual members. The design must consider the
increased compression induced in the framing members due to the tension in the roof panels.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>G.4.1.2
The actual stresses in the framing members and panels under all design load conditions shall be less than
or equal to the allowable stresses per the  Aluminum Design Manual , as published by the Aluminum Association, Inc.
(Washington, D.C.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>G.4.1.3
The allowable general buckling pressure  p a  shall equal or exceed the maximum pressure given in 5.2.2 (e).<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>p a
1.6 E
I x A<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>(G.4.1.3-1)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>LR
2  SF
------------------------
=
15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>where<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>E
is the modulus of elasticity of the dome frame members;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>I x
is the moment of inertia of frame members for bending in a plane normal to the dome surface;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A
is the cross-sectional area of frame members;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>R
is the spherical radius of the dome;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L
is the average length of the frame members;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>SF  is the safety factor = 1.65.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Alternatively,  p a  shall be determined by a non-linear finite element analysis with a safety factor of 1.65.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
