<<HEADING level=3>>I.7 Tanks Supported by Grillage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>I.7.1  Tanks designed and constructed in accordance with API Standard 650 that have a maximum nominal shell
thickness of 13 mm ( 1 / 2  in.), including any customer specified corrosion allowance, and maximum design temperature
not exceeding 93 °C (200 °F) may be supported by steel or concrete grillage. By agreement between the Purchaser
and the Manufacturer, these rules may be applied to tanks with shell thickness greater than 13 mm ( 1 / 2  in.). These
rules apply to single steel butt-welded bottoms supported by grillage members.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>I.7.2  The thickness and design metal temperature of the bottom plate shall be in accordance with Figure 4.1.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_348>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>I-6
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

at edge<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

ACI 350<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Piles (if required)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<HEADING level=3>>I.7.3  The maximum spacing between adjacent or radial grillage members and the bottom plate thickness shall
satisfy the requirements of I.7.3.1 and I.7.3.2.<<HEADING_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>I.7.4  The bottom plates shall be jointed together by butt-welds having complete penetration and complete fusion.
Joints shall be visually examined prior to welding to ensure the weld gap and fit-up will allow complete penetration.
Each weld pass shall be visually examined. The alignment and spacing of grillage members shall be such that the
joints between bottom plates are located approximately above the center of the grillage members to the greatest<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<HEADING level=3>>Figure I.10—Typical Leak Detection Wells<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>extent practical. Grillage members shall be arranged to minimize the length of unsupported tank shell spanning
between grillage members.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>I.7.5  Grillage members shall be symmetrical about their vertical centerline. Steel grillage members shall be
designed to prevent web crippling and web buckling as specified in Chapter K of the AISC,  Manual of Steel
Construction . Concrete grillage members may also be used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>I.7.6  The Purchaser shall specify the corrosion allowance to be added to steel grillage members. If a corrosion
allowance is required, the manner of application (added to webs only, added to webs and flanges, added to one
surface, added to all surfaces, and so forth) shall also be specified.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>I.7.7  For tanks designed to withstand wind or seismic loads, provisions shall be made to prevent sliding, distortion,
and overturning of the grillage members. Lateral bracing between the top and bottom flanges of adjacent steel<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_351>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
I-9<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Locate anchors near
grillage members<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Anchorage (if required)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Butt-welded joint

<<PARAGRAPH>>Butt-welded joint<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Grillage members<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>tg<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Top of
foundation<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>SECTION A-A<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Figure I.11—Tanks Supported by Grillage Members (General Arrangement)<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_352>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>I-10
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>grillage members may be required to prevent distortion and overturning. The lateral bracing and connections shall be
designed to transfer the specified lateral loads. If friction forces between the grillage members and the foundation are
not adequate to transfer the specified later load, the grillage members shall be anchored to the foundation.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>I.7.8  The tank shall be anchored to resist uplift forces (in excess of the corroded dead load) due to pressure and
wind or seismic overturning. Anchors shall be located near the intersection of the tank shell and a grillage member, or
near an additional stiffening member.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>I.7.9  The tank shell shall be designed to prevent local buckling at the grillage members and consideration shall be
given to shell distortion when the spacing of the grillage members is determined.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>I.7.10  The bottom plate and grillage members directly beneath roof support columns and other items supported by
the bottom shall be designed for the loads imposed. Additional support members are to be furnished if required to
adequately support the bottom.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>I.7.11  If flush-type cleanouts or flush-type shell connections are furnished, additional support members shall be
provided to adequately support the bottom-reinforcing and bottom-transition plates. As a minimum, the additional
support members shall consist of a circumferential member (minimum length and location according to Method A of
Figure 5.12) and radial support members. The radial support members shall extend from the circumferential member
to the inner edge of the bottom reinforcing (for flush-type cleanouts) or bottom-transition plate (for flush-type shell
connections). The circumferential spacing of the radial support members shall not exceed 300 mm (12 in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>I.7.12  For tanks located in a corrosive environment, and where atmospheric corrosion due to wet/dry cycles may
occur, consideration shall be given to protecting the soil side of the bottom plates, grillage members, and in particular,
the contact surface between the bottom plates and grillage members by utilizing protective coatings or by adding a
corrosion allowance to these members.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>I.8 Typical Installations<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Although it is not the intent of this Annex to provide detailed designs for the construction of undertank leak detection
systems and tanks supported by grillage, Figures I.1 through I.11 illustrate the general use and application of the
recommendations presented in this Annex.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_353>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Annex J
(normative)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Shop-Assembled Storage Tanks<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.1 Scope<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>J.1.1  This Annex provides requirements for the design and fabrication of vertical storage tanks in sizes that permit
complete shop assembly and delivery to the installation site in one piece. Storage tanks designed according to this
Annex shall not exceed 6 m (20 ft) in diameter.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.1.2  The application of this Annex to the design and fabrication of shop-assembled storage tanks shall be mutually
agreed upon by the Purchaser and the Manufacturer.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.2 Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.2.1  The material requirements of Annex A of this standard are applicable, except as noted in J.2.2.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.2.2  The selection of shell or bottom plate materials exceeding a nominal thickness of 13 mm ( 1 / 2  in.) shall be
based upon the requirements of Section 4 of this standard.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3 Design<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.1 Joints<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.1.1  Joints shall be designed as specified in 5.1; however, lap-welded joints in bottoms are not permissible. In
addition, the modifications given in J.3.1.2 through J.3.1.5 are applicable.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.1.2  All shell joints shall be butt-welded so that full penetration is produced without the use of back-up bars.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.1.3  Shell plates shall be sized to limit the number of plates to the smallest practical number consistent with
sound economic practice. Each course should preferably be constructed of one plate.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.1.4  Top angles are not required for flanged-roof tanks.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.1.5  Joints in bottom plates shall be butt-welded. The welding shall produce complete penetration of the parent
metal.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.2 Bottoms<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.2.1  All bottom plates shall have a minimum nominal thickness of 6 mm (0.236 in.) (49.8 kg/m 2  [10.2 lbf/ft 2 ], see
4.2.1.2 and 5.4.1).<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.2.2  Bottoms shall be constructed of a minimum number of pieces; wherever feasible they shall be constructed of
one piece.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>J.3.2.3  Bottoms may be flat or flat flanged. A flat-bottom shall project at least 25 mm (1 in.) beyond the outside
diameter of the weld attaching the bottom to the shell plate. A flat-flanged bottom shall have an inside corner radius
that is not less than three times the bottom thickness and a straight flange that is a minimum of 19 mm ( 3 / 4  in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>J.3.2.4  For flat bottoms, the attachment between the bottom edges of the lowest course shell plate and the bottom
plate shall be a continuous fillet weld laid on each side of the shell plate. Each fillet weld shall be sized in accordance
with 5.1.5.7. A flat-flanged bottom shall be attached to the shell by full-penetration butt-welds.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>J-1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_354>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>J-2
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.3 Shells<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Shell plates shall be designed in accordance with the formula given in A.4.1, but the nominal thickness of shell plates
shall not be less than the following:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) for tanks with a diameter less than or equal to 3.2 m (10.5 ft) to 4.8 mm ( 3 / 16  in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) for tanks with a diameter greater than 3.2 m (10.5 ft) to 6 mm (0.236 in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.4 Wind Girders For Open-Top Tanks<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Open-top tanks shall be provided with wind girders as specified in 5.9.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.5 Roofs<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.5.1 General<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>●
15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Roofs for tanks constructed in accordance with this Annex shall be of the self-supporting type and shall conform to either
J.3.5.2 or J.3.5.3. Alternate designs meeting the requirements of 5.10.2.8 are permitted with Purchaser approval.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.5.2 Cone Roofs<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Self-supporting cone roofs shall be designed as specified in 5.10.5, except they may be provided with a flange that
will permit butt-welded attachment to the shell (see J.3.1.4). Flanges shall be formed with a minimum inside corner
radius of three times the roof thickness or 19 mm ( 3 / 4  in.), whichever is larger.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.5.3 Dome and Umbrella Roofs<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Self-supporting dome and umbrella roofs shall be designed as specified in 5.10.6, except they may be flanged as
described in J.3.5.2. For dome roofs that are flanged, the radius of curvature shall not be limited to the maximum
requirements given in 5.10.6; instead, the curvature shall be limited by the depth of the roof, including the crown and
knuckle depth, as listed in Table J.1a and Table J.1b.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.5.4 Top Angles<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>When top angles are required, they shall be attached as specified in 5.10.7.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Table J.1a—Minimum Roof Depths for Shop-Assembled Dome-Roof Tanks (SI)<<HEADING_END>>

<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.6 Tank Connections and Appurtenances<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>J.3.6.1  Manholes, nozzles, and other connections in the shell shall be constructed and attached as specified in 5.7,
but it is unlikely that reinforcing plates will be required for manholes and nozzles in the tank shell. The need for
reinforcement shall be checked according to the procedure given in 5.7.2. Since the nominal shell-plate thicknesses
required by J.3.3 will normally exceed the calculated thickness, the excess material in the shell should satisfy the
reinforcement requirements in nearly all cases.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>J.3.6.2  The requirements of 5.7.3 for the spacing of welds do not apply except for the requirement that the spacing
between the toes of welds around a connection shall not be less than 2.5 times the shell thickness at the connection.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>J.3.6.3  The roofs of tanks constructed in accordance with this Annex will be inherently strong because of the
limitations in diameter required for shipping clearances. Thus, reinforcement of roof manholes and nozzles is not
required unless specifically requested by the Purchaser or unless roof loads exceed 1.2 kPa (25 lbf/ft 2 ), in which case
the amount and type of reinforcement shall be agreed upon by the Purchaser and the Manufacturer.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.6.4  For shell manholes and nozzles the radiographic requirements of 5.7.3.4 do not apply.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>J.3.6.5  For flush-type cleanout fittings, the provisions for stress relief specified in 5.7.4 and 5.7.7.3 are not required
unless any plate in the assembly has a thickness greater than 16 mm ( 5 / 8  in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>J.3.6.6  For flush-type shell connections, the provisions for stress relief specified in 5.7.4 and 5.7.8.3 are not
required unless any plate in the assembly has a thickness greater than 16 mm ( 5 / 8  in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.7 Corrosion Allowance<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>J.3.7.1  If the Purchaser requires that a corrosion allowance be provided, the allowance and the areas to which the
allowance is to be added shall be specified. If a corrosion allowance is specified without an indication of the area to
which it is to be added, the Manufacturer shall assume that it is to be added only to the calculated shell-plate
thickness.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.7.2  When a corrosion allowance is specified for the roof and bottom plates, it shall be added to the minimum
nominal thicknesses.<<HEADING_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Diameter   | Depth   |
|:-----------|:--------|
| ft         | in.     |
| 6          | 2       |
| 8          | 31/     |
|            | 2       |
| 10         | 51/     |
|            | 2       |
| 12         | 8       |
| 14         | 11      |
| 16         | 15      |
| 20         | 20      |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_356>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>J-4
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.8 Lifting Lugs<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.8.1  Lugs or clips for use in loading and unloading tanks and for use in placing tanks on foundations shall be
provided on all tanks constructed in accordance with this Annex.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>J.3.8.2  There shall be a minimum of two lugs on each tank. The location of the lugs shall be agreed upon by the
Purchaser and the Manufacturer. The lugs shall preferably be located at the top of the tank, in pairs, 180 degrees
apart.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>J.3.8.3  Lugs and their attachment welds shall be designed to carry their share of the applied load (twice the empty
weight of the tank) distributed in a reasonable manner and based on a safety factor of 4.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.8.4  Lugs capable of carrying the load described in J.3.8.3 shall be designed and attached in a manner that will
not damage the tank.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.3.9 Anchoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Because of the proportions of shop-assembled storage tanks, overturning as a result of wind loading must be
considered. If necessary, adequate provisions for anchoring shall be provided. See 5.12 for tank anchorage design
guidance.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.4 Fabrication and Construction<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.4.1 General<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>J.4.1.1  Fabrication and construction shall be in accordance with the applicable provisions of Sections 6 and 7 of this
standard. Erection shall be interpreted as assembly, and it shall be understood that the entire vessel is constructed in
the shop and not at the field site.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.4.1.2  Section 7.2.2 and Section 7.2.5 of this standard are not applicable to the bottoms and roofs of shop-
assembled tanks.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.4.2 Testing, Repairs, and Inspection<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.4.2.1 General<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>For testing of, repairs to, and inspection of shop-assembled tanks, the requirements of J.4.2.2 through J.4.2.4 replace
those of 7.3.2 through 7.3.7.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.4.2.2 Testing<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Unless otherwise specified by the Purchaser, as an alternative to the requirements of 7.3.2 through 7.3.8, a tank may
be shop tested for leaks by the following method:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) The tank bottom shall be braced by securely attaching an external stiffening member as required to prevent
permanent deformation during the test.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) All openings shall be closed with plugs or covers as needed. Bolts and gaskets of the size and type required for
final installation shall be used during the test.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) An internal air pressure of 14 kPa to 21 kPa (2 lbf/in. 2  to 3 lbf/in. 2 ) gauge shall be applied to the tank. For tanks
with a diameter of 3.7 m (12 ft) or less, a maximum pressure of 35 kPa (5 lbf/in. 2 ) gauge shall be used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_357>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
J-5<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d) Soap film, linseed oil, or another material suitable for the detection of leaks shall be applied to all shell, bottom,
roof, and attachment welds, and the tank shall be carefully examined for leaks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e) After the air pressure is released, the external stiffening member shall be removed, and any weld scars shall be
repaired.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.4.2.3 Repairs<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>All weld defects found by the leak test or by radiographic examination shall be repaired as specified in Section 8.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.4.2.4 Inspection<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The Purchaser’s inspector shall have free entry to the Manufacturer’s shop at all times. The Manufacturer shall afford
the Purchaser’s inspector reasonable facilities to assure the inspector that the work is being performed in accordance
with the requirements of this standard. All material and workmanship shall be subject to the replacement
requirements of 6.2.3.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.5 Examination of Shell Joints<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.5.1  The methods of examining shell joints described in Section 8 apply to shop-assembled tanks, but spot
radiography may be omitted when a joint efficiency of 0.70 is used (see A.3.4).<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>J.5.2  When radiographic examination is required (joint efficiency = 0.85), the spot radiographs of vertical joints shall
conform to 8.1.2.2, Item a only, excluding the 10 mm ( 3 / 8  in.) shell thickness limitation in Item a and excluding the
additional random spot radiograph required by Item a. The spot radiographs of horizontal joints shall conform to
8.1.2.3.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.6 Welding Procedure and Welder Qualifications<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The requirements for qualification of welding procedures and welders given in Section 9 apply to shop-assembled
tanks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>J.7 Marking<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Shop-assembled tanks shall be marked in accordance with Section 10, except that 10.1.4 and 10.2 are not
applicable. The nameplate (see Figure 10.1) shall indicate that the tank has been designed in accordance with this
Annex.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_358>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_359>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>Design specific gravity of liquid,  G :................................................................ 1.0<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Corrosion allowance:..................................................................................... 0.0 mm (0.0 in.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Tank diameter,  D : ......................................................................................... 85.0 m (280 ft)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Design Liquid Level (also total height of tank for the
examples in this Annex),  H : .................................................................. 19.2 m (64 ft)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Number of courses: ....................................................................................... 8.0<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Allowable stress for design,  S d : ..................................................................... —<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Allowable stress for testing,  S t : ......................................................................208 MPa (30,000 lbf/in. 2 )<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Height of bottom course,  h 1 :.......................................................................... 2,400 mm (96 in.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Nominal tank radius,   r : .................................................................................. 42,500 mm (1,680 in.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>(See 5.6.4 for definition of nomenclature.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
K-3<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>K.2.2 Bottom Course (Course 1)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>K.2.2.1 Design Condition<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t pd  =  2.6  ×  D   ×  ( H  – 1)  ×  G / S d  +  CA = 0.987 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t 1 d  = (1.06 – (0.463  ×  D / H )  ×  ( HG / S d ) 0.5 )  ×  (2.6 HDG / S d ) +  CA  = 0.962 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t 1 d  need not be greater than  t pd<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t 1 d   = minimum of above thicknesses = 0.962 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>K.2.2.2 Hydrostatic Test Condition<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t pt  = 2.6  ×  D   ×  ( H  – 1) /  S t  = 0.946 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t 1 d   t  = (1.06 – (0.463  ×  D / H )  ×  ( H / S t ) 0.5 )  ×  (2.6 HD / S t ) = 0.914 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t 1 t  need not be greater than  t pt<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t 1 t  = minimum of above thicknesses = 0.914 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t use  = nominal thickness used<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t min  = minimum nominal thickness required, the greater of  t d  or  t t<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t min  =  0.962 in. (controlled by  t 1 d )<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t use  = 1.000 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE    t use  >  t min  The greater thickness will be used for subsequent calculations and noted as the required thickness, therefore,
t 1 d   = 1.000 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>K.2.2.3 Check  L / H   ≤  2<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L  =  (6 Dt ) 0.5<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t  =  t use  –  CA  = 0.875 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L  = 38.34<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L/H  = 0.96  ≤  2<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>K.2.3 Shell Course 2<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>K.2.3.1 Design Condition<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h 1  =  96 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>r
= 1680 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t 1 d  = 1.000 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_362>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>K-4
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>CA  = 0.125 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t 1
= 0.875 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h 1 /( r   ×  t 1 ) 0.5  = 2.504 > 1.375 and < 2.625<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t 2
=  t 2 a  + ( t 1  –  t 2 a )(2.1 –  h 1 /(1.25  ×  ( rt 1 ) 0.5 )<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t 2 a  = 0.634 in. (see K.2.4)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t 2
= 0.657 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t 2 d  =  t 2  +  CA  = 0.782 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>K.2.3.2 Hydrostatic Test Condition<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h 1  =  96 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>r
= 1680 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t 1 t
= 1.000 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t 1
= 1.000 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h 1 /( r   ×  t 1 ) 0.5  =   2.342 >1.375 and < 2.625<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t 2
=  t 2 a  + ( t 1  –  t 2 a )(2.1 –  h 1 /(1.25  ×  ( rt 1 ) 0.5 )<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t 2 a   = 0.699 in. (See K.2.4)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t 2
= 0.767 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t 2 t  = 0.767 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t min  =  greater of  t 2 d  or  t 2 t  = 0.782 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t use  = 0.8125 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE     t use  >  t min , however, the extra thickness will not be used for subsequent calculations, therefore,  t 2 d  = 0.782 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>K.2.4 Second Course as Upper Shell Course<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>K.2.4.1 Design Condition<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>D
= 280 ft<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Material A573-70<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S d  = 28,000 psi<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S t

<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
K-5<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>CA  = 0.125 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>G
= 0.85<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H
= 32 ft<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>r
= 1680 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>C
= ( K 0.5 ( K  – 1))/(1+ K 1.5 )<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>K
=  t L / t u<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>x 1
= 0.61( rt u ) 0.5  + 3.84 CH<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>x 2
= 12 CH<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>x 3
= 1.22  ×  ( rt u ) 0.5<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t L
= 0.875 in. (thickness of bottom shell course less  CA )<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<HEADING level=2>>Annex L
(normative)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=2>>API Standard 650 Storage Tank Data Sheet<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>L.1 Introduction<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>L.1.1 Purpose<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>This Annex provides guidance to Purchasers (owners, engineering contractors, and other designated agents) and
Manufacturers (fabricators and erectors) for the preparation and completion of the  Atmospheric Storage Tank Data
Sheet  (hereafter referred to as the  Data Sheet ). The Data Sheet shall be prepared in conjunction with this standard
such that comprehensive proposals (bids) may be made and subsequent contracts may be placed for the fabrication
and erection of tanks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>L.1.2 Scope<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>This Annex explains information to be placed on the Data Sheet primarily by Purchasers for use by Manufacturers.
However, some of the instructions apply to either the Purchaser or the Manufacturer, depending on which party
assumes certain responsibilities.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>L.2 Use of This Annex<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>L.2.1 Data Sheet Purpose<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The Data Sheet (attached to this Annex) shall be part of a complete tank specification. The Data Sheet provides
space for defining specific technical information such as geometry, design loads, materials, and appurtenances, as
well as an outline sketch of the tank. The Data Sheet may be used as part of the Owner’s permanent record
describing the tank. Because some information on the Data Sheet may be determined by the Manufacturer, the Data
Sheet may also be used to facilitate gathering of the complete design requirements. The floating roof section of the
Data Sheet may be omitted if no floating roof is required for the tank.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>L.2.2 Purchaser’s Responsibility<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The preparer(s) of the Data Sheet shall have tank design experience and shall ensure that the requirements are both
accurate and complete. The Purchaser is primarily responsible for initiating and completing the Data Sheet.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>L.2.3 Manufacturer’s Responsibility<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The Manufacturer shall complete the Data Sheet as required to describe the proposal and shall provide the relevant
information required on all lines marked with an asterisk (*) that have not been provided by the Purchaser. The Data
Sheet shall be submitted at various times during the project as described in W.1.2(2).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>L.2.4 Text Legibility<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>All text placed on the Data Sheet shall be of size and quality to be readable and reproducible. Use additional sheets
or extend the form electronically for more space or necessary additions.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L-1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_376>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L-2
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>L.3 Specific Instructions<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>L.3.1 Line-by-Line Instructions<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Each place for data entry (numbered lines, boxes, table cells, etc.) on the Data Sheet shall be completed. In no case
should a line be left blank. Marking “NA” (not applicable), “Later,” “TBD” (to be determined), or other such terminology
can be used. The “Later” and “TBD” notations shall be edited to reflect subsequent decisions and as-built
configurations (see W.1.2).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Use consistent units for all dimensions and other data on the Data Sheet.  Show appropriate units for every
appropriate numerical entry.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The following numbered items correspond to the numbered lines and numbered tables on the Data Sheet:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Heading:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Data Sheet Status: Typical entries include: For Quotation, Bid, For Design Review, For Design Revision, and As-Built.
Revise to suit the status when submitted by the Purchaser or by the Manufacturer.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>General:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Special Documentation Package Requirements: List any exceptions to the default requirements listed in
Annex W.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Measurement Units to be used in API 650: Identify the set of units to be used when applying the rules in API
650.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1. Tank Manufacturer<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Manufacturer’s name.*<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Contract number*: Enter proposed or assigned number.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Address*: Enter physical address, not a post office box.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Manufacturer’s serial number for tank.*<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Year built.*<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Edition and Addendum of API 650 used for design and fabrication.*<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2. Purchaser<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Purchaser’s name.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Contract number or designation.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Address: Enter physical address, not a post office box.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Tank designation: For example, item number, equipment tag number, or other description.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3. Owner/Operator<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Owner/operator name.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Location of facility where tank will be operated.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_377>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
L-3<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4. Tank Dimensions<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Size Limitations*: Specify size limitations only when exact dimensions are to be determined by the
Manufacturer (e.g. maximum and minimum diameters, shell heights, overall heights, etc.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Tank Diameter*: Specify diameter and indicate ID, OD, or CL/BSC (centerline diameter of bottom shell
course).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Shell Height*: Specify the distance from the top surface of the bottom plate or annular ring to the upper edge
of the cylindrical shell including top angle, if any.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Maximum Capacity* and Net Working Capacity*:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Criteria*: Method used to determine capacity of tank: An example would be  API 2350.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5. Products Stored<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Liquid: Specify liquid(s) to be stored in the tank.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Design Specific Gravity: Enter the maximum specific gravity of the stored liquid(s) at designated
temperatures. Use greatest value of all products when tanks are to be designed for multiple products.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Minimum Design Specific Gravity for floating roof design: Enter specific gravity of the stored liquid(s) at
designated temperatures. Use lowest value of all products when tanks are to be designed for multiple
products.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Blanketing Gas: Specify blanketing gas in the space above the liquid.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Vapor Pressure: Specify absolute vapor pressure at the maximum operating temperature. Use the largest
value for tanks designed for multiple products.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
% Aromatic: Specify percentage by weight of aromatic hydrocarbons in tank. Refer to any supplemental
specification for protecting the materials of construction, as applicable.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Hydrogen Sulfide Service? (Yes/No): If “Yes,” a supplemental specification for material selection and
hardness shall be required. See 5.3.4.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Other Special Service Conditions: Include any conditions that may require further consideration. Consider
thermal expansion or shock, cyclic vibratory fatigue, and issues or regulations concerning the product
stored, e.g. chloride, caustic, amine, or ethanol corrosion, hydrogen blistering or embrittlement, oleum,
sulfuric acid, or ammonia service, RCRA (Resource Conservation and Recovery Act), HON (Hazardous
Organic National Emission Standard for Hazardous Air Pollutants), RMP (Clean Air Act Risk Management
Plan), etc. Provide supplemental specifications as needed. See 5.3.3.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Design and Testing:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Purchaser to Review Design Prior to Ordering Materials: Indicate if the Manufacturer is free to order materials prior to
Purchaser reviewing the design documents. Schedule may be affected. See W.1.3.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>6. Applicable Annexes*: See 1.1.6. Annex E may be selected on Line 8 of the Data Sheet. If no Annexes are chosen,
the basic design of this standard is intended.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>7. Design Parameters<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Maximum Design Temperature: See 3.20 for definition. This differs from the operating temperature. For
temperature limits, see 1.1.1, and Annex M and Annex S. If the roof design temperature is different than the<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_378>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L-4
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>shell temperature, as in the case of an uninsulated roof on an insulated shell, then use Line 23 to specify the
roof maximum design temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Design Metal Temperature*: Enter either lowest 1-day mean temperature plus 8 ºC (15 ºF) or a lower
temperature as specified by the Purchaser if operating conditions and/or local atmospheric conditions control
fracture toughness issues.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Design Liquid Level*: See 5.6.3.2, C.3.1.1, and E.2.2.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Design Internal Pressure: Specify internal pressure and units in the vapor space. See 5.2.1 c).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Design External Pressure: Specify external pressure and units in the vapor spade. See 5.2.1 b).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Internal Pressure Combination Factor ( F pe ): This factor is a modifier for the design internal pressure when
used in load combinations with other variable loads. Value equals normal operating internal pressure/design
internal pressure or a minimum of 0.4. Manufacturer to use 0.4 when not specified.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
External Pressure Combination Factor ( F pe ): This factor is a modifier for the design external pressure when
used in load combinations with other variable loads. Value equals normal operating external pressure/design
external pressure or a minimum of 0.4. Manufacturer to use 0.4 when not specified.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Maximum Fill Rate: Specify rate and units (e.g. 100 gallons per minute).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Maximum Emptying Rate: Specify rate and units (e.g. 75 gallons per minute).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Flotation Considerations (Yes/No): Include design consideration that advise the Manufacturer about tank
flotation anchorage, bottom uplift, and partial submersion pressures arising out of flood or dike
impoundment.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Flotation Supplemental Specifications*: Refer to any that may describe external liquid depth, external fluid
specific gravity, minimum internal liquid level, and any other information necessary for design.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Section 5.2.4 makes the design criteria here a matter of agreement between the Purchaser and the
Manufacturer.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Applied Supplemental Load Specification: Refer to supplemental specifications that provide concentrated
loads applied to the shell, such as openings or appurtenances from attached equipment, valves, or piping, or
reactions from stairs and platforms for determination of strength and stiffness issues by the Manufacturer. If
this information is not provided, the requirements of W.2(5) still apply.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>8. Seismic Design Data<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Seismic Design? (Yes/No): Indicate whether design for earthquakes is required. The Purchaser may specify
Annex E, or an alternate criterion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Annex E: Mark the box provided if this Annex shall be used for seismic design.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Alternate Seismic Criteria: Refer to any supplemental criteria different from this standard that shall be
followed. All required design factors shall be included in this supplemental specification.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Seismic Use Group: See E.3.1.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Site Class: See Table E.4-B.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_379>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
L-5<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Vertical Seismic Design: Indicate if this design is required.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Vertical Ground Motion Accelerator: Provide per E.6.1.3.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Basis of Lateral Acceleration: Select one of the three methods listed, and specify the appropriate
parameters. See E.4.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Freeboard: For SUG I designs, indicate if freeboard is required. See E.7.2.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Roof Tie Rods @ Outer Ring?* (Yes/No): See E.7.5<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>9. Design Wind Issues<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Top Wind Girder Style*: See 5.9, and Figure 5.24, for open-top and external floating roofs.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Dimensions of Top Wind Girder*: For example, if style were “Curb Angle,” the dimension might be
3  ×  3  ×   3 / 8  (in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Use Top Wind Girder as Walkway? (Yes/No): See 5.9, and Figure 5.25, and note 3 ft-6 in. dimension
preference of 5.9.4 if choice is “Yes.”<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Intermediate Wind Girders* (Yes/No): Specify “Yes” whenever wind girders shall be added to the shell to
satisfy shell stability stiffening predicated by wind loads. Specify “No” if shell stiffening is to be accomplished
by increasing the shell thickness. If not specified by the Purchaser, the Manufacturer must select between
the two alternatives and indicate the choice here.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Intermediate Wind Girder Style*: See 5.9 and Figure 5.24, for all kinds of tanks whenever wind girders are
specified.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Dimensions of Intermediate Wind Girders*: For example, if style were “formed plate,” dimension might be
b  = 30 in. per Figure 5.24.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Check Buckling in Corroded Condition? (Yes/No): If “Yes,” the wind load shall be applied to the corroded
shell (an option covered in 5.9.7.1) to establish the adequacy of the thicknesses and/or stiffening rings to
resist the applied forces.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>10. Shell Design<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
1-Foot Method?* (Yes/No): The Purchaser may select this shell thickness design method. The method is
subject to the applicable limitations noted in 5.6.3, A.4, J.3.3, and S.3.2. If not selected by the Purchaser, the
Manufacturer may select either this design method or one of the other two methods that this standard lists,
subject to the restrictions of this standard and the Purchaser’s approval.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Variable-Design-Point Method?* (Yes/No/Alternate): The Purchaser may select this shell thickness design
method. This method is subject to the restrictions detailed in 5.6.4. If the 1-Foot Method or Elastic Analysis
Method is selected by the Purchaser and the Variable-Design-Point Method is also selected as an
“Alternate” by the Purchaser, the Variable-Point Design Method may be used in addition to the Purchaser-
selected method, but the resulting proposal must be clearly marked as an “Alternate.” If the method is not
selected by the Purchaser, the Manufacturer may select either this design method or one of the other two
methods that this standard lists, subject to the restrictions of this standard and the Purchaser’s approval.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Elastic Analysis Method?* (Yes/No/Alternate): The Purchaser may select this shell thickness design method.
This method is subject to the restrictions detailed in 5.6.5. Cases when this method is mandatory are named
in 5.6.5 as well as requirements on the analysis boundary conditions. When it is not mandatory, the<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_380>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L-6
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Purchaser may select this shell design method. If the 1-Foot or Variable-Design-Point Method is selected by
the Purchaser and the Elastic Analysis Method is also selected as an “Alternate” by the Purchaser, the
Elastic Analysis Method may be used in addition to the Purchaser-selected method, but the resulting
proposal must be clearly marked as an “Alternate.” If the method is not selected by the Purchaser, the
Manufacturer may select either this design method or one of the other two methods that this standard lists,
subject to the restrictions of this standard and the Purchaser’s approval.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Plate-Stacking Criteria* Centerline-Stacked? (Yes/No) or Flush-Stacked on the Inside or Outside? (Yes/No)?<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Plate Widths (Shell Course Heights) and Thicknesses*: Specify nominal shell course heights and
thicknesses. The first course is attached to the bottom.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Joint Efficiency*: Specify in percentage. Applicable only to Annex A, Annex AL, Annex J, Annex S, and
Annex X designs. Mark “NA” for all other designs.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Shell-to-Bottom Weld Type*: See Figure 5.3A (inside and outside corner fillets), Figure 5.3C (inside and
outside partial penetration corner welds with fillet weld reinforcement), and J.3.2.4 (full penetration butt weld
to flanged flat bottom).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Shell-to-Bottom Weld Examination Method*: Choose among the options listed in accordance with 7.2.4.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Exceptions to Seal-welded Attachments (see Section 5.1.3.7): Specify where intermittent welding is
permitted.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>11. Open-Top and Fixed-Roof Data (see page 6 of the Data Sheet for Floating Roofs)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Open Top?* (Yes/No) Specify “Yes” if tank has no fixed roof or has an external floating roof. Specify “No” for
all other tanks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE
The remaining entries in this line apply to fixed roofs ONLY:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Fixed Roof Type*: Enter description, such as supported cone with internal structure, supported cone with
external structure, structurally-supported aluminum geodesic dome, self-supporting cone, self-supporting
dome, self-supporting umbrella, flanged only flat top, or other. See 5.10.1 or Annex G.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Roof Support Columns*: Specify pipe or structural shape. If structural shape is specified, indicate the kind
(e.g. wide flange, back-to-back channel, etc.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE
Pipe-type roof columns are preferred for internal floating roof tanks. In many cases the openings are  3 / 4  NPT
threaded couplings that allow the user to plug the openings when the tank is in service, to minimize corrosion of the supports
and reduce emission from the tank. The openings are needed to allow the free drainage and cleaning of the columns when the
tank is out of service.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Cone Slope*: Specify rise to run as a dimensionless ratio, e.g. “ 3 / 4 :12”.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Dome or Umbrella Radius*: See 5.10.6 for self-supporting approximate spherical radius of roof.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Weld Joints*: Describe the type of roof plate weld joint, which may be lap joint, butt joint, or some
combination thereof.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE DELETED<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Seal Weld Underside of Lap Joints? (Yes/No): May be required for roof plates with internal lining or to
prevent crevice corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_381>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
L-7<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Seal Weld Underside of Wind Girder Joints? (Yes/No): See 5.1.5.8.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Gas-tight? (Yes/No): See 7.3.8.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Joint Efficiency*: Use only for Annex F, Section F.6 roofs.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Thickness*: Provide nominal thickness of roof plates.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Sno w  Load*: Purchaser to provide the snow load for non-U.S. Sites. For non-US sites, the Manufacturer
should indicate the 50-year ground snow load selected. See 5.2.1e. For instructions on combining loads, see
5.10.2.1.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Applied Supplemental Loads Specification*: Indicate supplementary specifications for both dead and live
roof loads that are concentrated or have local distributions (e.g. the personnel loads of 5.8.6.2 and H.4.2.2).
Specify any reactions from platforms or walking surfaces as well as loads applied by equipment, valves, and
piping.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Column Lateral Load: Purchaser may optionally specify lateral loads imposed upon roof-supporting columns
in accordance with 5.10.2.9.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Venting Devices*? Enter type and quantity of devices for normal venting per API Standard 2000, and
pressure settings. Also, enter type(s) and quantity of emergency venting devices that meet either API
Standard 2000, circulation venting per Annex H, or a frangible roof design per 5.10.2. 6 ,  as applicable. Also
enter any special requirements for vents in areas where ice and snow may block vents. The frangibility of
tanks less than 50 ft in diameter may require additional design considerations beyond those required by this
standard.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
For Non-Frangible Roofs:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Seal Weld Roof Plates to Top Angle on the Inside? (Yes/No): When “Yes” is selected, the shell-to-roof-joint
shall be seal-welded on the inside. For certain designs, this may adversely affect frangibility.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Weld Rafters to Roof Plates? (Yes/No):<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Roof-to-Shell Detail*: See Figures 5.3A and F.3, J.3.5, and API 620, Figure 3-6.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Radial Projection of Horizontal Component to Top Angle*: Specify inward or outward projection.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>12. Required Bottom Data<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Thickness*: Enter nominal thickness, including corrosion allowance.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Style*: Enter one of the following: flat, cone up to center, cone down to center, side to side (tilted plane), cone
down to off-center. Enter all sump requirements (number, size, location, etc.) in Data Sheet (Table 3, Line 23,
or on the Tank Plan).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Slope*: Enter rise versus run. For the off-center style above, the slope specified is the maximum slope.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Weld Joint Type*: Enter one of the following: single-welded full-fillet lap joint, single-welded butt with backing
strip that remains in place, double-welded butt without backing strip, double-welded full-fillet lap joints, or
other, to be detailed on Data Sheet Line 23 if necessary.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Provide Drip Ring (Yes/No): If required, a drip ring shall be provided per 3.4.5. Unless the following Alternate
Specification is provided, the default drip ring shall be provided.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_382>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L-8
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Alternate Specification: Refer to an acceptable drip ring design specification if the Purchaser requires a drip
ring but declines the default design of 5.4.5.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Annular Ring* (Yes/No): The Purchaser may stipulate this type of detail even if not required by this standard.
A Purchaser’s choice of “No” does not relieve the Manufacturer from complying with the requirements of this
standard in this regard.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Annular Ring Minimum Radial Width* and Thickness*: Specify width and thickness.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>13. Foundation Information<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Furnished by*: Indicate Purchaser, Manufacturer, or others.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Type*: Indicate materials and form. See Annex B and Annex I (e.g. concrete ring-wall or steel wide flange
grillage on concrete pile cap).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Soil Allowable Bearing Pressure*: Estimate pressure from geotechnical report, experience with similar tanks
in the same area, etc.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Per Specification*: Refer to any specification that describes soil allowable bearing pressure.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Anchor Size*: See 5.3.1.1 and 5.12. Provide materials of construction, geometric forms, and corrosion
allowance for anchors in Table 2 of the Data Sheet.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Anchor Quantity*: Indicate the total number of anchors or anchor bolts to be provided.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Foundation Design Loads: See W.3(15). These loads are unfactored after the manner of the Allowable
Stress Design methodology. (Sign convention is as follows: positive acting downward, negative acting
upward.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Base Shear*: Indicate the values for the wind and seismic conditions in units of force.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>—
Overturning Moment*: Indicate in units of force-distance. See 5.11 for wind, and Annex E, or alternate
seismic criteria as specified on Line 8 of the Data Sheet ,  for seismic criteria.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Ring Forces*: Indicate loads delivered by the shell in units of force per circumference of shell.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 1
Note: The uniformly distributed loads are shell plus roof weight (both new and corroded), roof live load, internal
pressure, and partial vacuum.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 2
Note: The non-uniform loads are the peak magnitudes of the longitudinal compressive distributed force derived
from the wind and seismic-overturning moments without regard to any other compressive or tensile loads in the shell.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Bottom Forces*: Indicate support loads that are the uniformly applied forces to the bottom away from the
shell ring in units of force per unit area. These include weight of bottom plates, product and test liquid
weights, and pressure/vacuum loads. Mark all inapplicable entities as “NA.” For the hydrostatic test
exemption, product load shall be based on 1.1 times the specific gravity of the stored product or 1.0,
whichever is greater.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Other Foundation Loads*: Provide an attachment to describe these loads such as lateral soil pressure,
overburden, roof column reactions, pore pressure, uplift anchor forces, etc.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_383>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
L-9<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—

above grade, if any.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE
Lap joint nozzle flanges should be avoided in connections where the combined stresses (such as bending, cyclic, and
seismic) in the nozzle where attached to the lap joint stub-end exceed the API 650 basic allowable stress at the maximum design
temperature. Lap joint nozzle flanges should also be avoided in connections with vibration or when susceptible to environmental
stress corrosion cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Nozzle projections shall be measured from the outside of the shell to the face of the shell flange (FF) and from datum
line to the face of the flange for roof and floor openings, unless otherwise specified. Shell opening elevations shall be
from the datum line to the centerline of the opening, unless otherwise specified. Roof opening locations shall be
measured radially from the centerline of the tank. Specify datum line and elevations with orientations on the “Tank
Plans and Sketch” of the Data Sheet.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

calculations, place the “m” and “y” values for the gasket in the “Remarks” section of the Data Sheet,   Line 23. Clearly
indicate to which gaskets these values apply.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>25. Jackets and Other Heaters or Coolers<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Is a Jacket Required? (Yes/No)*: If Yes, a supplemental specification may be required to address some or all
of the following items.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Should the jacket be integral (utilize the shell as one boundary wall) or stand-alone (able to hold
pressure when detached from shell).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
How should the jacket be attached to the shell? Specify whether welded, bolted, or otherwise
attached.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
What type of jacket is required? Consider annular cylinder, pipe coil, half-pipe helix, panel coil, or other
types to be described.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Are Other Heaters or Coolers Required? (Yes/No)*: If Yes, a supplemental specification may be required to
address some or all of the following items.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Specify the type of heater or cooler. For example, internal coils, bayonet heat exchangers, or below
bottom piping.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Provide specifications for any other heaters or coolers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Specify design pressures for jacket or heaters or coolers, both internal pressure and partial vacuum.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Specify design temperatures for jackets and heaters/coolers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<HEADING level=3>>Floating Roof Data:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>30. Floating Roof Selection<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Design Basis: Check which API Annex is to be applied?<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Type of Roof*: Specify the option listed in Annex C or H. Only the Purchaser may specify “Other” and
describe another option.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>31. Seals<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Primary Seal: Select from types listed, or specify “Other” and supply necessary details or reference
specification. Foam seal material may absorb some products over time, becoming a potential safety issue.
See C.3.13 and H.4.4.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Shoe Mechanism: Indicate mechanism required for mechanical primary seal. Select the Manufacturer’s
standard, or specify a particular type (e.g. pantograph, leaf spring, safety-pin spring, coil spring scissors,
etc.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Electrically Isolate Mechanism from Shoes? (Yes/No): Indicate if required to insulate to prevent possible
arcing.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Wax Scrapers Required? (Yes/No): Such devices remove wax-like substances from the tank shell as the
roof descends to provide a cleaner sealing surface.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Nominal Shoe Thickness*: Include units. See C.3.13 and H.4.4.4.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Carbon Steel Shoes to be Galvanized? (Yes/No): This option cannot be selected for stainless steel shoes.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Secondary Seal: Indicate the need for a secondary seal.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Supplementary Specification: Refer to supplementary specification for secondary rim seal.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>32. Data for All Floating Roofs:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Overflow Openings in Shell Acceptable? (Yes/No): See C.3.1.1.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_390>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L-16
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Shell Extension? (Yes/No): Select a windskirt per C.3.1.1. If Yes is selected, this may affect capacity, design
liquid level, and the need for an overflow indicator (alarm), requiring a Purchaser-supplied supplemental
specification under Line 20. See API 2350.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Roof-Drain Check Valves Required? (Yes/No): See C.3.8.1.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Roof-Drain Isolation Valves Required? (Yes/No): See C.3.8.1.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Freeze Protection for Roof Drains Required? (Yes/No): See C.3.8.1. Freeze protection is not required in all
climates.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Roof-Drain Piping to External Nozzles: Select the type of piping from the blocks provided. If “Other” is
selected, provide description or reference supplemental specification. The number of roof drains required
and sump details shall be shown on the construction drawings.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Foam Dam? (Yes/No): See C.3.16.2.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Supplementary Specification: Provide supplementary foam dam specification reference.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Nominal Deck Thickness*: Specify a nominal deck thickness greater than that stated in C.3.3.2. If not
specified, the Manufacturer shall insert the thickness stated in the above reference.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Bulkhead Top Edges to be Liquid-Tight? (Yes/No): See H.4.1.8. This is mandatory for external floating roofs
but is a Purchaser’s option for internal floating roofs.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Seal-Weld Underside of Roof?: Select “Yes” to provide increased corrosion protection or additional stiffness.
This applies to seal welds in addition to the seal welding required in C.3.3.3 and H.4.3.5.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Electrical Bonding: Indicate if either shunts or cables will be used to bond the roof electrically to the shell,
and provide a supplemental specification to designate any technical requirements.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Quantity of Non-Guide Pole Gauge Wells Required: See C.3.14.1(2), for manual gauging apparatus in wells
not associated with a guide pole.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Quantity of Sample Hatches Required: See C.3.16.3 for sample hatches without gauging apparatus.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Guide Pole for Gauging? (Yes/No): Indicate whether the guide pole (anti-rotation device) shall be used for
gauging.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Slots in Guide Pole? (Yes/No): Indicate whether guide pole, if used for gauging, shall be slotted.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Datum Plates? (Yes/No): Indicate if required. See C.3.14.4.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Striking Plates? (Yes/No): Indicate if required. See C.3.14.5.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Guide Pole Emissions-Limiting Devices: Indicate any required by regulation or any additional devices
requested by the Purchaser for guide poles from the list provided. See C.3.14.1(1).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Quantity of Roof Manholes*: See C.3.5, C.3.11, and H.5.5.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— Minimum Roof Clearances Above Bottom: Indicate elevations above the bottom to the landed floating roof
for both the minimum operating level and the minimum maintenance level. These choices affect access and
capacity. See C.3.10.3, H.4.6.2, and API 2350.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_391>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
L-17<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Removable Leg Storage Racks? (Yes/No): Indicate if required.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Leg Sleeves or Fixed Low Legs: Mark the block that specifies whether the leg-supported floating roof shall
be provided with a sleeve through the roof plate or with fixed low legs.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>33. Additional Data for External Floating Roofs (See Annex C):<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Weather Shield? (Yes/No): Indicate the need for a weather shield on external floating roofs. If secondary rim
seals serve as weather shields, they shall not be additionally requested here.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Supplementary Specification: Provide references for weather shield specifications.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Rolling Ladder Required?* (Yes/No): Unless the Purchaser specifically declines here, a rolling ladder is to be
provided in accordance with C.3.7.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Must Each Leg be Field-Adjustable? (Yes/No): Indicate if required. If potential bottom settlement is an issue,
the Purchaser has the option to require a two-position removable leg that can accommodate local
adjustments that may differ for each leg. This option is for all floating roofs and is specifically discussed in
C.3.10.3.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Design Rainfall Intensity: Specify a rainfall rate, a minimum period of duration, and an association with a
statistically occurring storm such as that found in Technical Report No. 40 (e.g. 0.5 in. per hour for 5 minutes
for the 2-year storm).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Design Accumulated 24-hour Rainfall: Specify height of water accumulated in 24 hours associated with a
statistically occurring storm (e.g. 12 in. in 24 hours for the 100-year storm). See C.3.4 for minimum
requirements.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Out-of-Service Drains Required (Yes/No): Purchaser may choose to not have these drains installed. See
C.3.8.3.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Distortion and Stability Determinations Required? (Yes/No): List option per C.3.4.2.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Supplemental Specification: Document any established methodology chosen by agreement between the
Purchaser and the Manufacturer.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Landed Live Load*: See C.3.10.2. This space gives the Purchaser the option of specifying a larger live load
for external floating roofs and for specifying the stated live load for internal floating roofs even if drains are
provided that may normally negate the need for such live load design.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>34. Additional Data for Internal Floating Roofs<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Two-Position Legs Required? (Yes/No): See H.4.6.2. If the two positions shall be field-adaptable to account
for bottom settlement, indicate this in Line 23 of the Data Sheet.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Cable-Supported Floating Roof? (Yes/No): Indicate if required. This is an internal floating roof option as
found in H.4.6.5.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Fixed-Roof Inspection Hatches Required? (Yes/No): Indicate number required for evaluation of condition of
floating roof without having to enter the vapor space. See H.5.5.3.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Internal Roof Drain Required? (Yes/No): See H.4.1.10<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Omit Distribution Pads Supporting Uniform Live Loads? (Yes/No): See H.4.6.6<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Corrosion Gauge Required? (Yes/No): See H.5.8.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_392>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L-18
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Fixed Ladder Required? (Yes/No): This applies to vertical ladders attached to the shell, which will also
require a manhole in the fixed roof to be specified in Table 3.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Modified Minimum Point Load? (Yes/No): Point or concentrated loads are stated in H.4.2.2 for internal
floating roofs, but may be waived for tanks 9 m (30 ft) or smaller in diameter.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Mfr. to Leak Test Compartments: Indicate the percentage of compartments to be tested by the Manufacturer
and the location of the tests. If unknown prior to the Purchaser doing a field inspection, special contract
terms may be required to cover the additional costs.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Roof Erector’s Flotation Test: Indicate when this test is to be performed: See H.6.5, H.6.6 for restrictions on
these options.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Flotation Test Media: Indicate the media to be used and the water quality. See H.6.6. Provide a separate
specification, if required, to stipulate requirements.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Flotation Test Duration, Fill Height,: See H.6.6.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Flotation Test Items provided by Purchaser: List any items being supplied including those (gaskets,
fasteners, test blanks, etc.) after the test is completed. See H.6.6.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Responsible Party for Conducting Flotation Test and Inspecting Roof during Test: Purchaser can delegate
these. See H.6.6.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Table 5 Floating Roof Materials:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>According to C.3.1.2, the application of corrosion allowances (C.A.) shall be a matter of agreement between the
Purchaser and the Manufacturer. Document this agreement on the Data Sheet “Remarks” Line 23 (e.g. “Manufacturer
affirms that the nominal thicknesses chosen for floating roof components include the corrosion allowances shown in
the Table for Floating Roof Materials on page 7 of the Data Sheet”).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>L.3.2
Tank Plan and Sketches (Page 8 and Supplements)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>L.3.2.1
General<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Page 8 of the Data Sheet shall be used to show the shell and roof appurtenance orientations. A single sheet is
normally adequate for this purpose; however additional sheets may be necessary to show special details or
configurations. All sheets shall be identified and sequenced as part of the Data Sheet. Sketches may be made with
CAD or manual drafting. All sheets shall be identified by revision date or other means of record change.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE
Consider the prevailing wind direction when locating equipment requiring personnel access.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>L.3.2.2
Sketch Views<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The sketch view shall include an orthographic “Plan View” that may be used for the orientation of shell, roof, and
bottom openings. Other views may be added.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>L.3.2.3
Drafting Practices for Data Sheet Sketches<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Drafting practices shall be consistent with the following items.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Where practicable, sketches shall be to scale, but the scale need not be shown on the sketches.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Bottom views are not allowed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_393>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
L-19<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Plant north or geographic north arrow shall point upward on the sketch.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Plant north or geographic north shall be at the “0 degrees” orientation, as applicable.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Component thicknesses need not be shown on the sketch.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Internal details shall be identified and located. Provide only enough information to describe the item, or provide
reference to standard details. These items shall also be itemized in the appropriate tables in the Data Sheet.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
External appurtenances may be omitted from the sketch; however they must be itemized in the appropriate
tables in the Data Sheet.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>—
Foundation or anchorage details not clearly defined elsewhere shall be shown in the Data Sheet. This may
require that an “Elevation View” be provided.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>Annex W<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H.5.5.3<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>N.2.5<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_405>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Annex M
(normative)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Requirements for Tanks Operating at Elevated Temperatures<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>M.1
Scope<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>M.1.1
This Annex specifies additional requirements for API Standard 650 tanks with a maximum design
temperature exceeding 93 °C (200 °F) but not exceeding 260 °C (500 °F).<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>M.1.2
The following shall not be used for a maximum design temperature above 93 °C (200 °F):<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) Open-top tanks (see 5.9).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) Floating-roof tanks (see Annex C).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) Structurally-supported aluminum dome roofs (see G.1.1 and note below).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d) Internal floating roofs constructed of aluminum (see H.2.2 and note below).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e) Internal floating roofs constructed of composite material (see H.2.2). Lower temperature limits may apply for this
roof material type.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE
An exception may be made by the Purchaser for Items c and d, if the following criteria are met:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)  Allowable stress reductions for aluminum alloys are determined in accordance with   Annex AL, and alloys are evaluated for the
potential of exfoliation.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) Gaskets and seals are evaluated for suitability at the maximum design temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>M.1.3
Internal floating roofs in accordance with Annex H may be used for a maximum design temperature above
93 °C (200 °F), subject to the applicable requirements of this Annex. The vapor pressure of the liquid must be
considered. Sealing devices, particularly those of fabric and nonmetallic materials, shall be suitable for the maximum
design temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>M.1.4
Tanks for small internal pressures in accordance with Annex F may be used for a maximum design
temperature above 93 °C (200 °F), subject to the requirements of M.3.6.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>M.1.5
Shop-assembled tanks in accordance with Annex J may be used for a maximum design temperature above
93 °C (200 °F), subject to the applicable requirements of this Annex.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>M.1.6
The nameplate of the tank shall indicate that the tank is in accordance with this Annex by the addition of M to
the information required by 10.1.1. In addition, the nameplate shall be marked with the maximum design temperature
in the space indicated in Figure 10.1.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>M.2
Thermal Effects<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>This Annex does not provide detailed rules for limiting loadings and strains resulting from thermal effects, such as
differential thermal expansion and thermal cycling, that may exist in some tanks operating at elevated temperatures.
Where significant thermal effects will be present, it is the intent of this Annex that the Purchaser define such effects.
The Manufacturer shall propose, subject to the Purchaser’s acceptance, details that will provide strength and utility
equivalent to those provided by the details specified by this standard in the absence of such effects.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>M-1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_406>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>M-2
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>For a maximum design temperature above 93 °C (200 °F), particular consideration should be given to the following
thermal effects.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) Temperature differences between the tank bottom and the lower portion of the shell. Such thermal differences may
result from factors such as the method and sequence of filling and heating or cooling, the degree of internal
circulation, and heat losses to the foundation and from the shell to the atmosphere. With such temperature
differences, it may be necessary to provide for increased piping flexibility, an improved bottom-to-shell joint, and a
thicker annular ring or bottom sketch plates to compensate for increased rotation of the bottom-to-shell joint (see
M.4.2).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) The ability of the bottom to expand thermally, which may be limited by the method of filling and heating. With such
a condition, it may be necessary to provide improved bottom welding in addition to the details suggested in Item a.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) Temperature differences or gradients between members, such as the shell and the roof or stairways, the shell and
stiffeners, the roof or shell and the roof supports, and locations with insulation discontinuities.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d) Whether or not the contents are allowed to solidify and are later reheated to a liquid, including the effect on
columns, beams, and rafters. The possible build-up of solids on these components and the potential for plugging
of the vent system should also be considered.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e) The number and magnitude of temperature cycles the tank is expected to undergo during its design life.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>M.3
Modifications in Stress and Thickness<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>M.3.1
For a maximum design temperature not exceeding 93 °C (200 °F), the allowable stress specified in 5.6.2 (see
Table 5.2a and Table 5.2b) for calculating shell thickness need not be modified.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>M.3.2
For a maximum design temperature exceeding 93 °C (200 °F), the allowable stress specified in 5.6.2 shall be
modified as follows: The allowable stress shall be two-thirds the minimum specified yield strength of the material
multiplied by the applicable reduction factor given in Table M.1a and Table M.1b or the value given in Table 5.2a and
Table 5.2b for product design stress, whichever is less.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>M.3.3
For operating temperatures exceeding 93  ° C (200  ° F), the yield strength  F y  in 5.10.4.4 shall be multiplied by
the applicable reduction factor given in Table M.1a and Table M.1b.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>M.3.4
The allowable stress of 145 MPa (21,000 lbf/in 2 ) in the equation for shell-plate thickness in A.4.1 shall be
multiplied by the applicable reduction factor given in Table M.1a and Table M.1b.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>M.3.5
The requirements of 5.7.5 for shell manholes, 5.7.7 for flush-type cleanout fittings and of 5.7.8 for flush-type
shell connections shall be modified. The thickness of bottom reinforcing plate for flush-type shell cleanouts and flush-
type shell connections and bolting flange and cover plates for shell manhole and flush-type shell cleanouts shall be
multiplied by the ratio of 205 MPa (30,000 lbf/in. 2 ) to the material yield strength at the maximum design temperature if
the ratio is greater than one.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>M.3.6
The structural allowable stresses specified in 5.10.3 shall be calculated using Yield Strength ( F y ) and Modulus
of Elasticity ( E ) at the maximum design temperature. Refer to Table M.1a and Table M.1b for corrections to be applied
t o Yield Strength ( F y ) and Table M.2a and Table M.2b for values of Modulus of Elasticity ( E ) at maximum design
t emperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>1 4<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>M.3.7
In the roof-to-shell-joint area calculation per 5.10.5.2, the allowable stress  F a  shall be calculated using 0.6 x
Yield Strength ( F y ) (least) at maximum design temperature. Refer to Table M.1a and Table M.1b for corrections to be
applied to Yield Strength ( F y ) at maximum design temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_407>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
M-3<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>M.3.8
In E.6.2.4, the modification of the basic allowable membrane stress is stated in M.3.2. For the maximum
allowable hoop tension membrane stress determined by 0.9 F y  times the joint efficiency,  F y , shall be multiplied by th e
applicable reduction factor given in Table M.1a and Table M.1b.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>1 4<<HEADING_END>>
