<<HEADING level=3>>M.4
Tank Bottoms<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>M.4.1
Tanks with diameters exceeding 30 m (100 ft) shall have butt-welded annular bottom plates (see 5.1.5.6).<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>M.4.2
The following simplified procedure is offered as a recommended design practice for elevated-temperature
tanks where significant temperature differences between the tank bottom and the lowest shell course are expected.
The use of the procedure is not intended to be mandatory. It is recognized that other analytical procedures can be
employed as well as that operating conditions may preclude the need for such a procedure.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Shell-to-bottom junctions in elevated-temperature tanks may be evaluated for liquid head and temperature cycles with
the formulas, procedures, and exclusions given below. (See Conditions a and b in the note below, which exclude
tanks from such analyses.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE
A cyclic design life evaluation need not be made if all the criteria of either of the following conditions are met.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) The design temperature difference ( T ) is less than or equal to 220 °C (400 °F),  K  is less than or equal to 2.0, and
C  is less than or equal to 0.5.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) A heated liquid head, in feet, greater than or equal to 0.3( Dt ) 0.5  is normally maintained in the tank, except for an
occasional cool-down (about once a year) to ambient temperatures;  T  is less than or equal to 260 °C (500 °F); and
K  is less than or equal to 4.0. (For background information on the development of the stress formulas, design life
criteria, and C and B factors, see G.G. Karcher, “Stresses at the Shell-to-Bottom Junction of Elevated-Temperature
Tanks.”)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Temperature                                                         | Minimum Specified Yield Strength (MPa)   |                         |           |
| (°C)                                                                |                                          |                         |           |
|:--------------------------------------------------------------------|:-----------------------------------------|:------------------------|:----------|
|                                                                     | < 310 MPa                                | From ≥ 310 to < 380 MPa | ≥ 380 MPa |
| 94                                                                  | 0.91                                     | 0.88                    | 0.92      |
| 150                                                                 | 0.88                                     | 0.81                    | 0.87      |
| 200                                                                 | 0.85                                     | 0.75                    | 0.83      |
| 260                                                                 | 0.80                                     | 0.70                    | 0.79      |
| NOTE Linear interpolation shall be applied for intermediate values. |                                          |                         |           |
<<TABLE_END>>

| (°F)                                                                |                                               |                               |                   |
|:--------------------------------------------------------------------|:----------------------------------------------|:------------------------------|:------------------|
|                                                                     | < 45,000 lbf/in.2                             | ≥ 45,000 to < 55,000 lbf/in.2 | ≥ 55,000 lbf/in.2 |
| 201                                                                 | 0.91                                          | 0.88                          | 0.92              |
| 300                                                                 | 0.88                                          | 0.81                          | 0.87              |

| 500                                                                 | 0.80                                          | 0.70                          | 0.79              |

<<HEADING level=3>>M.5
Self-Supporting Roofs<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>M.5.1
For a maximum design temperature above 93 °C (200 °F), the calculated minimum thickness of roof plates, as
defined in 5.10.5.1.and 5.10.6.1, shall be increased by the ratio of 199,000 MPa (28,800,000 lbf/in. 2 ) to the material’s
modulus of elasticity at the maximum design temperature. (See Table M.2a and Table M.2b for modulus of elasticity.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>M.5.2
Table M.2a and Table M.2b shall be used to determine the material’s modulus of elasticity at the maximum
operating temperature.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>M.6
Wind Girders<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In the equation for the maximum height of unstiffened shell in 5.9.7.1, the maximum height ( H 1 ) shall be reduced by
the ratio of the material’s modulus of elasticity at the maximum design temperature to 199,000 MPa (28,800,000 lbf/
in. 2 ) when the ratio is less than 1.0 (see Table M.2a and Table M.2b for modulus of elasticity values).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_413>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Annex N
(normative)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Use of New Materials That Are Not Identified<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>N.1 General<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>New or unused plates and seamless or welded pipe that are not completely identified as complying with any listed
specification may be used in the construction of tanks covered by this standard, under the conditions specified in N.2.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>N.2 Conditions<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>N.2.1  A material may be used if an authentic test record for each heat or heat-treating lot of material is available that
proves that the material has chemical requirements and mechanical properties within the permissible range of a
specification listed in this standard. If the test requirements of the listed specification are more restrictive than any
specification or authentic tests that have been reported for the material, more restrictive tests shall be performed in
accordance with the requirements of the listed specification, and the results shall be submitted to the Purchaser for
approval.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>N.2.2  If an authentic test record is not available or if all the material cannot be positively identified with the test
record by legible stamping or marking, the following requirements apply.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) Each plate shall be subjected to the chemical analysis and physical tests required by the designated specification,
with the following modifications: The carbon and manganese contents shall be determined in all check analyses.
When the designated specification does not specify carbon and manganese limits, the Purchaser shall decide
whether these contents are acceptable. When the direction of rolling is not definitely known, two tension
specimens shall be taken at right angles to each other from a corner of each plate, and one tension specimen
shall meet the specification requirements.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) Each length of pipe shall be subjected to a chemical check analysis and sufficient physical tests to satisfy the
Purchaser that all of the material is properly identified with a given heat or heat-treatment lot and that the chemical
and physical requirements of the designated specification are met. Material specified as suitable for welding, cold
bending, close coiling, and the like shall be given sufficient check tests to satisfy the Purchaser that each length of
material is suitable for the fabrication procedure to be used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>N.2.3  Charpy V-notch impact tests must be performed when required by Figure 4.1 to verify that the material
possesses the toughness required by Table 4.4a and Table 4.4b.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>N.2.4  After a material is properly identified with a designated specification and the Purchaser is satisfied that the
material complies with the specification in all respects, the testing agency shall stencil or otherwise mark, as permitted
by the specification, a serial  S  number on each plate or each length of pipe (or as alternatively provided for small
sizes in the specification) in the presence of the Purchaser.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>N.2.5  Suitable report forms clearly marked “Report on Tests of Nonidentified Materials” shall be furnished by the
tank Manufacturer or testing agency. The forms shall be properly filled out, certified by the testing agency, and
approved by the Purchaser.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>N.2.6  The Purchaser shall have the right to accept or reject the testing agency or the test results.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>N.2.7  The requirements for fabrication applicable to the designated specification to which the nonidentified material
corresponds shall be followed, and the allowable design stress values shall be those specified in this standard for the
corresponding specification.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>N-1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_414>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_415>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Annex O
(normative)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Under-Bottom Connections<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>This annex provides a number of design options requiring decisions by the Purchaser; standard requirements;
recommendations; and information that supplements the basic standard.  This annex becomes a requirement only
when the Purchaser specifies an option covered by this annex or specifies the entire annex.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>O.1 Scope<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>This Annex contains recommendations to be used for the design and construction of under-bottom connections for
storage tanks. The recommendations are offered to outline good practice and to point out certain precautions that are
to be observed. Reference should be made to Annex B for considerations involving foundation and subgrade.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>O.2 Recommendations<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>O.2.1  The recommendations of this Annex are intended for use only where significant foundation settlement is not
expected. It is not possible to establish precise limits, but if predicted settlement exceeds 13 mm ( 1 / 2  in.), the
recommendations should be subjected to detailed engineering review for possible additions, modifications, or
elimination of bottom connections. Particular consideration shall be given to possible differential settlement in the
immediate area of the bottom connection and with respect to connecting piping.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>O.2.2  The arrangement and details of bottom connections may be varied to achieve the utility, tightness, and
strength required for the prevailing foundation conditions. The details shown in Figure O.1, Figure O.2, and Figure
O.3 are examples. Figure O.1 and Figure O.2 show details used on a concrete ringwall foundation, but similar
designs may be used on earth foundations. Figure O.3 shows another detail used on earth foundations. Other
arrangements of foundation and connection (including combination sump and pipe) may be used under the
provisions of O.2.6. When required by the Purchaser, seismic considerations (see Annex E) shall be included.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>O.2.3  Support of the pipe by the soil and bottom connection shall be evaluated to confirm adequacy and resistance
to liquid, static, and dynamic loads. Both deflection and stress shall be considered in the evaluation.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>O.2.4  Consideration shall be given to predicted settlement that would affect the relative positions of the tank and
pipe or pipe supports outside the tank (see O.2.1).<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>O.2.5  Bottom connections used in floating-roof tanks shall be provided with a baffle to prevent impingement of the
inlet product stream directly against the floating roof.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>O.2.6  All details are subject to agreement between the Purchaser and the Manufacturer.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>O.3 Guideline Examples<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>O.3.1 Concrete Vault and Ringwall (See Figure O.1 and Figure O.2)<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>O.3.1.1  The concrete ceiling vault shown in Figure O.2 provides improved support of the tank bottom and shell and
provides more uniform reinforcing-bar distribution around the ringwall opening than the details shown in Figure O.1
provide.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>O.3.1.2  Particular attention is required for the backfill specifications and placement of the backfill around the vault
area and around the inside of the entire ringwall. Compaction shall be adequate to prevent significant localized
settlement.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>O.3.1.3  Consideration should be given to the soil characteristics at the different elevations at the bottom of the
ringwall and the vault, especially for the deeper vaults to accommodate the larger connections.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>O-1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_416>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>O-2
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>O.3.1.4  Recommended details and dimensions are shown in Figure O.1 and Figure O.2, and Table O.1a and Table
O.1b. Dimension  K  is considered adequate to place the connection out of the influence of shell-to-bottom rotation
when the tank is statically loaded. Seismic loading shall be analyzed for additional considerations. The method shall
be a matter of agreement between the Manufacturer and the Purchaser. When the tank bottom has annular plates
(thicker than the tank bottom), it is recommended either to provide at least 300 mm (12 in.) between the edge of the
pipe connection or reinforcing plate and the inner edge of the annular plate or to locally extend the annular plate,
thickened if necessary, to encompass the bottom connection. The dimensions in Tables O.1a and O.1b may be
changed to achieve desired clearances for installations, inspections, and the like.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_420>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_421>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Annex P
(normative)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Allowable External Loads on Tank Shell Openings<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>This annex provides a number of design options requiring decisions by the Purchaser; standard requirements;
recommendations; and information that supplements the basic standard.  This annex becomes a requirement only
when the Purchaser specifies an option covered by this annex or specifies the entire annex.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.1 Introduction<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>This Annex shall be used (unless specified otherwise by the Purchaser on Line 29 of the Data Sheet) for tanks larger
than 36 m (120 ft) in diameter, and only when specified by the Purchaser for tanks 36 m (120 ft) in diameter and
smaller. See W.2(5) for additional requirements.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>This Annex presents two different procedures to determine external loads on tank shells. Section P.2 establishes limit
loads and P.3 is based on allowable stresses. This Annex is based on H. D. Billimoria and J. Hagstrom’s “Stiffness
Coefficients and Allowable Loads for Nozzles in Flat Bottom Storage Tanks” and H. D. Billimoria and K. K. Tam’s
“Experimental Investigation of Stiffness Coefficients and Allowable Loads for a Nozzle in a Flat Bottom Storage Tank.”<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.2 Limit Loads<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.2.1 Scope<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>This Annex establishes requirements for the design of storage-tank openings that conform to Table 5.6a and
Table 5.6b and will be subjected to external piping loads. The requirements of this Annex represent accepted
practice for the design of shell openings in the lower half of the bottom shell course that have a minimum
elevation from the tank bottom and meet the requirements of Table 5.6a and Table 5.6b. It is recognized that the
Purchaser may specify other procedures, special factors, and additional requirements. Any deviation from these
requirements shall be mutually agreed upon by the Purchaser and the Manufacturer.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.2.2 General<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The design of an external piping system that will be connected to a thin-walled, large-diameter cylindrical vertical
storage tank may pose a problem in the analysis of the interface between the piping system and the tank opening
connections. The piping designer must consider the stiffness of the tank shell and the radial deflection and meridional
rotation of the shell opening at the opening-shell connection resulting from product head, pressure, and uniform or
differential temperature between the shell and the bottom. The work of the piping designer and the tank designer
must be coordinated to ensure that the piping loads imposed on the shell opening by the connected piping are within
safe limits. Although three primary forces and three primary moments may be applied to the mid-surface of the shell
at an opening connection, only one force,  F R , and two moments,  M L  and  M C , are normally considered significant
causes of shell deformation (see P.2.3 for a description of the nomenclature).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.2.3 Nomenclature<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a
is the outside radius of the opening connection, in mm (in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>E
is the modulus of elasticity, in MPa (lbf/in. 2 ) (see Table P.1a and Table P.1b);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>F R  is the radial thrust applied at the mid-surface of the tank shell at the opening connection, in N (lbf);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>F P  is the pressure end load on the opening for the pressure resulting from the design product head at the
elevation of the opening centerline,  π a 2 P , in N (lbf);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P-1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_422>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P-2
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>G
is the design specific gravity of the liquid;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H
is themaximum allowable tank filling height, in mm (in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>K C  is the stiffness coefficient for the circumferential moment, in N-mm/radian (in.-lbf/radian);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>K L  is the stiffness coefficient for the longitudinal moment, in N-mm/radian (in.-lbf/radian);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>K R  is the stiffness coefficient for the radial thrust load, in N/mm (lbf/in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L
is the vertical distance from the opening centerline to the tank bottom, in mm (in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>M C  is the circumferential moment applied to the mid-surface of the tank shell, in N-mm (in.-lbf);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>M L  is the longitudinal moment applied to the mid-surface of the tank shell, in N-mm (in.-lbf);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P
is the pressure resulting from product head at the elevation of the opening centerline, in MPa (lbf/in. 2 );<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>R
is the nominal tank radius, in mm (in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t
is the shell thickness at the opening connection, in mm (in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Δ T  is the normal design temperature minus installation temperature, in °C (°F);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W
is the unrestrained radial growth of the shell, in mm (in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W R  is the resultant radial deflection at the opening connection, in mm (in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X A  is the  L  +  a , in mm (in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X B  is the  L  –  a , in mm (in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X C  is the  L , in mm (in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Y C  is the coefficient determined from Figure P.4b;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Y F ,  Y L are the coefficients determined from Figure P.4a;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>is the thermal expansion coefficient of the shell material, in mm/[mm-°C] (in./[in.-°F]) (see Table P.1a and
Table P.1b);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>is the characteristic parameter, 1.285/( Rt ) 0.5  (1/mm) (1/in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>equals  a /( Rt ) 0.5 ;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>is the unrestrained shell rotation resulting from product head, in radians;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>θ C  is the shell rotation in the horizontal plane at the opening connection resulting from the circumferential
moment, in radians;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>θ L
is the shell rotation in the vertical plane at the opening connection resulting from the longitudinal moment, in
radians.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<HEADING level=3>>P.2.4 Stiffness Coefficients for Opening Connections<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The stiffness coefficients  K R ,  K L , and  K C  corresponding to the piping loads  F R ,  M L , and  M C  at an opening connection,
as shown in Figure P.1, shall be obtained by the use of Figures P.2A through P.2L. Figures P.2A through P.2L shall be
used to interpolate intermediate values of coefficients.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<HEADING level=3>>P.2.6 Determination of Loads on the Opening Connection<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The relationship between the elastic deformation of the opening connection and the external piping loads is
expressed as follows:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>K R ,  K L , and  K C  are the shell stiffness coefficients determined from Figures P.2a through P.2l.  W R ,  θ L , and  θ C  are the
resultant radial deflection and rotation of the shell at the opening connection resulting from the piping loads  F R ,  M L ,
and  M C  and the product head, pressure, and uniform or differential temperature between the shell and the tank
bottom.  F R ,  M L , and  M C  shall be obtained from analyses of piping flexibility based on consideration of the shell
stiffness determined from Figures P.2a through P.2l, the shell deflection and rotation determined as described in
P.2.5.1 and P.2.5.2, and the rigidity and restraint of the connected piping system.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.2.7 Determination of Allowable Loads for the Shell Opening<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.2.7.1 Construction of Nomograms<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.2.7.1.1  Determine the nondimensional quantities  X A /( Rt ) 0.5 ,  X B /( Rt ) 0.5 , and  X C /( Rt ) 0.5  for the opening configuration
under consideration.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P.2.7.1.2  Lay out two sets of orthogonal axes on graph paper, and label the abscissas and ordinates as shown in
Figure P.3a and Figure P.3b, where  Y C ,  Y F , and  Y L  are coefficients determined from Figure P.4a and Figure P.4b.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P.2.7.1.3  Construct four boundaries for Figure P.3a and two boundaries for Figure P.3b. Boundaries  b 1  and  b 2  shall
be constructed as lines at 45-degree angles between the abscissa and the ordinate. Boundaries  c 1 ,  c 2 , and  c 3  shall be
constructed as lines at 45-degree angles passing through the calculated value indicated in Figure P.3a and Figure
P.3b plotted on the positive x axis.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.2.7.2 Determination of Allowable Loads<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P.2.7.2.1  Use the values for  F R ,  M L , and  M C  obtained from the piping analyses to determine the quantities ( λ / 2 Y F )
( F R / F P ), ( λ / aY L )( M L / F P ), and ( λ / aY C )( M C / F P ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.2.7.2.2  Plot the point ( λ / 2 Y F ) ( F R / F P ), ( λ / aY L )( M L / F P ) on the nomogram constructed as shown in Figure P.5a.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.2.7.2.3  Plot the point ( λ / 2 Y F ) ( F R / F P ), ( λ / aY L )( M C / F P ) on the nomogram constructed as shown in Figure P.5b.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P.2.7.2.4  The external piping loads  F R ,  M L , and  M C  to be imposed on the shell opening are acceptable if both points
determined from P.2.7.2.2 and P.2.7.2.3 lie within the boundaries of the nomograms constructed for the particular
opening-tank configuration.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.2.8 Manufacturer and Purchaser Responsibility<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P.2.8.1  The Manufacturer is responsible for furnishing to the Purchaser the shell stiffness coefficients (see P.2.4)
and the unrestrained shell deflection and rotation (see P.2.5). The Purchaser is responsible for furnishing to the
Manufacturer the magnitude of the shell-opening loads (see P.2.6). The Manufacturer shall determine, in accordance
with P.2.7, the acceptability of the shell-opening loads furnished by the Purchaser. If the loads are excessive, the
piping configuration shall be modified so that the shell-opening loads fall within the boundaries of the nomograms
constructed as in P.2.7.1.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>

|    |     |    |      |    |      |    |     |     | 0.005  |         |
|    |     |    |      |    |      |    | a / | R = | 0.005  |         |
|    |     |    |      |    |      |    |     |     | 02     |         |
|    |     |    |      |    | a /R |    | =   | 0.  | 02     |         |
|    |     |    | a /R |    | =    |    | 0.0 | 4   |        |         |
|    | R / | t  |      |    |      |    |     |     |        |         |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_4>>
| 0    | 1     |
|:-----|:------|
| L/2a | = 1.5 |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_5>>
| 0   | 1   |
|:----|:----|
| R / | t   |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>

<<HEADING level=3>>Figure P.4a—Obtaining Coefficients  Y F  and  Y L<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P.2.8.2  Changing the elevation of the opening and changing the thickness of the shell are alternative means of
reducing stresses, but because these measures can affect fabrication, they may be considered only if mutually
agreed upon by the Purchaser and the Manufacturer.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.2.9 Sample Problem<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.2.9.1 Problem<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A tank is 80 m (260 ft) in diameter and 19.2 m (64 ft) high, and its bottom shell course is 34 mm (1.33 in.) thick. The
tank has a low-type nozzle with an outside diameter of 610 mm (24 in.) in accordance with API Standard 650, and the
nozzle centerline is 630 mm (24.75 in.) up from the bottom plate, with reinforcement on the shell (see Figure P.6).
What are the end conditions ( W ,  θ ,  K R ,  K L , and  K C ) for an analysis of piping flexibility? What are the limit loads for the
nozzle?<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a
=
305 mm (12 in.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L
=
630 mm (24.75 in.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H
=
19,200 mm (64  ×  12 = 768 in.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>D T  =
90 ° – 20 ° = 70 °C (200 ° – 70 ° = 130 °F)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>R
=
80,000/2 = 40,000 mm ((260  ×  12)/2 = 1560 in.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>P-24
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.2.9.3 Summary<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The limiting piping loads are as follows:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In SI units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>F R max
= 310,000 N (tension at A controls)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>M C max  = 4.96  ×  10 8  N-mm (tension at C ′  controls)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>M L max  = 1.8  ×  10 8  N-mm (tension at A controls)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In USC units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>F R max
=
70,900 lbf (tension at A controls)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>M C max  =
4.50  ×  10 6  in.-lbf (tension at C ′  controls)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>M L max  =
1.61  ×  10 6  in.-lbf (tension at A controls)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE   This section is based on the paper “Analysis of Nozzle Loads in API 650 Tanks”  32<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.3 Alternative Procedure for the Evaluation of External Loads on Tank Shell Openings<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.3.1 Scope<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P.3.1.1  This section provides guidelines for the use of alternative methods in determining local stresses in nozzles
and cylindrical shells from external loads. Localized stresses at nozzle locations in shells shall be evaluated using one
of the methods listed below. For each method, the acceptance criteria shall be in accordance with P.3.3.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) Stress calculations shall be in accordance with WRC 297 or ASME Section VIII Division 2, or<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) Stress calculations shall be performed using a numerical analysis such as the finite element analysis (FEA).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P.3.1.2  The guidelines of this section regarding FEA, only apply to analysis utilizing shell elements. The use of solid
continuum elements requires different analysis procedures including stress linearization of the results and is beyond
the scope of this section.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P.3.1.3  The guidelines of this section do not address all details of good FEA modeling practice. In addition to the
subjects addressed, selection of element type, element size, aspect ratio, and application of boundary conditions and
loadings, for example, can have a significant effect on the results. Skill and experience on the part of the engineer are
necessary.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.3.2 Parameters<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>For comparative analysis, modeling shall utilize the following parameters.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P.3.2.1  Any reinforcing plate shape that meets the requirements of this Standard is acceptable. Using a thickened
insert plate is considered equivalent to using two separate plates, shell plus reinforcing plate.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>32  Analysis of Loads for Nozzles in API 650 Tanks, M. Lengsfeld, K.L. Bardia, J. Taagepera, K. Hathaitham, D.G. LaBounty, M.C.
Lengsfeld. Paper PVP-Vol 430, ASME, New York, 2001.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_445>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
P-25<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.3.2.2  Welds do not need to be modeled.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P.3.2.3  Loads are applied at end of the nozzle. Evaluate the perimeter surface and membrane stresses at a
distance that is 1.50 times the thickness being considered away from the junction. In addition, local primary
membrane stress shall be evaluated at a distance 1.0( RT ) 0.5  from the discontinuity.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P.3.2.4  Load cases shall include product and hydrostatic conditions at design liquid level. Loads on nozzles result-
ing from thermal movement of the tank shall be considered. Internal pressure shall be added as additional product
head.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.3.2.5  Use Figure P.1 sign convention (“right-hand rule”). Loads are mechanical and all loads shall be taken
simultaneously. Minimum load combinations are:<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) + F R + M C + M L<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) – F R + M C + M L<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P.3.2.6  FEA will frequently show the neck is overstressed due to product loading alone, however, the stress is self-
limiting and neck strains can be shown to be low. Neck stresses need not be analyzed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.3.2.7  Bottom of shell plate shall be considered radially fixed and shall be free to rotate.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.3.2.8  Thermal stress in the shell need not be included in this analysis.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.3.2.9  Tank size is a non-essential variable. Therefore the entire tank does not need to be modeled.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.3.3 Allowable Stress Limits<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.3.3.1  For membrane stress, limit stress to 1.5( S d ). Local primary membrane stress, including primary bending,
shall be limited to 1.1( S d ).<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>P.3.3.2  For surface stress, limit stress to the greater of 2( F y ) and 3( S d ), but shall not exceed the tensile (ultimate)
strength.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_446>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_447>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Annex R
(informative)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=2>>References for Tanks in Non-petroleum Product Service<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>R.1
In addition to the tanks covered in the Scope of API 650, this standard is frequently specified for tanks storing a
variety non-petroleum liquids. The industry documents listed in this annex provide additional guidance for both
specific design and material selection considerations to reduce or prevent accelerated corrosion mechanisms from
damaging the tank.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>R.2
The list of references included in this annex is not exhaustive and the user needs to do their own research to
confirm recommendations.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>R.3
For commodities not listed in the Scope of API 650, or for additional information, chemical manufacturers often
provide guidance documents for storing and handling of their specific products.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>NACE International   33<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Corrosion Prevention by Protective Coatings , Second Edition, Item #37507<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>Design, Fabrication and Inspection of Storage Tank Systems for Concentrated Fresh and Process Sulfuric Acid and
Oleum at Ambient Temperatures , Item #SP0294-2006<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

No. MS-2<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_449>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Annex S
(normative)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Austenitic Stainless Steel Storage Tanks<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.1 Scope<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.1.1  This Annex covers materials, design, fabrication, erection, and testing requirements for vertical, cylindrical,
aboveground, closed- and open-top, welded, austenitic stainless steel storage tanks constructed of material grades
201-1, 201LN, 304, 304L, 316, 316L, 317, and 317L. This Annex does not cover stainless steel clad plate or strip-
lined construction.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.1.2  This Annex applies only to tanks in nonrefrigerated services with a maximum design temperature not
exceeding 260 °C (500 °F). Tanks designed to this Annex shall be assigned a maximum design temperature no less
than 40 °C (100 °F). It is cautioned that exothermic reactions occurring inside unheated storage tanks can produce
temperatures exceeding 40 °C (100 °F).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.1.3  The minimum thicknesses specified in this Annex are corroded thicknesses unless otherwise stated.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.1.4  This Annex states only the requirements that differ from the basic rules in this standard. For requirements not
stated, the basic rules must be followed.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.2 Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.2.1 Selection and Ordering<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.2.1.1  Materials shall be in accordance with Table S.1a and Table S.1b.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.2.1.2  Selection of the type/grade of stainless steel depends on the service and environment to which it will be
exposed and the effects of fabrication processes (see S.4.3.2 and S.4.4.3). The Purchaser shall specify the type/
grade.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.2.1.3  External structural attachments may be carbon steels meeting the requirements of Section 4 of this
standard, providing they are protected from corrosion and the design and details consider the dissimilar properties of
the materials used. (This does not include shell, roof, or bottom openings and their reinforcement.) Carbon steel
attachments (e.g. clips for scaffolding) shall not be welded directly to any internal surface of the tank. For stainless
steel tanks subject to external fire impingement, the use of galvanizing on attachments, including ladders and
platforms, is not recommended.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.2.2 Packaging<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Packaging stainless steel for shipment is important to its corrosion resistance. Precautions to protect the surface of
the material depend   on the surface finish supplied and may vary among Manufacturers. Normal packaging methods
may not be sufficient to protect the material from normal shipping damage. If the intended service requires special
precautions, special instructions shall be specified by the Purchaser.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.2.3 Impact Testing<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Impact tests are not required for austenitic stainless steel base metals.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S-1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_450>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S-2

<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 1  Unless otherwise specified by the Purchaser, plate, sheet, or strip shall be furnished with a No. 1 finish and shall be hot-rolled,
annealed, and descaled.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 2  Carbon steel flanges and/or stub ends may be used by agreement between the Purchaser and the Manufacturer, providing the
design and details consider the dissimilar properties of the materials used and are suitable for the intended service.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 3  Castings shall not be used unless specified by the Purchaser. If specified, castings shall meet ASTM A351 and shall be inspected in
accordance with ASME  Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code , Section VIII, Division 1, Annex 7.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 4  All bars in contact with the product shall be furnished in the hot-rolled, annealed, and descaled condition.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 5  Other bolting materials may be used by agreement between the Purchaser and the Manufacturer.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

| NOTE 3 Castings shall not be used unless specified by the Purchaser. If specified, castings shall meet ASTM A351 and shall be inspected in |                      |                         |                                         |
| accordance with ASME Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code, Section VIII, Division 1, Annex 7.                                                   |                      |                         |                                         |
| NOTE 4 All bars in contact with the product shall be furnished in the hot-rolled, annealed, and descaled condition.                        |                      |                         |                                         |
| NOTE 5 Other bolting materials may be used by agreement between the Purchaser and the Manufacturer.                                        |                      |                         |                                         |

the following values:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

of Shell Plate<<HEADING_END>>

<<HEADING level=3>>S.3.1.2 Bottom Plates<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>All bottom plates shall have a corroded thickness of not less than 5 mm ( 3 / 16  in.). Bottom plates which weld to shell
plates thicker than 25 mm (1.0 in.) shall have a corroded thickness of not less than 6 mm ( 1 / 4  in.). Unless otherwise
agreed to by the Purchaser, all rectangular and sketch plates (bottom plates on which the shell rests that have one
end rectangular) shall have a minimum nominal width of not less than 1200 mm (48 in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.3.1.3 Annular Bottom Plates<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Butt-welded annular bottom plates meeting the requirements of 5.5.2 through 5.5.5 are required when either the
bottom shell course maximum product stress is greater than 160 MPa (23,200 lbf/in. 2 ) or the bottom shell course
maximum test stress is greater than 172 MPa (24,900 lbf/in. 2 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.3.2 Shell Design<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.3.2.1 General<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.3.2.1.1  The required nominal shell thickness shall not be less than the greatest of the design shell thickness plus
corrosion allowance, hydrostatic test shell thickness, or the nominal thickness listed in 5.6.1.1 (note 4 does not apply).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.3.2.1.2  Unless otherwise agreed to by the Purchaser, the shell plates shall have a minimum width of 1200 mm
(48 in.).<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.3.2.2 Shell Thickness Calculation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The requirements of 5.6 shall be followed, except as modified in S.3.2.2.1, S.3.2.2.2, and S.3.2.2.3.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.3.2.2.1  Allowable stresses for all shell thickness calculation methods are provided in Table S.2a and Table S.2b.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.3.2.2.2  Annex A is not applicable.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.3.2.2.3  The following formulas for design shell thickness and test shell thickness may alternatively be used for
tanks 60 m (200 ft) in diameter and smaller.<<HEADING_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>S-6
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE   The allowable stresses recognize the increased toughness of stainless steels over carbon steels and the relatively low
yield/tensile ratios of the stainless steels. The increased toughness permits designing to a higher proportion of the yield strength,
however, the Manufacturer and Purchaser shall be aware that this may result in permanent strain (see Table S.2a and Table S.2b).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.3.3 Shell Openings<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.3.3.1  The minimum nominal thickness of connections and openings shall be as follows:<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Size of Nozzle
Minimum Nominal
Neck Thickness<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NPS 2 and less
Schedule 80S<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NPS 3 and NPS 4
Schedule 40S<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Over NPS 4
6 mm (0.25 in.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE   Reinforcement requirements of 5.7 must be maintained.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.3.3.2  Thermal stress relief requirements of 5.7.4 are not applicable.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.3.3.3  Shell manholes shall be in conformance with 5.7.5 except that the corroded thickness requirements of
bolting flange and cover plate shall be multiplied by the greater of (a) the ratio of the material yield strength at 40 °C
(100 °F) to the material yield strength at the maximum design temperature, or (b) the ratio of 205 MPa (30,000 psi) to
the material yield strength at the maximum design temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.3.3.4  As an alternative to S.3.3.3, plate ring flanges may be designed in accordance with API Standard 620 rules
using the allowable stresses given in Table S.3a and Table S.3b.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.3.3.5  Allowable weld stresses for shell openings shall conform to 5.7.2.8 except  S d  = the maximum allowable
design stress (the lesser value of the base materials joined) permitted by Table S.2a and Table S.2b.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.3.4 Roof Design and Roof Manholes<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.3.4.1  The yield strength given in Table S.5a and Table S.5b shall be used for  F y  in 5.10.4.4.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.3.4.2  All stainless steel components of the roof manhole shall have a nominal thickness of not less than 5 mm
( 3 / 16  in.).<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.3.4.3  In 5.10.3.1 the stress limitations and safety factors of ANSI/AISC 360 shall be modified to those in ASCE 8.
ASCE 8, Appendix D entitled, “Allowable Stress Design,” shall be used in determining allowable unit stresses.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.3.4.4  For columns, ASCE 8 shall be used to determine allowable unit stresses. Modified allowable stress values
for  l / r  > 120 are not applicable.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.3.5 Annex F—Modifications<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In F.2, the shell thickness shall be as specified in S.3.2 except that the pressure  P  (in kPa [in. of water]) divided by
9.8G (12G) shall be added to the design liquid height in meters (ft).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.3.6 Annex M—Modifications<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.3.6.1  Annex M requirements shall be met for stainless steel tanks with a maximum design temperature over 40 °C
(100 °F) as modified by S.3.6.2 through S.3.6.7.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.3.6.2  Allowable shell stress shall be in accordance with Table S.2a and Table S.2b.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_455>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
S-7<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.3.6.3
In M.3.5, the requirements of 5.7.7 for flush-type cleanout fittings and of 5.7.8 for flush-type shell connections
shall be modified. The thickness of the bottom reinforcing plate, bolting flange, and cover plate shall be multiplied by the
greater of (a) the ratio of the material yield strength at 40 °C (100 °F) to the material yield strength at the maximum
design temperature, or (b) the ratio of 205 MPa (30,000 psi) to the material yield strength at the maximum design
temperature. (See Table S.5a and Table S.5b for yield strength.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.3.6.4
In M.3.5, the stainless steel structural allowable stress dependent on Yield Strength ( F y ) or Modulus of
Elasticity ( E ) or both Yield Strength ( F y ) and Modulus of Elasticity ( E ) shall be based on Yield Strength ( F y ) and
Modulus of Elasticity ( E ) at the maximum design temperature. Refer to Table S.5a and Table S.5b for Yield Strength
( F y ) and Table S.6a and Table S.6b for values of Modulus of Elasticity ( E ) at maximum design temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.3.6.5
In M.5.1, the requirements of 5.10.5 and 5.10.6 shall be multiplied by the ratio of the material modulus of
elasticity at 40 °C (100 °F) to the material modulus of elasticity at the maximum design temperature. (See Table S.6a
and Table S.6b for modulus of elasticity.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.3.6.6
In M.5.1, for a maximum design temperature above 40 °C (100 °F), the calculated minimum thickness of
roof plates, as defined in 10.5.1 and 5.10.6.1, shall be increased by the ratio of the material modulus of elasticity at
40 °C (100 °F) to the material modulus of elasticity at the maximum design temperature. (See Table S.6a and
Table S.6b for modulus of elasticity.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.3.6.7
In roof-to-shell-joint area calculation per 5.10.5.2 and 5.10.6.2, allowable stress  F a  shall be calculated using
0.6 x Yield Strength ( F y ) (least) at maximum design temperature. Refer to Table S.5a and Table S.5b for Yield
Strength ( F y ) at maximum design temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>1 5<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.3.6.8
In rafter spacing calculations per 5.10.4.4, Yield Strength ( F y ) of roof plate material at maximum design
temperature listed in Table S.5a and Table S.5b shall be used.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4
Fabrication and Construction<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.1
General<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Special precautions must be observed to minimize the risk of damage to the corrosion resistance of stainless steel.
Stainless steel shall be handled so as to minimize contact with iron or other types of steel during all phases of
fabrication, shipping, and construction. The following sections describe the major precautions that should be
observed during fabrication and handling.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.2
Storage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Storage should be under cover and well removed from shop dirt and fumes from pickling operations. If outside
storage is necessary, provisions should be made for rainwater to drain and allow the material to dry. Stainless steel
should not be stored in contact with carbon steel. Materials containing chlorides, including foods, beverages, oils, and
greases, should not come in contact with stainless steel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.3
Thermal Cutting<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.3.1
Thermal cutting of stainless steel shall be by the iron powder burning carbon arc or the plasma-arc method.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.4.3.2
Thermal cutting of stainless steel may leave a heat-affected zone and intergranular carbide precipitates.
This heat-affected zone may have reduced corrosion resistance unless removed by machining, grinding, or solution
annealing and quenching. The Purchaser shall specify if the heat-affected zone is to be removed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.4
Forming<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.4.1
Stainless steels shall be formed by a cold, warm, or hot forming procedure that is noninjurious to the
material.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_456>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S-8
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 1
S d  may be interpolated between temperatures.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 2
The design stress shall be the lesser of 0.3 of the minimum tensile strength or 0.9 of the minimum yield strength. The factor of 0.9 of
yield corresponds to a permanent strain of 0.10 %. When a lower level of permanent strain is desired, the Purchaser shall specify a reduced yield
factor in accordance with Table Y-2 of ASME Section II, Part D. The yield values at the different maximum design temperatures can be obtained
from Table S.5a.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 3
For dual-certified materials (e.g. ASTM A182M/A182 Type 304L/304), use the allowable stress of the grade specified by the
Purchaser.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE

<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.4.2
Stainless steels may be cold formed, providing the maximum strain produced by such forming does not
exceed 10 % and control of forming spring-back is provided in the forming procedure.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.4.4.3
Warm forming at 540 °C (1000 °F) to 650 °C (1200 °F) may cause intergranular carbide precipitation in 304,
316, and 317 grades of stainless steel. Unless stainless steel in this sensitized condition is acceptable for the service
of the equipment, it will be necessary to use 304L, 316L, or 317L grades or to solution anneal and quench after
forming. Warm forming shall be performed only with agreement of the Purchaser.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.4.4
Hot forming, if required, may be performed within a temperature range of 900 °C (1650 °F) to 1200 °C
(2200 °F).<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.4.5
Forming at temperatures between 650 °C (1200 °F) and 900 °C (1650 °F) is not permitted.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.5
Cleaning<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.4.5.1
When the Purchaser requires cleaning to remove surface contaminants that may impair the normal
corrosion resistance, it shall be done in accordance with ASTM A380, unless otherwise specified. Any additional
cleanliness requirements for the intended service shall be specified by the Purchaser.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.5.2
When welding is completed, flux residue and weld spatter shall be removed mechanically using stainless
steel tools.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.5.3
Removal of excess weld metal, if required, shall be done with a grinding wheel or belt that has not been
previously used on other metals.<<HEADING_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Maximum Design Temperature                   | Modulus of Elasticity (MPa)   |
| (°C) Not Exceeding                           |                               |
|:---------------------------------------------|:------------------------------|
| 40                                           | 194,000                       |
| 90                                           | 190,000                       |
| 150                                          | 186,000                       |
| 200                                          | 182,000                       |
| 260                                          | 179,000                       |
| NOTE Note: Interpolate between temperatures. |                               |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Maximum Design Temperature             | Modulus of Elasticity (psi)   |
| (°F) Not Exceeding                     |                               |
|:---------------------------------------|:------------------------------|
| 100                                    | 28,100,000                    |
| 200                                    | 27,500,000                    |
| 300                                    | 27,000,000                    |
| 400                                    | 26,400,000                    |
| 500                                    | 25,900,000                    |
| NOTE Interpolate between temperatures. |                               |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_460>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S-12
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.4.5.4
Chemical cleaners used shall not have a detrimental effect on the stainless steel and welded joints and shall
be disposed of in accordance with laws and regulations governing the disposal of such chemicals. The use of
chemical cleaners shall always be followed by thorough rinsing with water and drying (see S.4.9).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.6
Blast Cleaning<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>If blast cleaning is necessary, it shall be done with sharp acicular grains of sand or grit containing not more than 2 %
by weight iron as free iron or iron oxide. Steel shot or sand used previously to clean nonstainless steel is not
permitted.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.7
Pickling<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>If pickling of a sensitized stainless steel is necessary, an acid mixture of nitric and hydrofluoric acids shall not be used.
After pickling, the stainless steel shall be thoroughly rinsed with water and dried.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.8
Passivation or Iron Freeing<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>When passivation or iron freeing is specified by the Purchaser, it may be achieved by treatment with nitric or citric
acid. The use of hydrofluoric acid mixtures for passivation purposes is prohibited for sensitized stainless.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.9
Rinsing<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.9.1
When cleaning and pickling or passivation is required, these operations shall be followed immediately by
rinsing, not allowing the surfaces to dry between operations.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.4.9.2
Rinse water shall be potable and shall not contain more than 200 parts per million chloride at temperatures
below 40 °C (100 °F), or no more than 100 parts per million chloride at temperatures above 40 °C (100 °F) and below
65 °C (150 °F), unless specified otherwise by the Purchaser.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.9.3
Following final rinsing, the equipment shall be completely dried.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.10
Hydrostatic Testing<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.4.10.1
The rules of 7.3.6 apply to hydrostatic testing except that the penetrating oil test in 7.3.6, Item 2) shall be
replaced with liquid penetrant examination conducted by applying the penetrant on one side and developer on the
opposite side of the welds. The dwell time must be at least one hour.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.4.10.2
The materials used in the construction of stainless steel tanks may be subject to severe pitting, cracking, or
rusting if they are exposed to contaminated test water for extended periods of time. The Purchaser shall specify a
minimum quality of test water that conforms to the following requirements:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) Unless otherwise specified by the Purchaser, water used for hydrostatic testing of tanks shall be potable and
treated, containing at least 0.2 parts per million free chlorine.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) Water shall be substantially clean and clear.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) Water shall have no objectionable odor (that is, no hydrogen sulfide).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d) Water pH shall be between 6 and 8.3.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e) Water temperature shall be below 50 °C (120 °F).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
The chloride content of the water shall be below 50 parts per million, unless specified otherwise by the Purchaser.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_461>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
S-13<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.10.3  When testing with potable water, the exposure time shall not exceed 21 days, unless specified
otherwise by the Purchaser.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.10.4  When testing with other fresh waters, the exposure time shall not exceed 7 days.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.4.10.5  Upon completion of the hydrostatic test, water shall be completely drained. Wetted surfaces shall be
washed with potable water when nonpotable water is used for the test and completely dried. Particular attention shall
be given to low spots, crevices, and similar areas. Hot air drying is not permitted.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.11 Welding<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.4.11.1  Tanks and their structural attachments shall be welded by any of the processes permitted in 7.2.1.1 or by
the plasma arc process. Galvanized components or components coated with zinc-rich coating shall not be welded
directly to stainless steel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.4.11.2  Weld procedure qualifications for stainless steel alloys shall demonstrate strength matching the base
metals joined (i.e. 3XX stainless shall be welded with a matching E3XX or ER3XX filler metal).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.4.11.3  For the 300 series stainless steel materials, the filler metal mechanical properties and chemistry shall both
match the type of base metals joined (i.e. 3XX stainless shall be welded with a matching E3XX or ER3XX filler metal).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.4.11.4  For the 200 series stainless steel materials, filler metals of matching composition are not available. The
Manufacturer, with approval of the Purchaser, shall select the appropriate filler metal, taking into account the
corrosion resistance and mechanical properties required for the joint.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.11.5  Dissimilar material welds (stainless steels to carbon steels) shall use filler metals of E309/ER309 or higher
alloy content.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S.4.11.6  Two stainless steel plates identical in material type may be welded together prior to erection in order to
form a single shell plate subassembly. Plates welded together shall have thicknesses within 1.6 mm ( 1 / 16  in.) of each
other with the maximum plate thickness being 13 mm ( 1 / 2  in.). No more than two plates shall be used to form one
subassembly. Vertical edges of the pair of plates comprising a subassembly shall be aligned. The vertical joint offset
requirement of 5.1.5.2 (b) shall be applied only between the subassembly and plates above and below it. The
subassembly shall conform to the dimensional tolerances contained in Section 7 and shall be subjected to inspection
requirements contained in Section 8. At least 25 % of vertical spot radiographs shall be made at the subassembly
horizontal weld to field vertical weld intersection. All welding procedure specifications shall be in accordance with
Section 9.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.12 Welding Procedure and Welder Qualifications<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Impact tests are not required for austenitic stainless steel weld metal and heat-affected zones.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.13 Postweld Heat Treatment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Postweld heat treatment of austenitic stainless steel materials need not be performed unless specified by the
Purchaser.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.14 Examination of Welds<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.14.1 Radiographic Examination of Butt-Welds<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Radiographic examination of butt-welds shall be in accordance with 8.1 and Table S.4.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_462>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S-14
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.4.14.2 Examination of Welds by Liquid Penetrant Method<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The following component welds shall be examined by the liquid penetrant method before the hydrostatic test of the
tank:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) the shell-to-bottom inside attachment weld;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) all welds of opening connections in tank shell that are not completely radiographed, including nozzle and manhole
neck welds and neck-to-flange welds;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) all welds of attachments to shells, such as stiffeners, compression rings, clips, and other nonpressure parts for
which the thickness of both parts joined is greater than 19 mm ( 3 / 4  in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d) all butt-welded joints in tank annular plates on which backing strips are to remain.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.5 Marking<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Marking shall be in accordance with Section 10, except that nameplates shall not be attached by brazing.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>S.6 Annexes<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The following Annexes are modified for use with austenitic stainless steel storage tanks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) Annex A is not applicable to tanks built to this Annex, except for the radiography requirements of A.5.3 subject to
the joint efficiency used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) Annex C may be used; however, the Purchaser shall identify all materials of construction.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) Annex F is modified as outlined in S.3.5 of this Annex.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d) Annex J may be used, except the nominal shell thickness for all tank diameters shall not be less than 5 mm
( 3 / 16  in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e) Annex K is not applicable to tanks built to this Annex.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Annex M is modified as outlined in S.3.6 of this Annex.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g) Annex N is not applicable.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h) Annex O may be used; however, the structural members of Table O.1a and Table O.1b shall be of an acceptable
grade of material.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>i)
All other Annexes may be used without modifications.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_463>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Annex SC
(normative)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Stainless and Carbon Steel Mixed Materials Storage Tanks<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>SC.1 Scope<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>SC.1.1  This Annex covers materials, design, fabrication, erection, and testing requirements for vertical, cylindrical,
aboveground, closed- and open-top, welded, storage tanks constructed with stainless steel and carbon steel.
Generally, in this Annex the term stainless steel includes austenitic or duplex unless noted otherwise. Stainless steel
and carbon steel may be used in the same tank for shell rings, bottom plates, roof structure and other parts of a tank
to provide product storage for conditions that require only certain portions of the tanks to provide added corrosion
resistance. These tanks are mixed material tanks. Stainless steel and carbon steel plates may be mixed in the
bottom, roof or within any shell course. This Annex does not cover stainless steel clad plate or strip lined construction.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>SC.1.2  This Annex applies to tanks in non-refrigerated services with a maximum design temperature not exceeding
260  ° C (500  ° F). For the purposes of this Annex, the design temperature shall be the maximum design temperature
as specified by the Purchaser. It is cautioned that exothermic reactions occurring inside unheated storage tanks can
produce temperatures exceeding 40  ° C (100  ° F).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>SC.1.3  This Annex states only the requirements that differ from the basic rules in this standard. For requirements
not stated, the basic rules must be followed including Annex S and Annex X as applicable. References to paragraphs
in this Annex shall be to the basic document unless stipulated otherwise.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>SC.1.4  For limitations due to thermal effects see S.3.6 and X.3.7.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>SC.1.5  The nameplate of the tank shall indicate that the tank is in accordance with this Annex by the addition of
Annex SC to the information required by 10.1.1. In addition, the nameplate shall be marked with the maximum design
temperature in the space indicated in Figure 10.1.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>SC.2 Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>SC.2.1  Materials shall be in accordance with Section 4, Annex S, and Annex X.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>SC.2.2  Selection of the type/grade of stainless steel and carbon steel for mixed material tanks depends on the
service and environment to which it will be exposed and the effects of fabrication processes. (S.4.3.2, S.4.4.3, and
X.2.1.1) The Purchaser shall select the type/grade. The Purchaser shall also specify which components shall be
stainless steel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>SC.2.3  Components of a tank including shell, roof, bottom or bottom openings and their reinforcement may be
carbon steels meeting the requirements of Section 4, provided they are protected from corrosion and the design and
details consider the dissimilar properties of the materials used. Carbon steel attachments (e.g., clips for scaffolding)
shall not be welded directly to any internal stainless steel tank surface.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>SC.2.4  Impact tests are not required for austenitic stainless steel base metals. See X.2.3.2 for impact testing
requirements for duplex stainless steel. Carbon steels in a mixed material tank shall require impact testing in
accordance with the basic document.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>SC.2.5   Welding of stainless steel to carbon steel shall use stainless steel electrodes appropriate for the type/grade
of stainless steel used and the welding process employed.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>SC-1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_464>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>SC-2
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>SC.3 Design<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A structural analysis of the entire tank structure is required to adequately predict stresses due to differential
movements if item a and either items b or c also apply:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) austenitic stainless steel is joined to either carbon steel or duplex stainless steel components such as bottom to
first shell course, adjacent shell courses, and roof to top shell course;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) the design temperature exceeds 40 °C (100 °F) and the diameter exceeds 30 m (100 ft); or<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) the design temperature exceeds 93 °C (200 °F).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The structural analysis required above shall include all material properties that affect differential component
expansion and necessary for adequate stress prediction.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The material combination of this paragraph applies to all other sub-paragraphs in Section SC.3. No analysis of
stresses from differential movements is required for duplex stainless steel joined to carbon steel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>SC.3.1  Bottom<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>SC.3.1.1  When the bottom plate and first shell course are of different materials, the design shall account for
differential component expansion.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>SC.3.1.2  When the annular plate and first shell course are of different materials and the design temperature is
greater than 40 °C (100 °F), the design shall account for differential shell component expansion. When the first shell
course is carbon steel and the annular plate is stainless steel, the requirements of 5.5.1 shall apply.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>SC.3.2  Shell Design<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>SC.3.2.1  The variable point design method shall not be used for design of mixed material tank shells.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>SC.3.2.2  Austenitic stainless steel insert plates or thickened insert plates shall not be used in carbon steel or duplex
stainless steel plates and carbon steel or duplex stainless steel insert plates or thickened insert plates shall not be
used in austenitic stainless steel plates except when an evaluation for differential movement due to temperature is
performed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>SC.3.2.3  Where adjacent shell courses are of different materials and the design temperature is greater than 40  ° C
(100  ° F), the design shall account for differential shell course expansion with regard to out of plane bending in the
carbon steel plates. Use of stiffeners or thicker carbon steel plates may be required.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>SC.3.2.4  The required nominal shell thickness shall not be less than the greatest of the design shell thickness plus
corrosion allowance, hydrostatic test shell thickness, or the nominal plate thickness listed in 5.6.1.1 (note 4 does not
apply to the first shell courses made of stainless steel material).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>SC.3.3   When the roof and shell are of different materials and the operating temperature is greater than 40  ° C
(100  ° F), the design shall account for differential component expansion. Use of stiffeners or thicker component
members may be required.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>SC.3.4 Nozzles and Manways<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>SC.3.4.1  Reinforcement requirements of 5.7 must be maintained except insert plates and thickened insert plates
shall comply with SC.3.2.2.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>SC.3.4.2   Nozzles and manways shall be of the same material as the shell course unless otherwise specified by the
Purchaser.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_465>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
SC-3<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>SC.3.4.3  Reinforcing plates for shell penetrations shall be carbon steel to carbon steel and stainless steel to
stainless steel even if the nozzle material differs from the shell material.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>SC.4 Miscellaneous Requirements<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>SC.4.1  Chemical cleaners and pickling solutions used shall not have a detrimental effect on the stainless steel or
carbon steel in mixed material tanks and their welded joints. Chemical cleaners and pickling solutions shall be
disposed of in accordance with laws and regulations governing the disposal of such chemicals. The use of chemical
cleaners shall always be followed by thorough rinsing with potable water and drying (see S.4.9 and X.4.5).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>SC.4.2  Impact tests are not required for austenitic stainless steel weld metals and heat-affected zones. Impact tests
of the carbon steel or duplex stainless steel heat affected zone shall be performed when required by the basic
document or Annex X.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>SC.4.3  Postweld heat treatment of austenitic stainless steel and duplex stainless steel materials need not be
performed unless specified by the Purchaser. PWHT of carbon steel components shall be performed when required
by the basic document. For mixed material nozzle assemblies, the PWHT requirements of 5.7.4 are not mandatory
except when specified by the Purchaser. The Purchaser is cautioned that mixed material nozzles with duplex
stainless steel should not be PWHT due to the potential damaging effects of high temperature on the duplex material.
The Purchaser is advised to discuss with a materials consultant or mill representative to determine what PWHT can
be done for the specific material/chemistry/configuration.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>SC.4.4  Surfaces of carbon steel plates shall be free of rust and scale prior to welding to stainless steel plates.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>SC.4.5   At butt welds between stainless and carbon steel, at least one side of the joint shall be beveled with land not
to exceed  t /3 in order to prevent excessive weld metal dilution.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>SC.4.6   Internal galvanic corrosion will occur by using mixed material construction and additional mitigation such as
appropriate localized coatings should be considered.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>SC.4.7   Where substantial quantities of uncoated stainless steel are welded to coated carbon steel, accelerated
corrosion rates are possible at holidays in the carbon steel coating.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_466>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_467>>

| Air Test  | Welded shell joints above the hydrostatic test water level, if not vacuum tested or tested to        |           |    |
|           | 7.3.7.1, Item 1) or 7.3.7.1, Item 3).                                                                |           |    |
| Air Test  | Roofs designed to be gas-tight if roof seams are not vacuum-box tested.                              |           |    |
| Air Test  | Compartment welds of external floating roofs, if not tested with vacuum box or penetrating oil.      | C.3.6     |    |
|           |                                                                                                      | F.4.4     |    |
|           |                                                                                                      | F.8.3     |    |
|           |                                                                                                      | G.10.1.2  |    |
|           |                                                                                                      | H.6.4     |    |
|           |                                                                                                      | J.4.2.2   |    |
|           |                                                                                                      | 7.3.7     |    |
|           |                                                                                                      | 5.7.8.11  |    |
|           |                                                                                                      | 7.2.1.12d |    |
|           |                                                                                                      | 7.2.3.6   |    |
|           |                                                                                                      | 7.2.3.7   |    |
|           |                                                                                                      | 7.2.4.1a  |    |
| Air Test  | Annex F roofs during hydro-test of tanks.                                                            |           |    |
| Air Test  | Aluminum dome roofs, if required to be gas-tight.                                                    |           |    |
| Air Test  | Shop fabricated compartments (pontoons). Test in shop and field.                                     |           |    |
| Air Test  | Shop built tanks, if not tested per 7.3.2 through 7.3.8.                                             |           |    |
| Hydro     | Tank shell.                                                                                          |           |    |
| MT        | Flush-type shell connections: Nozzle-to-tank shell, Repad welds, shell-to-bottom reinforcing         |           |    |
|           | pad welds on the root pass, each 13 mm (1/2 in.) of weld, and completed weld. Inspect after          |           |    |
|           | stress relieving before hydro-test.                                                                  |           |    |
| MT        | Non-structural small attachments, such as insulation clips (not supports) studs and pins,            |           |    |
|           | unless tested by liquid penetrant.                                                                   |           |    |
| MT        | Permanent attachment welds and temporary weld removal areas on Group IV, IVA, V, and VI              |           |    |
|           | materials, unless tested by liquid penetrant.                                                        |           |    |
| MT        | Completed welds of stress relieved assemblies, after stress relief, but before hydro-test,           |           |    |
|           | unless tested by PT.                                                                                 |           |    |
| MT        | First pass of the internal shell-to-bottom weld unless examined by penetrating oil or PT or VB.      |           |    |
|           | Not required if the final weld is tested by pressure (see 7.2.4.2), or if agreed to by Purchaser     |           |    |
|           | and the final weld is tested by MT, PT, or VB.                                                       |           |    |
| MT        | Final shell-to-bottom weld, as alternative to requirements of 7.2.4.1 or 7.2.4.2 either side of the  |           |    |
|           | finished joint, if not PT or VB tested.                                                              |           |    |
| MT        | Shell-to-bottom fillet welds including the root pass, 20 mm (1/2 in.), and final surface of Annex    |           |    |
|           | M tanks for which the stress concentration factor of K = 2.0 is used.                                |           |    |
| Pen. Oil  | First pass of the internal shell-to-bottom weld if approved instead of MT, VB, or PT.                |           |    |
| Pen. Oil  | Welded shell joints if no water for hydrostatic test and if not tested to the requirements of 7.3.6, |           |    |
|           | Item 2) a) ii) or 7.3.6, Item 2) a) iii).                                                            |           |    |
| Pen. Oil  | Welded shell joints above the hydrostatic test water level if not tested to 7.3.7.1, Item 2) or      |           |    |
|           | 7.3.7.1, Item 3).                                                                                    |           |    |
