<<HEADING level=3>>Acceptance Standards:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>MT:
ASME Section VIII, Appendix 6 (Paragraphs 6-3, 6-4, 6-5)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>PT:
ASME Section VIII, Appendix 8, (Paragraphs 8-3, 8-4, 8-5)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>RT:
ASME Section VIII, Paragraph UW-51(b)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Tracer Gas: API Std 650, Section 8.6.11.b<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>UT:
For welds examined by UT in lieu of RT, acceptance standards are in Annex U.6.6. For UT when RT is used for
the requirements of 7.3.2.1, the acceptance standard is as agreed upon by the Manufacturer and Purchaser.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>VB:
API Std 650, Section 8.6.9<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>VE:
API Std 650, Section 8.5.2<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Examiner Qualifications:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>MT:
API Std 650, Section 8.2.3<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>PT:
API Std 650, Section 8.4.3<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>RT:
ASNT SNT-TC-1A Level II or III. Level-I personnel may be used under the supervision of a Level II or Level III
with a written procedure in accordance with ASME Section V, Article 2.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Tracer Gas: None<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>UT:
For welds examined by UT in lieu of RT, the inspector must be ASNT-TC-1A or CP-189 Level II or Level III per
API Std 650 Annex U.4.1. For UT when RT is used for the requirements of 7.3.2.1, the required qualifications are
ASNT-TC-1A Level II or Level III. A Level I may be used with restrictions, see API Std 650, Section 8.3.2.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>VE:
API Std 650, Section 8.5.1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>VB:
API Std 650, Section 8.6.4<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Procedure Requirements:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>MT:
ASME Section V, Article 7<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>PT:
ASME Section V, Article 6<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>RT:
A procedure is not required. However, the examination method must comply with ASME Section V, Article 2.
Acceptance standards shall be in accordance with ASME Section VIII, Paragraph UW-51(b).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>UT:
For shell welds examined by UT in lieu of RT, ASME, Section V, Article 4 and API Std 650 Annex U.3.5. For
welds when RT is used for the requirements of 7.3.2.1, ASME Section V.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>VB:
API Std 650, Sections 8.6.2, 8.6.5, 8.6.6, 8.6.7, and 8.6.8<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>VE:
None<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Tracer Gas: API Std 650, Section 8.6.11.a<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_471>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Annex U
(normative)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Ultrasonic Examination in Lieu of Radiography<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.1 General<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.1.1 Purpose<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>This Annex provides detailed rules for the use of the ultrasonic examination (UT) method for the examination of tank
seams as permitted by 7.3.2.1. This alternative is limited to joints where the thickness of the thinner of the two
members joined is greater than or equal to 10 mm ( 3 / 8  in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.1.2 Application and Extent<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The provisions of 8.1 governing:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) when adjacent plates may be regarded as the same thickness;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) application (see 8.1.1); and<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) number and Locations (see 8.1.2);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>shall apply to this ultrasonic method. When these sections refer to radiography, for purposes of this Annex, they shall
be read as applied to UT.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.2 Definitions<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.2.1
documenting
Preparation of text and/or and figures.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.2.2
evaluation
All activities required in U.6.3 through U.6.6 to determine the acceptability of a flaw.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.2.3
flaw
A reflector that is not geometric or metallurgical in origin that may be detectable by nondestructive examination but is
not necessarily rejectable.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.2.4
flaw categorization
Whether a flaw is a surface flaw or is a subsurface flaw (see U.6.4). Note that a flaw need not be surface-breaking to
be categorized as a surface flaw.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>U.2.5
flaw characterization
The process of quantifying the size, location and shape of a flaw. See U.6.3 for size and location. The only shape
characterization required by this Annex is applied to the results of supplemental surface examination by MT or PT
(see U.6.6.2).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>U-1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_472>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>U-2
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.2.6
indication
That which marks or denotes the presence of a reflector.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>U.2.7
interpretation
The determination of whether an indication is relevant or non-relevant. i.e. whether it originates from a geometric or
metallurgical feature or conversely originates from a flaw (see U.6.2).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.2.8
investigation
Activities required to determine the interpretation of an indication (see U.6.1 and U.6.2).<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.2.9
recording
The writing of ultrasonic data onto an appropriate electronic medium.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.2.10
reflector
An interface at which an ultrasonic beam encounters a change in acoustic impedance and at which at least part of the
energy is reflected.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.3 Technique<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>U.3.1  The UT volume shall include the weld metal, plus the lesser of 25 mm (1 in.) or  t  of adjoining base metal on
each side of the weld unless otherwise agreed upon by the Purchaser and the Manufacturer.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>U.3.2  UT for the detection of flaws shall be performed using automated, computer-based data acquisition except
that initial scanning of adjacent base metal for flaws that can interfere with the automated examination may be
performed manually. UT for sizing of flaws shall be performed as described in U.6.3.1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>U.3.3  A documented examination strategy or scan plan shall be provided showing transducer placement,
movement, and component coverage that provides a standardized and repeatable methodology for weld acceptance.
The scan plan shall also include ultrasonic beam angle to be used, beam directions with respect to weld centerline,
and tank material volume examined for each weld. The documentation shall be made available to the Owner upon
request.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.3.4  Data from the examination volume, per U.3.1, shall be recorded and/or documented as follows:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) For automated computer-based scans, data shall be recorded using the same system essential variables,
specified value or range of values, used for the demonstration of the procedure per U.4.3.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) For manual scans, results shall be documented in a written report.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>U.3.5  The UT shall be performed in accordance with a written procedure which has been reviewed and approved by
the Purchaser and conforms to the requirements of ASME Section V, Article 4, except that:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) the calibration block shown in Figure T-434.2.1 of ASME Section V, Article 4 shall be used for distance amplitude<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>(e.g. pulse-echo) techniques, and Figure III-434.2.1 (a) or (b) shall be used for non-distance amplitude [e.g. Time
of Flight Diffraction (TOFD) examination] techniques,<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) for examination techniques that provide plate quality information (e.g. TOFD), the initial base material straight-
beam examination need not be performed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_473>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
U-3<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>U.3.6  The examination methodology (including U.6.6) shall be demonstrated to be effective over the full weld
volume. It is recognized that TOFD may have limitations in detection of flaws at the surface such that it may be
necessary to supplement TOFD with pulse-echo techniques suitable for the detection of near-field and far-field flaws.
The variety of surface and sub-surface category flaws in the test plate mandated by U.4.3a are intended to ensure
that any such limitations are adequately addressed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.4 Personnel Qualifications and Training<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>U.4.1 Personnel Qualifications —Personnel performing and evaluating UT examinations shall be qualified and
certified in accordance with their employer’s written practice. ASNT SNT-TC-IA or CP-189 shall be used as a
guideline. Only Level-II or Level-III personnel shall perform UT examinations, analyze the data, or interpret the
results.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.4.2 Qualification Records —Qualification records of certified personnel shall be approved by the Manufacturer
and maintained by their employer.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>U.4.3 Personnel Testing —Personnel who acquire and analyze UT data shall be trained using the equipment of
U.3.2, and the procedure of U.3.5 above. Additionally, they shall pass a practical examination based on the technique
on a blind test plate. The testing program details shall be by agreement between the Purchaser and the inspection
company but shall in any case include the following elements as a minimum.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) The test plate shall contain a variety of surface and sub-surface category flaws including multiple flaws described
in U.6.5. Some of the flaws shall be acceptable and others unacceptable per the applicable criteria of Table U.1a
or Table U.1b.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) The practical examination should cover detection, interpretation, sizing, plotting, categorization, grouping, and
characterization that is sufficient to cover the cases outlined in U.6.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) Criteria for passing the test shall include limits on the number of miscalls, both of rejectable flaws missed or
accepted and acceptable regions rejected.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d) Testing shall be facilitated by a third-party or by the Purchaser.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.5 Level III Review<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.5.1  The final data package shall be reviewed by a UT Level-III individual qualified in accordance with U.4.1 and
U.4.3 above. The review shall include the following.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) The ultrasonic data record.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) Data interpretations.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) Evaluations of indications performed by another qualified Level-II or Level-III individual. The data review may be
performed by another individual from the same organization.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>U.5.2  Alternatively, the review may be achieved by arranging for a data acquisition and initial interpretation by a
Level-II individual qualified in accordance with. U.4.1 and U.4.3 above, and a final interpretation and evaluation shall
be performed by a Level-III individual qualified per U.5.1.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.6 Interpretation and Evaluation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>U.6.1 Investigation Criteria —Reflectors that produce a response greater than 20 % of the reference level shall be
investigated. Alternatively, for methods or techniques that do not use amplitude recording levels, sized reflectors
longer than 40 % of the acceptable surface or subsurface flaws in Table U.1a and Table U.1b shall be investigated.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_474>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>U-4
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The investigation shall interpret whether the indication originates from a flaw or is a geometric indication in
accordance with U.6.2 below. When the reflector is determined to be a flaw, the flaw shall be evaluated and
acceptance criteria of Table U.1a and Table U.1b as applicable shall apply.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.6.2 Interpretation as Geometric/Metallurgical —Ultrasonic indications of geometric and metallurgical origin
shall be interpreted as follows:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>U.6.2.1  Indications that are determined to originate from the surface configurations (such as weld reinforcement or
root geometry) or variations in metallurgical structure of materials may be interpreted as geometric indications, and<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) need not be sized or categorized in accordance with U.6.3 and U.6.4 below;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) need not be compared to the allowable flaw acceptance criteria of Table U.1a and Table U.2b; and<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) the maximum indication amplitude (if applicable) and location shall be documented, for example: internal
attachments, 200 % DAC maximum amplitude, 1 in. above the weld centerline, on the inside surface, from 90° to
95°.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.6.2.2  The following steps shall be taken to classify an indication as geometric.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) Interpret the area containing the indication in accordance with the applicable examination procedure.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) Plot and verify the indication’s coordinates, provide a cross-sectional display showing the indication’s position and
any surface conditions such as root or counter-bore.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) Review fabrication or weld prep drawings.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.6.2.3  Alternatively, other NDE methods or techniques may be applied to interpret an indication as geometric (e.g.,
alternative UT beam angles, radiography, ID and/or OD profiling).<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.6.3 Flaw Sizing<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.6.3.1  Flaws shall be sized using automated, computer-based data acquisition or by a supplemental manual
technique that has been demonstrated to perform acceptably per U.4.3.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>U.6.3.2  The dimensions of the flaw shall be defined by the rectangle that fully contains the area of the flaw. The
length ( l ) of the flaw shall be drawn parallel to the inside pressure-retaining surface of the component. The height ( h )
of the flaw shall be drawn normal to the inside pressure-retaining surface.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.6.4 Flaw Categorization<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>If the space between the surface and the flaw in the through-thickness direction is less than one-half the measured
height of the flaw, then the flaw shall be categorized as a surface flaw with flaw height extending to the surface of the
material.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.6.5 Grouping of Multiple Flaws<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>U.6.5.1  Discontinuous flaws that are oriented primarily in parallel planes shall be considered to lie in a single plane if
the distance between the adjacent planes is equal to or less than 13 mm ( 1 / 2  in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.6.5.2  If the space between two flaws aligned along the axis of weld is less than the length of the longer of the two,
the two flaws shall be considered a single flaw.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.6.5.3  If the space between two flaws aligned in the through-thickness direction is less than the height of the flaw
of greater height, the two flaws shall be considered a single flaw.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_475>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
U-5<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.6.6 Flaw Acceptance Criteria<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>U.6.6.1 Acceptance Criteria Tables —Flaw dimensions resulting after the application of the rules of U.6.3, U.6.4,
and U.6.5 shall be evaluated for acceptance using the criteria of Table U.1a and Table U.1b.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>U.6.6.2 Surface Examination —Flaws categorized as surface flaws during the UT examination may or may not be
surface-connected. Therefore, unless the UT data analysis confirms that the flaw is not surface-connected, a
supplemental surface examination (MT or PT) shall be performed in accordance with 8.2 or 8.4 as applicable for all
surface flaws. Any flaws which are detected by MT or PT and characterized as planar are unacceptable regardless of
length.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.7 Repairs<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>All repaired areas, plus the lesser of 25 mm (1 in.) or  t  of the adjoining weld on each side of the repair, shall be
reinspected per this Annex.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>U.8 Flaw Documentation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In addition to the data record prescribed by U.3.4, written documentation shall be produced for each unacceptable
flaw and those acceptable flaws that either exceed 50 % of reference level for amplitude based techniques or exceed
75 % of the acceptable length for non-amplitude techniques.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_477>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Annex V
(normative)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Design of Storage Tanks for External Pressure<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.1
Scope<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>This Annex provides minimum requirements that may be specified by the Purchaser for tanks that are designed for
external pressure (vacuum) loading. This Annex applies to tanks for which the design external pressure exceeds
0.25 kPa (1 in. of water) but does not exceed 6.9 kPa (1.0 lbf/in. 2 ). This Annex applies to tanks subject to uniform
external pressure. The requirements in this Annex represent accepted practice for application to flat-bottom tanks.
However, the Purchaser may specify other procedures or additional requirements. Any deviation from the
requirements of this Annex must be by agreement between the Purchaser and the Manufacturer.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.2
General<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The design procedures presented in this Annex are intended to allow the user to evaluate the design of the bottom,
shell, and fixed roof of tanks for a specified design external pressure. See 5.2.2 for requirements for combining
external pressure loads with other design loads. The requirements of this Annex are not intended to supersede the
requirements of other Annexes of this standard that may be specified. For Annex M, S, SC, and X tanks, the variables
in the equations prescribed in this Annex shall be modified in accordance with the requirements of Annex M, Annex S,
Annex SC, and Annex X, respectively.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.3
Nomenclature and Definitions<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.3.1
Nomenclature<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>is the angle between a horizontal plane and the surface of the roof plate, in degrees;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A reqd
is the total required cross-sectional area of the stiffener region, in mm 2  (in. 2 );<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A stiff
is the required cross-sectional area of stiffener, mm 2  (in. 2 ) Note:  A stiff   must be at least  1 / 2   ×   A total ;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>D
is the nominal tank diameter, in m (ft);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>D L
is the dead load, the weight of the tank or tank component calculated using nominal thickness unless
otherwise specified, in kPa (lb/ft 2 );<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>E
is the modulus of elasticity of the roof plate material, in MPa, (lb/in. 2 );<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f
is the smallest of the allowable tensile stresses of the roof plate material, shell plate material, or stiffener ring
material at the maximum operating temperature, in MPa (lb/in. 2 );<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f c
is the smallest of the allowable compressive stresses of the roof plate material, shell plate material,
bottom plate material, or stiffener ring material at the maximum operating temperature, in MPa (lb/in. 2 ).
f c  =  0.4 F y  of components considered for the intermediate and bottom stiffener regions. However, for
carbon steel,  f c  need not be less than 103 MPa (15,000 lb/in. 2 ).  f c  = 0.6 F y  of components considered for
the top end stiffener region. However, for carbon steel,  f c  need not be less than 140 MPa (20,000 lb/in. 2 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>F pe
is a modifier for the design external pressure when used in load combinations with other variable loads.
Value equals normal operating external pressure/design external pressure or a minimum of 0.4.
Manufacturer to use 0.4 when not specified. (See 5.2.2.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>F y
is the yield strength of the component at the maximum operating temperature, in MPa (lb/in. 2 );<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V-1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_478>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V-2
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>G in
is the unit weight of liquid inside tank, in kg/m 3  (lb/ ft 3 );<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>G out
is the unit weight of flood liquid, in kg/m 3  (lb/ ft 3 ) (1000 kg/m 3  [62.4 lb/ ft 3 ] for water);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H
is the shell height, in m (ft);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h 1 ,  h 2 … h n
is the height of shell courses 1, 2, 3, through n, respectively, in m (ft);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H in
is the height or depth of liquid inside tank, in m (ft);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H safe
is the maximum height of unstiffened shell permitted, based on  t smin , in m (ft);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H TS
is the Transformed height of tank shell, in m (ft);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>I act
is the The actual moment of inertia of the stiffener ring region, in cm 4  (in. 4 );<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>I reqd
is the required moment of inertia of the stiffener ring, in cm 4  (in. 4 );<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L 1 ,  L 2
is the distances between adjacent intermediate stiffeners or intermediate stiffener and top of shell or
bottom of shell, respectively, in m (ft);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L r
is the minimum roof live load on horizontal projected area of the roof, kPa (lb/ft 2 ) = 1.0kPa (20 lb/ft 2 );<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L s
equals ( L 1  +  L 2 )/2, in m (ft);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>N
is the number of waves into which a shell will buckle under external pressure;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>N s
is the number of intermediate stiffeners;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P e
is the specified design external pressure, in kPa (lb/ft 2 );<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P r
is the total design external pressure for design of roof, in kPa (lb/ft 2 );<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P s
is the total design external pressure for design of shell, in kPa (lb/ft 2 ).  P s  = the greater of 1) the specified
design external pressure,  P e , excluding wind or 2)  W  +  F pe P e  (see 5.2.2 for an important consideration);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>is the stability factor (see V.8.1 for values);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Q
is the radial load imposed on the intermediate stiffener by the shell, in N/m (lb/in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>q s
is the first moment of area of stiffener for design of stiffener attachment weld, in cm 3  (in. 3 );<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>R
is the roof dish radius, in m (ft);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S
is the design balanced specified snow load ( S b ), in kPa (lb/ft 2 );<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S d
is the allowable design stress, in MPa, (lb/in. 2 );<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t
is the nominal shell thickness, mm (in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t b
is the nominal thickness of bottom plate under the shell, in mm (in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t cone
is the required nominal thickness of cone roof plate, in mm (in.). Maximum corroded thickness shall be
12.5 mm (0.5 in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_479>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
V-3<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t dome
is the required nominal thickness of dome roof plate, in mm (in.). Maximum corroded thickness shall be
12.5 mm (0.5 in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t s 1 ,  t s 2 … t sn
is the nominal thickness of cylindrical shell course 1, 2…n, in mm (in.), where the subscript numbering is
from top to bottom of the shell;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE
The subscript 1 denotes the top shell course and  n  denotes the lowest shell course;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t shell
is the nominal thickness of shell at level under consideration, in mm (in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t s min
is the nominal thickness of thinnest shell course, in mm (in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V 1
is the radial load imposed on the stiffener by the shell, in N/m (lb/in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V s 1
is the radial pressure load imposed on the stiffener from the shell for sizing the stiffener attachment weld,
in N/m (lb/ft);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>v s
is the radial shear load on stiffener for sizing the stiffener attachment weld, in N (lb);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V s 2
is the weld shear flow load imposed for sizing the stiffener attachment weld, in N/m (lb/ft);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W
is the maximum wind pressure consistent with the specified design wind velocity, in kPa (lb/ft 2 ). The
maximum wind pressure shall be calculated as follows (see 5.9.7.1, Note 2):<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In SI units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W
1.48
V

<<PARAGRAPH>>In USC units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W

<<PARAGRAPH>>where<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V
is the specified design wind velocity (3-sec gust), in kph (mph);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W bott
is the weight of bottom plate, in kg/m 2  (lb/ft 2 );<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>w shell
is the contributing width of shell on each side of intermediate stiffener, in mm (in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X btm
is the length of bottom plate within tension/compression ring region, in mm (in.).  X btm   = 16  t b ;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X cone
is the length of cone roof within tension/compression ring region, in mm (in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X dome
is the length of umbrella or dome roof within tension/compression ring region, in mm (in.);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X shell

<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_480>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V-4
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.3.2
Definitions<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V.3.2.1
specified design external pressure ( P e )
Design external pressure specified on the tank data sheet (see Annex L) by the Purchaser. This specified value
excludes any external pressure due to wind.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>●
14<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.3.2.2
total design external pressure for the roof ( P r )
Sum of the specified design external pressure and the roof live load or snow load and the dead load as provided in
V.7.1.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.3.2.3
total design external pressure for the shell ( P s )
Sum of the specified design external pressure and the external pressure due to wind as combined in V.8.1.2.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.4
Construction Tolerances<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The procedures prescribed in this Annex are only valid for tanks that satisfy the construction tolerances of 7.5.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.5
Corrosion Allowance<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Unless specified otherwise by the Purchaser, the evaluation of tanks in accordance with the requirements of this
Annex may be based on the nominal thickness of the pressure-resisting components. If the nature of the tank service
conditions is such that corrosion will result in a uniform loss of thickness of the affected components, the Purchaser
should specify that corrosion allowance be deducted from the nominal thickness used in the evaluation.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.6
Testing<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Testing of the tank design for external pressure is not required by this Annex, but may be performed if specified by the
Purchaser.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.7
Fixed Roof<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The total design external pressure loading,  P r , on the roof is determined by the following equation:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P r  = the greater of  D L  + ( L r  or  S ) +  F pe  P e  or  D L  +  P e   + 0.4 ( L r  or  S )<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.7.1
Column-Supported Cone Roof<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Column-supported cone roofs may be used on tanks designed for external pressure, providing the design and
construction satisfy the following requirements.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V.7.1.1
The roof plate spanning between support rafters may be designed as a simple beam spanning several
supports, or as a catenary beam spanning between supports, or as a diaphragm, by agreement between the
Purchaser and the Manufacturer. Regardless of the design method selected, the following considerations shall be
addressed in the design:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) allowable stress for both membrane and bending;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) joint efficiency of welds joining the roof plates together;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) assumed end fixity conditions for plate (beam) span;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d) allowable deflection criteria.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_481>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
V-5<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>If the roof plate is designed as a catenary beam, the following additional considerations shall be addressed in the
design.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e) Possibility of stress reversal and fatigue loading of welds at and between supports of the roof plate.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.7.1.2
Additional guidance on the design of supported cone roof plates for pressure loading may be found in
Reference 8 and Reference 9, for example, and in other published texts.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.7.2

<<HEADING level=3>>V.8
Shell<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.8.1
Unstiffened Shells<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The procedure utilizes the nominal thickness of thinnest shell course and the transformed shell method to establish
intermediate stiffener number and locations. The equations in V.8.1.2 and V.8.1.3 contain variables for a stability
factor,  ψ , that is dependent upon the magnitude of the design external pressure. The equations also include a 0.8
“knockdown” factor for imperfections in the cylindrical shell geometry. Shells shall be checked for two conditions:
1) the combined wind plus design external pressure, and 2) for design external pressure alone. Each condition shall
be checked using the appropriate stability factor,  ψ,  as follows.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_485>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
V-9<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t dome<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X dome<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Top end
stiffener<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Intermediate
stiffener<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L 1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2 x  w shell<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L 2<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Bottom end
stiffener region<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE    See Annex F, Figure F.2 for alternative configurations and
associated limitations on structural section used for top stiffener.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Figure V.1b—Dimensions for Self-Supporting Dome Roof<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_486>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V-10
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In SI Units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Condition 1—Wind plus specified design external pressure<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>ψ  = 1.0 for wind plus design external pressure [when design external pressure ( P e ) is less than or equal to
0.25 kPa]. For this case, Annex V is not mandatory.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>ψ  = [ P e  + 0.70]/0.95 for wind plus design external pressure [when design external pressure ( P e ) is greater
than 0.25 kPa, but less than or equal to 0.70 kPa].<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>ψ  = [ P e /0.48] for wind plus design external pressure [when design external pressure ( P e ) is greater than
0.70 kPa; however,  ψ  need not exceed 2.5].<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Condition 2—Specified design external pressure only<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>ψ =  3.0<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In USC Units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Condition 1—Wind plus specified design external pressure<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>ψ =  1.0 for wind plus design external pressure [when design external pressure ( P e ) is less than or equal to
5.2 psf]. For this case, Annex V is not mandatory.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>ψ =  [ P e  + 15]/20 for wind plus design external pressure [when design external pressure ( P e ) is greater than
5.2 psf, but less than or equal to 15 psf].<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>ψ =  [ P e /10] for wind plus design external pressure [when design external pressure ( P e ) is greater than 15 psf;
however,  ψ  need not exceed 2.5].<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Condition 2—Specified design external pressure only<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>ψ =  3.0<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V.8.1.1
For an unstiffened tank shell subjected to external pressure sufficient to cause buckling, buckling will occur
elastically if the following criterion (see note below) is satisfied. Note that this criterion will typically be satisfied except
for very small, exceptionally thick tanks. If this criterion is not satisfied, external pressure effects should be evaluated
in accordance with the requirements of the ASME  Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code , Section VIII, Division 1.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 1
Source is The Structural Research Council (SSRC) text, “Guide to Stability Design Criteria for Metal Structures,” Section
14.3.5.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In SI units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>D
t s min

<<HEADING level=3>>V.8.1.3
The equation in V.8.1.2 can be rewritten to calculate the nominal thickness of the thinnest shell course
required for a specified design external pressure as:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In SI units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<HEADING level=3>>V.8.1.4
For tanks with shell courses of varying thickness, the transformed shell height,  H TS , for the tank shell is
determined in accordance with the following procedure:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) The transformed height of the shell is calculated as the sum of the transformed widths of the individual shell
courses as described in Item b.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) The transformed width of each individual shell course is calculated by multiplying the actual shell height by the
ratio  ( t s 1 / t act ) 2.5 . Note that  t s 1  =  t act  for the top shell course.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The transformed shell height is determined from the following equation:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H TS
h 1
t s 1
t s 1
-----




2.5
h 2
t s 1
t s 2
-----




2.5
… h n
t s 1
t sn
-----




2.5
+
+
=<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The transformed shell height is an analytical model of the actual tank. The transformed shell has a uniform thickness
equal to the topmost shell thickness and a height equal to the transformed height. This analytical model of the actual
tank will have essentially an equivalent resistance to buckling from external pressure as the actual tank.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.8.1.5
End stiffeners shall be provided for unstiffened shells and shall satisfy the design requirements of V.8.2.3.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_488>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V-12
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.8.2
Circumferentially Stiffened Shells<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Tank shells may be strengthened with circumferential stiffeners to increase the resistance to buckling under external
pressure loading. When circumferential stiffeners are used to strengthen the cylindrical shell to resist buckling due to
external pressure, the design of the stiffeners shall meet the following requirements.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.8.2.1
Number and Spacing of Intermediate Stiffener Rings<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.8.2.1.1
Calculate the transformed shell height in accordance with V.8.1.4. (See V.10 for a numerical example of
the calculation of the transformed shell height.)<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V.8.2.1.2
Calculate the maximum spacing of intermediate stiffeners. The equation in V.8.1.3 can be rearranged to
solve for a “safe height” of shell,  H safe , as follows.  H safe  is the maximum height of unstiffened shell permitted, based on
the transformed shell thickness ( t s 1 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In SI units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H safe
t s min
2.5  E<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>15,203 D
1.5  P s
----------------------------------------
=<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In USC units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H safe
0.6  t s min
2.5  E<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>D
1.5  P s
-----------------------------------
=<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V.8.2.1.3
Calculate the number of intermediate stiffeners required,  N s , based on  H safe , in accordance with the
following equation. A zero or negative value of  N s  means that no intermediate stiffeners are required. Round up the
calculated value of  N s  to the nearest integer for use in subsequent calculations.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>N s

<<PARAGRAPH>>2.5<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>For design purposes, the minimum value of  N  is 2 and the maximum value of  N  is 10. Use the same  N  2  for
intermediate and end stiffeners.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.8.2.2.2  The distance between adjacent intermediate stiffeners on the actual shell for shells of non-uniform
thickness is determined in accordance with the following procedures.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) Maximum spacing,  L s , on minimum shell thickness,  t s min , = H Safe .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) Maximum spacing,  L s  on other shell thicknesses  = (H Safe )(t sx /t smin ) 2.5 , where  t sx  is the individual shell thickness.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) Where the spacing between stiffeners includes different shell thicknesses, adjust the actual spacing using the
transformed shell spacings adjusted accordingly. See V.10 for a numerical example of this procedure.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.8.2.2.3  The radial load imposed on the stiffener by the shell is determined in accordance with the following
equation:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In SI units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Q
1000 P s L s
=<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In USC units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Q
P s L s
12
----------
=<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The stiffener should be located at  H TS    / ( N s  + 1)  spacing where  N s  is number of intermediate stiffeners on the
transformed shell.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.8.2.2.4  The actual moment of inertia of the intermediate stiffener region,  I act  shall be greater than or equal to the
total required moment of inertia of this region,  I reqd , where:<<HEADING_END>>

considered effective as an end stiffener shall be not more than 16 t b , where  t b  is the thickness of the bottom or annular
plates, unless a detailed stress analysis demonstrates that a greater width may be used. The contributing distance on
one side of the stiffener is determined in accordance with the following equation:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<HEADING level=3>>V.8.2.4 Strength of Stiffener Attachment Weld<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Stiffening ring attachment welds shall be sized to resist the full radial pressure load from the shell between stiffeners,
and shear loads acting radially across the stiffener caused by external design loads carried by the stiffener (if any)
and a computed radial shear equal to 2 % of the stiffening ring’s compressive load.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.8.2.4.1  The radial pressure load from the shell shall be determined in accordance with the following formula:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In SI units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V s 1  = 1000  P s L s<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In USC units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V s 1  =  P s L s<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.8.2.4.2  The radial shear load shall be determined in accordance with the following formula:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In SI units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>v s  = 10  P s L s D<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In USC units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>v s  = 0.01  P s L s D<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.8.2.4.3  The weld shear flow due to the radial shear load shall be determined in accordance with the following
formula:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In SI units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V s 2  = 100  v s q s  /  I act<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_493>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
V-17<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In USC units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V s 2  = 12  v s q s  /  I act<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>where<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>q s
is the first moment of area of the stiffener.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.8.2.4.4  The combined load for the design of the weld shall be determined in accordance with the following
formula:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W w  = ( V s 1 2  +  V s 2 2 ) 1/2<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.8.2.4.5  The minimum fillet weld leg size shall be the smallest of the shell thickness at the location of the stiffener,
the stiffener thickness at the weld location, or 6 mm ( 1 / 4  in.).<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.8.2.5 Lateral Bracing of Stiffener<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The projecting part of a stiffening ring without an outer vertical flange need not be braced if the width of the projecting
part in a radial vertical plane does not exceed 16 times its thickness. When this condition is not satisfied, the stiffening
ring shall be laterally braced in accordance with the requirements of API 620, 5.12.5.8.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.9 Bottom<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V.9.1  The bottom of the tank shall be evaluated for external pressure loading if either of the following conditions is
applicable. These conditions do not need to be considered simultaneously unless specified by the Purchaser.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1) If the total design external pressure force on the bottom plate exceeds the sum of the weight of the bottom
plates plus the weight of any product required by the Purchaser to remain in the tank when external pressure is
acting, membrane stresses in the bottom must be evaluated.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2) If the area around the tank will be subject to flooding with liquid, provisions should be included in the design of
the tank and its operating procedures to ensure that the tank contains sufficient liquid to counteract bottom uplift
resulting from external flooding conditions. If the tank cannot be filled with liquid of sufficient depth to counteract
the uplift from the liquid pressure under the bottom of the tank, membrane stresses in the bottom must be
evaluated.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V.9.2  In both of the above cases, the bottom may be evaluated as a membrane subjected to uniform loading and
restrained by the compression ring characteristics of the bottom-to-shell junction. For column-supported roofs, the
design of the columns shall consider the additional axial loading due to external pressure.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.9.3  The following provisions apply when Condition 2 in V.9.1 exists.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.9.3.1  Calculation of external (flooding) pressure:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The calculation of the hydrostatic external pressure due to flooding is performed using the equation:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P  =  G out H<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Rule 1:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>When flooding of the area surrounding a tank is possible, the most effective way to prevent damage to the shell or
bottom is to maintain an equivalent or higher level of liquid inside the tank whenever flooding occurs. The required
minimum level of liquid to be maintained inside the tank is calculated as follows:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>( G in   x   H in ) +  W bott   / (p  x   R 2 ) ³  G out   ×   H out<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Rule 2:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>When it is not possible to satisfy the equation in Rule 1, the tank and anchorage, if used, shall be designed to safely
resist the unbalanced pressure resulting from flood liquid. As a minimum, the following components shall be evaluated:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_494>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V-18
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V.9.3.2 allowable stress:  Unless otherwise specified, the flooding described above may be considered a
temporary loading and the allowable stress increased accordingly. However, the increase in allowable stress shall not
exceed 33 % of the basic allowable stress for the subject component when evaluating the component for flood
loading.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V.9.3.3 anchorage:  For tanks that are mechanically anchored, the anchorage devices shall be adequate to resist
the uplift and shear forces resulting from the pressure due to external flood liquid. If the tank is not mechanically
anchored, provisions should be made to guide the tank back into its original position when the flooding conditions
recede.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V.9.3.4 attached piping and sump:  Piping and other components connecting the tank to the ground or another
structure shall be capable of withstanding, without damage or failure, loads and movements due to any unbalanced
pressures resulting from flooding of the area around the tank. If a sump is used, the design of the sump shall consider
the possibility of the sump floating out of its pit during a flooding event.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V.9.3.5 bottom plate:  Under the pressure of external flood liquid without counterbalancing internal liquid, the
bottom plate will tend to deform or “balloon” upwards. As the bottom deforms and is subject to additional unbalanced
pressure, membrane stresses increase in the bottom plate. The bottom plate shall be capable of withstanding this
deformation without overstress of the plate or the attaching welds.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V.9.3.6 corner joint:  As the bottom plate deforms upwards, compressive stresses and bending stresses in the shell-
to-bottom joint increase. The shell plate and bottom plate components of the shell-to-bottom joint within the effective
compression ring limits shall be proportioned to maintain combined stresses within the yield strength corresponding to
the weaker of the two components.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.10 Example Calculations<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The following example calculations illustrate, in US Customary units, the use of this Annex.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>V.10.1 Data<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Tank diameter = 75 ft-0 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Tank shell height = 48 ft-0 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Design liquid level = 48 ft-0 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Design specific gravity of liquid = 1.0<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Allowable design stress,  S d  = 23,200 lb/in. 2<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Allowable stress in tension ring,  f   = 21,600 lb/in. 2<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Minimum yield strength of all steel = 36,000 lb/in. 2<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Specified corrosion allowance = None<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Tank bottom plate thickness =  3 / 8  in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Design external pressure = 0.6 lb/in. 2 g (86.4 lb/ft 2 )<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Design wind velocity (3-sec gust) = 120 mph (Maximum wind pressure,  W  = 31 lb/ft 2 )<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Design snow load = 0 lb/ft 2<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_495>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
V-19<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Roof design live load = 25 lb/ft 2<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Modulus of Elasticity,  E  = 30,000,000 lb/in. 2<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Shell course heights and thicknesses calculated by the one-foot method are as follows:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<HEADING level=3>>V.10.2
External Pressure Calculations<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>1) Select roof type: Try a self-supporting cone roof with a 20-degree slope from horizontal.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>From V.7,<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P r  = The greater of  D L  + ( L r  or  S ) +  F pe  P e  or  D L  +  P e  + 0.4 ( L r  or  S ),<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>where:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>D L  = 20.4 lb/ft 2  (Estimated assuming  1 / 2 −ιν.  roof plate),<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L r  = 25 lb/ft 2 ,<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S  = 0 lb/ft 2 ,<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>F pe  = 0.4, ,<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P e  = 0.6 lb/in. 2  = 86.4 lb/ft 2 ,<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P r  =  D L  + ( L r  or  S ) +  F pe   P e  = 20.4 + 25 + 0.4 (86.4) = 80.0 lb/ft 2 , or,<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P r  =  D L  +  P e  + ( L r  or  S ) = 20.4 + 86.4 + 0.4 (25) = 116.8 lb/ft 2  (Governs).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The required nominal thickness of the cone roof plate is calculated from V.7.2.1, as follows:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t cone
D
sin φ
----------
P r
0.248 E
-----------------
=<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t cone
75
0.342
-------------
116.8
7,440,000
------------------------
=<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t cone  = 0.869 in.,   this thickness is not practical. Consider a supported cone roof or a self-supporting dome roof.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

| 4                                                                                                                          | 31        | 0.261                | 5/ *                |
|                                                                                                                            |           |                      | 16                  |
| 5                                                                                                                          | 39        | 0.328                | 0.328               |
| 6                                                                                                                          | 47        | 0.395                | 0.395               |
| * The thicknesses of the upper four shell courses were increased from those required for hydrostatic pressure to eliminate |           |                      |                     |
| need for an intermediate wind girder.                                                                                      |           |                      |                     |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>V-20

<<PARAGRAPH>>Try a lap-welded dome roof with a dish radius of 1.0  ×   D  = 1.0  ×  75 = 75 ft. Assuming the plate weight does not
change significantly, the required thickness of the dome plate is calculated from V.7.3.1 as follows:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t dome
4.47 R  P r
E -----
=<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

---------------------------
=<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t dome  = 0.661 in.,  this thickness is not practical for lap-welding.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Consider a butt-welded dome roof with a dish radius of 0.8  ×   D  = 0.8  ×  75 = 60 ft-0 in. Again assuming the plate
weight does not change significantly, the required thickness of the dome plate is calculated from V.7.3.1 as follows:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t dome
4.47 R  P r
E -----
=<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t dome

116.8
30,000,000
---------------------------
=<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t dome  = 0.529 in. , this thickness is practical for butt-welding. (Alternatively, a supported cone roof could be used.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>2) Calculate the roof tension ring area required at the junction of the roof and cylindrical shell:<<HEADING_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>From V.7.3.5, the required area of the stiffener is calculated as follows:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A stiff  =  A reqd  –  t s 1 X shell  –  t dome X dome<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A stiff  = 7.21 – (0.3125)(7.21) – (0.529)(11.7)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A stiff  = –1.23 sq. in.,  Stiffener is not required<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Note:
This value should be recalculated, if necessary, after selection of final shell thickness.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<HEADING level=3>>4) Calculate the minimum shell thickness required for the combined loading from design external pressure
and wind:<<HEADING_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>P s

specified design wind pressure, lb/ft 2 ;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>P s
=  P e  or ( W  +  F pe  P e ) = 86.4 lb/ft 2  or [31 + 0.4(86.4)] = 86.4 lb/ft 2 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<HEADING level=3>>6) Calculate the maximum spacing of intermediate stiffeners:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>From V.8.2.1.2,<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H S afe
0.6  t s min
2.5  E<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>ψ D
1.5  P s
-----------------------------------
=<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H S afe
0.6 0.3125
2.5  30,000,000
3 75
1.5  86.4
-----------------------------------------------------------------
=<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H Safe  = 5.84 ft<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>7) Calculate the number of intermediate stiffeners required,  N s , based on  H Safe :<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>From V.8.2.1.3,<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>N s  + 1 =  H TS  /  H Safe<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>N s  + 1 = 43.54 / 5.84 = 7.46<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>N s  = 7<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Transposed spacing for 7 equally spaced stiffeners = 43.54 / 8 = 5.44 ft<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8) Calculate the intermediate stiffener spacing for the non-uniform shell thickness:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>From V.8.2.2.2,<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Intermediate stiffener spacing on 0.3125-in. shell plate is,<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L s  =  H Safe  = 5.84 ft<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Course Number                                                                                               | Actual Shell Course   | Thickness   | Transformed Shell Course   |
|                                                                                                             | Height                | (in.)       | Height *                   |
|                                                                                                             | (ft)                  |             | (ft)                       |
|:------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|:----------------------|:------------|:---------------------------|
| 1                                                                                                           | 8                     | 0.3125      | 8.00                       |
| 2                                                                                                           | 8                     | 0.3125      | 8.00                       |
| 3                                                                                                           | 8                     | 0.3125      | 8.00                       |
| 4                                                                                                           | 8                     | 0.3125      | 8.00                       |
| 5                                                                                                           | 8                     | 0.328       | 7.09                       |
| 6                                                                                                           | 8                     | 0.395       | 4.45                       |
| Sum =                                                                                                       | 48 ft                 | Sum =       | 43.54 ft                   |
| * For example, the transformed height of No. 5 shell course = (0.3125/.328)2.5(8) = 7.09 ft (see V.8.1.4.b) |                       |             |                            |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_499>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
V-23<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Intermediate stiffener spacings on 0.328 in. and 0.395 in. shell plate are,<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L s  = [ H Safe ]( t sx /t smin ) 2.5<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L s  = [5.84](0.328/0.3125) 2.5  = 6.59 ft<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>L s  = [5.84](0.395/0.3125) 2.5  = 10.49 ft<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>For equal transposed width we would like to locate 5 stiffeners on 0.3125 in. shell at spacing = 5.44 ft. However, this
causes the 3 rd  stiffener (location = 5.44 ft  ×  3 = 16.32 ft) to be closer to the horizontal shell seam than we would prefer.
Therefore, we will try to locate the 5 stiffeners on the 0.3125 in. shell at spacing = 5.75 ft (must be less than or equal
to  L S  = 5.84 ft).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Locate the 6 th  stiffener as follows:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Available 0.3125-in. shell plate = (4  ×  8 ft) – (5  ×  5.75 ft) = 3.25 ft<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Maximum length of 0.328-in. shell = (5.84 – 3.25)  ×  (0.328 / 0.3125) 2.5  = 2.92 ft<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>6 th  stiffener must be located no more than 2.92 ft on 0.328-in. shell. Stiffener can be located 1.5 ft on 0.328-in. shell<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Location of 6 th  stiffener = 32 + 1.5 = 33.5 ft from top of tank<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Locate the 7 th  stiffener as follows:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Available 0.328-in. shell = (5  ×  8) – 33.5 = 6.5 ft<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Maximum spacing on 0.328-in. shell =  L s  = 6.59 ft<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>To keep stiffener away from horizontal shell seam, locate stiffener less than 6.59 ft.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Location of 7 th  stiffener = 33.5 + 5.75 = 39.25 ft<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Check the remaining unstiffened shell:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Difference between actual and transformed shell height = 48 – 43.54 = 4.45 ft<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Length of 0.328-in. shell below stiffener = 40 – 39.25 = 0.75 ft<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Transformed shell stiffener spacing = 0.75  ×  (0.3125/0.328) 2.5  + 8.0  ×  (0.3125/0.395) 2.5  = 5.12 ft. Must be less than or
equal to 5.84 ft ( H Safe ) - OK<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>9) If fewer stiffeners and thicker shell plates is a more economical solution, the design can be adjusted as
follows:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Assume, for this example, a uniform shell thickness equal to the thickness of the lowest shell course, i.e.
t avg  = 0.395 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H safe  is then calculated as follows:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H safe
0.6 0.395
2.5  30,000,000
3 75
1.5  733.36
)  86.4
--------------------------------------------------------------
=<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H safe  = 10.48 ft<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>For  t avg  = 0.395 in.,  H TS  is recalculated to be equal to 48 ft.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_500>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>V-24
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The number of stiffeners required is:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>N s  + 1 = 48 / 10.48 = 4.58;  N s  = 4<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Actual spacing for 4 stiffeners = 48 / 5 = 9.6 ft<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

A reqd
t sn X shell
–
t b X btm
–

<<PARAGRAPH>>A stiff  = 1.80 – (0.395)(8.0) – (0.375)(6.0) = –3.61 in.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The contributing portion of the shell-to-bottom joint has a calculated moment of inertia of 20.2 in. 4  and will satisfy the
area and inertia requirements. Thus, an additional stiffener is not necessary.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
