American Iron & Steel Institute (AISI) Publication,  Steel Plate Engineering Data, Volume 2 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>[8]
ASME Paper 65-MET-15, “Theoretical and Experimental Study of Steel Panels in Which Membrane Tension is
Developed,” by J. S. McDermott.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>[9]
Machine Design Magazine, December 9, 1976, “Stress Analysis of Pressurized Panels,” by J. A. Martinelli.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_504>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_505>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Annex W
(normative)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Commercial and Documentation Recommendations<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>This annex provides a number of design options requiring decisions by the Purchaser; standard requirements;
recommendations; and information that supplements the basic standard.  This annex becomes a requirement only
when the Purchaser specifies an option covered by this annex or specifies the entire annex.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The following commercial and documentation recommendations apply to all tanks when specified by the Purchaser
on the Data Sheet.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>W.1 Document Submittals and Review<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>W.1.1 General<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1) Technical documents listed below shall be submitted by the Manufacturer for review by the Purchaser at
specified times during a project. Additional documents may be required and shall be a matter of agreement
between the Purchaser and the Manufacturer. Submittals and reviews shall be in accordance with contractual
schedule agreements. All documents shall be in reproducible form agreeable to the Purchaser.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2) Unless specified otherwise by the Purchaser, the minimum required content of the technical documentation
packages shall be as described in this Annex.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>W.1.2 Quotation or Bid Document Package<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1) All quotations shall be submitted in accordance with this standard and Purchaser’s requirements listed in the
Data Sheet. In addition, a second quotation containing alternates to Purchaser’s requirements may be quoted
for Purchaser’s consideration provided the alternates are clearly marked as such and are completely described
in that bid.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2) The Manufacturer shall mark and return the Purchaser’s previously prepared Data Sheet. Some entries will not
be determined until completion of negotiations and/or completion of the detailed design. Such entries may
remain blank for this submittal. The bid shall include the design wind speed and design snow loads (ground,
balanced and unbalanced) that will be used in the design by the Manufacturer.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3) The Manufacturer shall provide a list of all engineered accessories being purchased from suppliers, indicating
the Manufacturer, and model or part number. Alternatively, when a specific Manufacturer is not known at the
time of bidding, a list of Manufacturer-approved suppliers may be submitted. Excluded from the list requirement
are commodities such as plate, pipe, flanges, and bolts. Included in the list are items such as floating roofs,
dome roofs, roof seals, pressure vents, gauges, and instrumentation. Also, see C.1.1.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>W.1.3 Design Review Document Packages<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Unless specified otherwise, a Purchaser’s review of Manufacturer’s design calculations and general arrangement
drawings is required before the order of materials. Unless specified otherwise, the Purchaser’s review of the
documents listed in Items 3 through 7 below is required prior to the start of fabrication. Work may begin following
conclusion of any negotiations generated by the review process. A copy of the review packages with any annotations
including nozzle size, orientations, projections, placement and elevations of ladders, platforms, stairs, and
attachments, etc., shall be returned to the Manufacturer. The Manufacturer shall promptly revise/update the drawings,
calculations, and information on the  Data Sheet  showing all review-generated changes and shall submit copies to the
Purchaser. The Design Review Document shall consist of at least the following.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W-1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_506>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W-2
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1) Manufacturer’s design calculations as described in W.2 and structural loads for foundation design.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2) General arrangement drawings with complete material specification.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3) Detailed fabrication drawings.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4) Welding procedure specifications (WPSs) and procedure qualification records (PQRs). This shall include weld
hardness criteria when required by the Purchaser. Review of duplicate weld procedures for multiple tanks is not
required when written permission is received from the Purchaser.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5) Heat treatment procedures (if required).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>6) Nondestructive examination procedures and testing procedures.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>7) Description of proposed test gaskets (see 4.9), including material properties, dimensions, and design
characteristics.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>W.1.4 Interim Documents During Construction<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The Manufacturer shall promptly submit revised documents describing any design or construction changes to the
Purchaser. Copies of Material Test Reports applicable to components listed in 4.2.10.1 shall be forwarded to the
Purchaser upon receipt of the reports.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>W.1.5 Post-Construction Document Package<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Upon completion of construction and testing, copies of a Manufacturer’s data book shall be supplied in the quantities
specified in the contract. Each copy shall contain at least the documents listed below.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1) Final general arrangement and detail fabrication drawings, marked “as-built” by the Manufacturer, complete
with dimensions and data, with complete materials specification and parts list.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2) Design calculations described in W.2.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3) Copies of Material Test Reports applicable to shell plates and annular plates.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4) Reports of the results of all tests including weld hardness (when weld hardness criteria are specified), and
reports of all nondestructive examinations. Radiographic films shall also be included. For tank pressure test
data, include results and duration of pressure test(s), test water level, fill rate, imposed pneumatic pressure, hold
times, drain rate, etc.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5) Shell and bottom elevation measurements for hydro-test.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>6) Nameplate facsimile.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>7) Manufacturer’s certification per Figure 10.2.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>8) The  Data Sheet  reflecting as-built conditions.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>9) A drawing that lists the following for each shell course:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) the required shell thicknesses for both the design condition (including corrosion allowance) and the hydrostatic
test condition;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) the nominal thickness used;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_507>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
W-3<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) the material specification;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d) the allowable stresses.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>10) Nominal thicknesses used for materials other than shell plates.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>11) Handling criteria and rigging instructions (for shop-built tanks only).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>W.2 Manufacturer’s Calculations<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>All manual calculations shall include relevant formulas and source paragraphs in this standard or in other
specifications or engineering practices, values used in the formulas, calculated results, and acceptance criteria used.
Where a computer program performs design calculations, a program description shall be given, including name and
version of the program, program limitations and assumptions used, and a brief description of what the program does.
These calculations and/or computer programs shall address at least the following.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1) Determination of design thicknesses for all pressure boundary elements to satisfy all specified loading
conditions, which may include contents, pressure, partial vacuum, dead loads, live loads, snow loads, rain
loads, roof flotation, dike or flood plain partial submergence, wind, and seismic activity.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2) Overturning check and anchorage due to wind forces, seismic forces, and internal pressure, if applicable.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3) Seismic design requirements (e.g. base shear, longitudinal compression, sliding friction resistance checks,
overturning moment checks, and anchorage), if applicable.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4) Shell stability checks to determine whether shell stiffeners or increased shell course thicknesses will be
required.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5) Unless specified otherwise by the Purchaser, whenever the tank diameter exceeds 36 m (120 ft), shell stiffness<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>coefficients, maximum unrestrained radial deflection, angle of rotation of bottom course shell nozzles, and the
nomographs for moments and forces that these nozzles can safely sustain from connected piping shall be
provided in accordance with provisions of Annex P. Alternate analysis techniques, such as the finite element
method, may also be used to satisfy this requirement.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>6) Any additional calculations specified by the Purchaser to show compliance with this standard and any Annexes<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>invoked.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>W.3 Manufacturer’s Drawing Contents<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>All Manufacturer’s drawings shall be thoroughly checked for accuracy and completeness before sending for
Purchaser review. Manufacturer’s drawing(s) shall show, as a minimum, the following information.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1) An updated list of drawings for each tank shall be resubmitted each time drawings are revised and reissued.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2) Identification of the storage tank as designated by the Purchaser.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3) Reference to applicable practices, standards, specifications, details, and associated drawings and sketches.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4) Materials of construction, designated corrosion allowance(s), and gasket specifications.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5) Extent of postweld heat treatments.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>6) Extent of radiography to be applied to bottom, shell, and roof butt-welds.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_508>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W-4
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>7) Shell design joint efficiencies, for Annex A, Annex J, and Annex S.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>8) Complete details and dimensions of the tank, including external and internal attachments and appurtenances
supplied by Manufacturer and sub-contractors.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>9) Bottom slope.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>10) Nominal plate thicknesses for shell, roof, reinforcement, and bottom.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>11) Location of all welded seams. All welds shall be either pictorially detailed or identified by use of the standard
welding symbols of ANSI/AWS A2.4. Welding procedures shall be listed for each weld. A “weld map” may be
used if it clearly indicates the weld procedure specification used for every joint.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>12) For flanges other than those conforming to ASME B16.5 or ASME B16.47, and marked accordingly, show all
dimensions and finish of flange face.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>13) Facsimile of nameplate with data to be stamped thereon with location and details of fabrication of nameplate
bracket.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>14) Empty, operating, and test weight of tank.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15) Loads on foundation as also shown on the  Data Sheet ,   Line 13.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>16) Foundation plans and construction details (if supplied by the Manufacturer or the sub-contractor).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>W.4 Bids for Floating Roofs<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W.4.1  Bids for tanks having floating roofs shall contain sufficient engineering data, including material specifications
for both metallic and non-metallic components, nominal thicknesses, roof weight, and sufficient information (see
C.3.4.1 and C.3.4.2 or H.2.1, as applicable) to enable the Purchaser to verify that the bidder has considered all
specified design requirements.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W.4.2  Manufacturer shall list in the quotation all roof accessories furnished and included in the base price of the
roof. If any accessories are purchased from other suppliers, the Manufacturer shall provide that supplier’s name and
the model or part number.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>W.4.3  Manufacturer shall state the lowest and highest operating level of roof in the quotation.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>W.4.4  Manufacturer shall clearly describe the extent of electrical grounding and shunts included as a part of the
floating roof design.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>W.4.5  Manufacturer shall provide a cross-section of all seals showing materials and complete details of construction
with the bid.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W.4.6  The Manufacturer shall submit with the bid the minimum and the maximum allowable annular space between
the roof and shell, as well as the maximum and minimum annular space the proposed roof seal system can
accommodate.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>W.4.7  Manufacturer shall specify size, number, and type of drains with the quotation (external roof only).<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>W.4.8  The bid shall state if a wind skirt, a top-shell extension, or overflows will be required for proper functioning of
the roof seal (external roof only).<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_509>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
W-5<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W.4.9  The Manufacturer of the external floating roof shall prepare and submit to the Purchaser prior to order
placement a written declaration that the roof design complies with all design requirements of Annex C.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>DELETED<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W.4.10  The Manufacturer of the internal floating roof shall prepare and submit to the Purchaser prior to order
placement a written declaration that the roof design complies with all design requirements of Annex H.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>DELETED<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>W.5 Required Floating Roof Contract Calculations<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>W.5.1  The Manufacturer of the external floating roof shall prepare and submit to the Purchaser the following
calculations.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W.5.1.1  For single-deck pontoon and double-deck roofs, calculations showing that the roof design complies with the
buoyancy requirements of C.3.4.1a, using the smaller of the specific gravity in C.3.4.1 (0.7), or the minimum specific
gravity of the product specified on the Data Sheet, Line 5.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>W.5.1.2  For single-deck pontoon roofs and double deck roofs, calculations showing that the roof design complies
with the punctured compartment loading condition as specified in C.3.4.1b.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>W.5.1.3  Calculations showing that the design of the roof and roof supports satisfies C.3.10.2.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W.5.2  The Manufacturer of the internal floating roof shall prepare and submit to the Purchaser the following
calculations, considering internal floating roof deflections and stresses for each of the load conditions required by
Annex H. All calculations for the floating condition shall be based upon the design specific gravity (per H.4.2.1.1).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>W.5.2.1  Calculations showing that the roof design complies with the buoyancy requirements of H.4.2.1.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>W.5.2.2  For single-deck pontoon and double-deck roofs, calculations showing that the roof design complies with the
punctured compartment loading condition as specified in H.4.2.3.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>W.5.2.3  Calculations showing that the design of the roof and roof supports in the landed condition satisfies
H.4.2.2.2.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W.5.2.4  The internal floating roof Manufacturer shall specify the internal floating roof weight and total flotation
displacement provided based on a flotation level for design specific gravity per H.4.2.1.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>W.6 Jobsite Responsibilities<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Unless otherwise specified by the Purchaser, the Manufacturer shall furnish all labor, tools, equipment, supplies,
materials, utilities (including power for welding), storage, and personnel services necessary for, and reasonably
incidental to, the delivery of materials to the site, the construction of the tank(s), and the removal of surplus and scrap
materials from the job site. See the  Data Sheet  (see Line 14) for the Manufacturer’s additional post-hydro-test
responsibilities. The Purchaser shall furnish and dispose of the water for hydro-testing the tank from the tie-in points
as designated on the Data Sheet, Line 14.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_510>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_511>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Annex X
(normative)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Duplex Stainless Steel Storage Tanks<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.1
Scope<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.1.1
This Annex covers materials, design, fabrication, erection, and testing requirements for vertical, cylindrical,
aboveground, closed- and open-top, welded, duplex stainless steel storage tanks constructed of material grades
2205 (UNS S31803), 2003 (UNS S32003), 2101 (UNS S32101), 2102 (UNS S82011), 2202 (UNS S32202), 2205
(UNS S32205), 2304 (UNS S32304), 255 (UNS S32550), 255+ (UNS S32520), 2507 (UNS S32750), and Z100 (UNS
S32760). This Annex does not cover stainless steel clad plate or strip lined construction.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.1.2
This Annex applies only to tanks in non-refrigerated services with a maximum design temperature not
exceeding 260  ° C (500  ° F) and a design metal temperature of –40  ° C (–40  ° F) or warmer. Ambient temperature tanks
(non-heated) shall have a design temperature of 40  ° C (100  ° F). It is cautioned that exothermic reactions occurring
inside unheated storage tanks can produce temperatures exceeding 40  ° C (100  ° F).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.1.3
The minimum thicknesses specified in this Annex are corroded thicknesses unless otherwise stated.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.1.4
This Annex states only the requirements that differ from the basic rules in this standard. For requirements not
stated, the basic rules must be followed.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.2
Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.2.1
Selection and Ordering<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.2.1.1
Materials shall be in accordance with Table X.1.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.2.1.2
Selection of the type/grade of duplex stainless steel depends on the service and environment to which it will
be exposed. The Purchaser shall specify the type/grade.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.2.1.3
External structural attachments may be carbon steels meeting the requirements of Section 4 of this
standard, providing any permanent attachments are protected from corrosion. (This does not include shell, roof, or
bottom openings and their reinforcement.) Carbon steel attachments (e.g. clips for scaffolding) shall not be welded
directly to any internal surface of the tank.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.2.2
packaging<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Packaging duplex stainless steel for shipment is important to maintain its corrosion resistance. Precautions to protect
the surface of the material depend on the surface finish supplied and may vary among Manufacturers. Standard
packaging methods may not be sufficient to protect the material from normal shipping damage. If the intended service
requires special precautions, the Purchaser shall specify special instructions.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.2.3
Qualification Testing<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.2.3.1
Tests for detecting detrimental intermetallic phases for ASTM A923 are required from one plate per heat
treat lot as follows:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>UNS S32205/S31803
Methods B & C<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>UNS S82011/S32202
Method B 1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>UNS S32003
Method B 1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X-1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 1
Unless otherwise specified by the purchaser, plate, sheet, or strip shall be furnished with a No. 1 finish and shall be hot-rolled,
annealed, and descaled.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 2
Carbon steel flanges and/or stub ends may be used by agreement between the purchaser and manufacturer, providing the design
and details consider the dissimilar properties of the materials used and are suitable for the intended service.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 3
Castings shall not be used unless specified by the purchaser. If specified, castings shall meet ASTM A890 and shall be inspected in
accordance with ASME Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code, Section VIII, Division 1, Appendix 7.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 4
All bars in contact with the product shall be furnished in the hot-rolled, annealed, and descaled condition.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE 5
Other b ol t i ng materials may be used by agreement between the purchaser and manufacturer.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>UNS S32750
Method B 1  & C<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>UNS S32550/S32520
Method B 1  & C<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>UNS S32760
Method B 1  & C 3<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1 B test values to be agreed upon between Purchaser and Manufacturer but not less than 54J (40 ft-lbf).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.2.3.2
Tests for detecting detrimental intermetallic phases per ASTM A1084 are required from one plate per heat
treat lot as follows:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>UNS S32304
Methods B & C<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>UNS S32101
Methods B & C<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.2.3.3
Charpy Impact Test Requirements<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.2.3.3.1
Charpy Impact testing at design metal temperature (DMT) in accordance with X.2.3.3.2 is required for
plate components listed in 4.2.10.1 and for pipe and forgings used for shell nozzles/manways, for materials listed in
Table X.1 and where either Item a) or Item b) below is true:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) all thicknesses where the design metal temperature (DMT) is between –29  ° C and –40°  ° C (–20  ° F and –40  ° F),
or<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) all components where the nominal/governing thickness is greater than 10 mm ( 3 / 8  in.) for all temperatures.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_513>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
X-3<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>For impact test evaluation of shell nozzles made from pipe or forgings, the governing thickness as defined in 4.5.4.3
shall be used instead of the nominal thickness of the pipe or forgings.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.2.3.3.2
Three specimens tested per ASTM A370 or equivalent ISO Standards shall have a lateral expansion
opposite the notch not less than 0.38 mm (0.015 in.) at design metal temperature (DMT) or lower. In addition to lateral
expansion, impact test energy values in Joules (ft-lbf) shall be measured and reported on test reports. If the value of
lateral expansion for one specimen of a set is less than 0.38 mm (0.015 in.) but not less than 0.25 mm (0.01 in.) and
the average value of the three specimens equals or exceeds 0.38 mm (0.015 in.), a retest of three additional
specimens may be made, each of which must equal or exceed 0.38 mm (0.015 in.). If the required values are not
obtained in the retest or if the values in the initial test are less than minimum required for retest, the material may be
reheat treated. After reheat treatment, new sets of specimens shall be made and retested; all specimens must meet
the lateral expansion value of 0.38 mm (0.015 in.) minimum.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>ASTM A923 Practice B test results may be used to fulfill these requirements provided the lateral expansion is
measured and reported.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.3
Design<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.3.1
Bottom Plates<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>All bottom plates shall have a nominal corroded thickness of not less than 5 mm ( 3 / 16  in.). Unless otherwise approved
by the Purchaser, all rectangular and sketch plates (bottom plates on which the shell rests that have one end
rectangular) shall have a nominal width of not less than1200 mm (48 in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.3.2
Annular Bottom Plates<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Butt-welded annular bottom plates meeting the requirements of 5.5.2 through 5.5.5 are required when either the
bottom shell course maximum product stress is greater than 160 MPa (23,200 lbf/in. 2 ) or the bottom shell course
maximum test stress is greater than 172 MPa (24,900 lbf/in. 2 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.3.3
Shell Design<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.3.3.1
Shell Minimum Thickness<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The required nominal shell thickness shall not be less than the greatest of the design shell thickness plus corrosion
allowance, hydrostatic test shell thickness, or the nominal thickness listed in 5.6.1.1 (note 4 does not apply).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.3.3.2
Minimum Plate Widths<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Unless otherwise approved by the Purchaser, the shell plates shall have a minimum width of 1200 mm (48 in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.3.3.3
Shell Thickness Calculation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The requirements of 5.6 shall be followed except as modified in X.3.3.3.1 through X.3.3.3.3.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.3.3.3.1
Allowable stresses for all shell thickness calculation methods are provided in Table X.2a and Table X.2b.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.3.3.3.2
Annex A is not applicable.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.3.3.3.3
The following formulas for design shell thickness and test shell thickness may alternatively be used for
tanks 60 m (200 ft) in diameter and smaller.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_514>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X-4
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In SI units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t d  = (4.9 D ( H  – 0.3) G )/(( S d )( E )) +  CA<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t t  = (4.9 D ( H  – 0.3))/(( S t )( E ))<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>where<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t d
is the design shell thickness, in mm;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t t
is the hydrostatic test shell thickness, in mm;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>D
is the nominal diameter of tank, in m (see 5.6.1.1);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H
is the design liquid level, in m (see 5.6.3.2);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>●
14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>G
is the design specific gravity of the liquid to be stored, as specified by the Purchaser;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>E
is the joint efficiency, 1.0, 0.85, or 0.70 (see Table X.3);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>CA  is the corrosion allowance, in mm, as specified by the Purchaser (see 5.3.2);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S d
is the allowable stress for the design condition, in MPa (see Table X.2a and Table X.2b);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S t
is the allowable stress for hydrostatic test condition, in MPa (see Table X.2a and Table X.2b).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In USC units:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t d  = (2.6 D ( H  – 1) G )/(( S d )( E )) + CA<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t t  = (2.6 D ( H  – 1))/(( S t )( E ))<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>where<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t d
is the design shell thickness, in inches;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>t t
is the hydrostatic test shell thickness, in inches;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>D
is the nominal diameter of tank, in ft (see 5.6.1.1);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>H
is the design liquid level, in ft (see 5.6.3.2);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>G
is the specific gravity of the liquid to be stored, as specified by the Purchaser;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>E
is the joint efficiency, 1.0, 0.85, or 0.70 (see Table X.3);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>CA  is the corrosion allowance, in inches, as specified by the Purchaser (see 5.3.2);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S d
is the allowable stress for the design condition, in lbf/in. 2  (see Tables X.2a and X.2b);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>S t
is the allowable stress for hydrostatic test condition, in lbf/in. 2  (see Tables X.2a and X.2b).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_515>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
X-5<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.3.4
Shell Openings<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.3.4.1
The minimum nominal thickness of connections and openings shall be as follows:<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Size of Nozzle
Minimum Nominal Neck Thickness<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NPS 2 and less
Schedule 80S<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NPS 3 and NPS 4
Schedule 40S<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Over NPS 4
Schedule 40S but need not be greater than the shell thickness<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NOTE
Reinforcement requirements of 5.7 must be maintained.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.3.4.2
Thermal stress relief requirements of 5.7.4 are not applicable.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.3.4.3
Shell manholes shall be in conformance with 5.7.5.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.3.4.4
As an alternative to X.3.4.3, plate ring flanges may be designed in accordance with API 620 rules using the
allowable stresses given in Table X.2a and Table X.2b.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.3.4.5
Allowable weld stresses for shell openings shall conform to 5.7.2.7 except   S d  = the maximum allowable
design stress (the lesser value of the base materials joined) permitted by Table X.2a and Table X.2b.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<HEADING level=3>>X.3.5
Roof Design<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.3.5.1
All duplex stainless steel components of the roof manhole shall have a nominal thickness of not less than 5
mm ( 3 / 16  in.).<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.3.5.2
In roof-to-shell-joint area calculation per 5.10.5.2 and 5.10.6.2, allowable stress  F a  shall be calculated using
0.6 x Yield Strength ( F y ) (least) at maximum design temperature. Refer to Table X.4a and Table X.4b for Yield
Strength ( F y ) at maximum design temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>1 5<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.3.5.3
In rafter spacing calculations per 5.10.4.4, Yield Strength ( F y ) of roof plate material at maximum design
temperature as listed in Table X.4a and Table X.4b shall be used.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.3.6
Annex F—Modifications<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In F.2, the shell thickness shall be as specified in X.3.3 except that the pressure  P  [in kPa (in. of water)] divided by
9.8G (12G) shall be added to the design liquid height in meters (ft).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
X-7<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.3.7
Annex M—Modifications<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.3.7.1
Annex M requirements shall be met for duplex stainless steel tanks with design temperatures over 40  ° C
(100  ° F) as modified by X.3.7.2 through X.3.7.5.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.3.7.2
Allowable shell stress shall be in accordance with Table X.2a and Table X.2b.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.3.7.3
In M.3.6, the duplex stainless steel structural allowable stress dependent on Yield Strength ( F y ) or Modulus
of Elasticity ( E ) or both Yield Strength ( F y ) and Modulus of Elasticity ( E ) shall be based on Yield Strength ( F y ) and
Modulus of Elasticity ( E ) at the maximum design temperature. Refer to Table X.4a and Table X.4b for Yield Strength
( F y ) and Table X.5a and Table X.5b for values of Modulus of Elasticity ( E ) at maximum design temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.3.7.4
In M.5.1, for a maximum design temperature above 40 °C (100 °F), the calculated minimum thickness of roof
plates, as defined in 5.10.5.1 and, 5.10.6.1 shall be increased by the ratio of the material modulus of elasticity at 40 °C
(100 °F) to the material modulus of elasticity at the maximum design temperature. (See Table X.5a and Table X.5b for
modulus of elasticity.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.3.7.5
In M.6 (the equation for the maximum height of unstiffened shell in 5.9.7.1), the maximum height shall be
multiplied by the ratio of the material modulus of elasticity at the design temperature to the material modulus of
elasticity at 40  ° C (100  ° F).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4
Fabrication and Construction<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.1
General<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Special precautions must be observed to minimize the risk of loss of the corrosion resistance and toughness of duplex
stainless steel. Duplex stainless steel shall be handled so as to minimize contact with iron or other types of steel
during all phases of fabrication, shipping, and construction.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The thermal history of the material must also be controlled. The following sections describe the major precautions that
should be observed during fabrication, and handling.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.2
Storage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Storage should be under cover and well removed from shop dirt and fumes from pickling operations. If outside
storage is necessary, provisions should be made for rainwater to drain and allow the material to dry. Duplex stainless
steel should not be stored in contact with carbon steel. Materials containing chlorides, including foods, beverages,
oils, cleaners and greases, should not come in contact with duplex stainless steel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.3
Thermal Cutting<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.3.1
Thermal cutting of duplex stainless steel shall be by the plasma-arc method or by laser cutting.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.4.3.2
Thermal cutting of duplex stainless steel may leave a heat-affected zone with intermetallic precipitates. This
heat-affected zone may have reduced corrosion resistance and toughness unless removed by machining or grinding.
Normally the HAZ from thermal cutting is thin enough to be removed by edge preparation machining and adjacent
base metal melting during welding. The Purchaser shall specify if the heat-affected zone is to be removed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.4
Forming<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.4.1
Duplex stainless steels shall be formed by a cold or hot forming procedure that is not injurious to the
material.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
X-11<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.4.2
Duplex stainless steels may be cold formed. The maximum strain produced by such cold forming shall not
exceed 10 % and control of forming spring-back is provided in the forming procedure.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.4.3
Hot forming, if required, may be performed within a temperature range shown in Table X.6a and Table X.6b.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Forming at temperatures between 600  ° F (315  ° C) and the minimum temperature shown in Table X.6a and
Table X.6b is not permitted.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.5
Cleaning<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.4.5.1
When the Purchaser requires cleaning to remove surface contaminants that may impair the normal
corrosion resistance; it shall be done in accordance with ASTM A380, unless otherwise specified. The Purchaser
shall specify any additional cleanliness requirements for the intended service.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.5.2
When welding is completed; flux residues and weld spatter shall be removed mechanically using stainless
steel tools.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.5.3
Removal of excess weld metal, if required, shall be done with a grinding wheel or belt that has not been
previously used on other metals.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.5.4
Removal of weld heat tint, if required, shall be done using an appropriate pickling product and pickling
procedure.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.4.5.5
Chemical cleaners and pickling solutions used shall not have a detrimental effect on the duplex stainless
steel or welded joints and shall be disposed of in accordance with laws and regulations governing the disposal of
such chemicals. Thorough rinsing with water and drying shall always follow the use of any chemical cleaners or
pickling solutions (see X.4.9).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.6
Blast Cleaning<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>If blast cleaning is necessary, it shall be done with sharp acicular grains of sand or grit containing not more than 1%
by weight iron as free iron or iron oxide. Steel shot or sand previously used to clean non stainless steel materials is
not permitted.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.7
Pickling<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>If pickling of a duplex stainless steel is necessary, an acid mixture of nitric and hydrofluoric acids shall be used. After
pickling, the stainless steel shall be thoroughly rinsed with water and dried.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.8
Passivation or Surface Iron Removal<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>When the Purchaser specifies passivation or surface iron removal, cleaning may be achieved by treatment with nitric
or citric acid. Nitric hydrofluoric acid shall be used to remove embedded iron.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.9
Rinsing<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.4.9.1
When cleaning, pickling, or passivation is required, these operations shall be followed immediately by
rinsing, not allowing the surfaces to dry between operations. Pickling solutions may require a neutralization treatment
before rinsing.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.4.9.2
Rinse water shall be potable and shall not contain more than 200 parts per million chloride at temperatures
below 40  ° C (100  ° F), or no more than 100 parts per million chloride at temperatures above 40  ° C (100  ° F) and below
65  ° C (150  ° F), unless specifically allowed by the Purchaser.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.9.3
Following final rinsing, the equipment shall be completely dried.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_522>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X-12
API S TANDARD  650<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.10
Hydrostatic Testing<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.4.10.1
The rules of 7.3.6 apply to hydrostatic testing except that the penetrating oil test in 7.3.6, Item 2) shall be
replaced with liquid penetrant examination conducted by applying the penetrant on one side and developer on the
opposite side of the welds. The penetrant dwell time must be at least one hour.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.4.10.2
The materials used in the construction of duplex stainless steel tanks may be subject to pitting, or general
corrosion if they are exposed to contaminated test water for extended periods of time. The Purchaser shall specify a
minimum quality of test water that conforms to the following requirements.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) Unless otherwise specified by the Purchaser, water used for hydrostatic testing of tanks shall be potable and
treated, containing at least 0.2 parts per million free chlorine.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) Water shall be substantially clean and clear.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) Water shall have no objectionable odor (that is, no hydrogen sulfide).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d) Water pH shall be between 6 and 8.3.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e) Water temperature shall be below 50  ° C (120  ° F).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
The chloride content of the water shall be below 50 parts per million, unless otherwise allowed by the Purchaser.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.10.3
When testing with potable water, the exposure time shall not exceed 21 days, unless otherwise specified
by the Purchaser.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.10.4
When testing with other fresh waters, the exposure time shall not exceed 7 days.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.4.10.5
Upon completion of the hydrostatic test, water shall be completely drained. Wetted surfaces shall be
washed with potable water when non-potable water is used for the test, and completely dried. Particular attention
shall be given to low spots, crevices, and similar areas. Hot air drying is not permitted.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.11
Welding<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.4.11.1
Tanks and their structural attachments shall be welded by any of the processes permitted in 7.2.1.1.
Galvanized components or components coated with zinc-rich coating shall not be welded directly to duplex stainless
steel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.4.11.2
Filler metal chemistry shall be as specified by the Purchaser. Proper filler metal selection may be
discussed with the materials manufacturer. Dissimilar welds to carbon steels shall use filler metals of E309L or higher
alloy content.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.12
Welding Procedure and Welder Qualifications<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.4.12.1
Welding Procedure and Welder Qualification requirements shall be as specified in Section 7. In addition,
welding procedures used for welding components listed in X.2.3.3.1 shall also meet the requirements of ASTM A923
Method B and Method C as required in X.2.3.1 or ASTM A1084 Method B and Method C as required in X.2.3.2 with test
values to be agreed upon between Purchaser and Manufacturer. Weld metal and heat affected zone test specimens
tested per ASTM A370, or equivalent ISO Standards, shall meet the lateral expansion requirements described in
X.2.3.3.2. Welding Procedure Qualification Records shall document the results of tests required both by Section 7,
ASTM A923 and X.2.3.3.2.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.4.12.2
For any material that has not been assigned a P-number in Table QW-422 of Section IX of the ASME Code,
the Welding Procedure and the Welder Qualification shall be developed for that specific material.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_523>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>W ELDED  T ANKS   FOR  O IL  S TORAGE
X-13<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.13
Postweld Heat Treatment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Post weld heat treatment of duplex stainless steel materials shall not be performed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.14
Examination of Welds<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.14.1
Radiographic Examination of Butt-Welds<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.14.1.1
Radiographic examination of butt-welds shall be in accordance with 6.1 and Table X.3.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>X.4.14.1.2
When shell designs use joint efficiency = 0.85, spot radiographs of vertical joints shall conform to 8.1.2.2,
Item a, excluding the 10 mm ( 3 / 8  in.) shell-thickness limitation in Item a and excluding the additional random spot
radiograph required by Item a.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.4.14.2
Examination of Welds by Liquid Penetrant Method<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The following component welds shall be examined by the liquid penetrant method before the hydrostatic test of the
tank.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) The shell-to-bottom inside attachment weld.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) All welds of opening connections in tank shell that are not completely radiographed, including nozzle and manhole
neck welds and neck-to-flange welds.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) All welds of attachments to shells, such as stiffeners, compression rings, clips, and other nonpressure parts for
which the thickness of both parts joined is greater than 19 mm ( 3 / 4  in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d) All butt-welded joints in tank annular plates on which backing strips are to remain.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.5
Marking<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Marking shall be in accordance with Section 10, except that nameplates shall not be attached by brazing.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>●<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>X.6
Annexes<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The following Annexes are modified for use with duplex stainless steel storage tanks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a) Annex A is not applicable to tanks built to this Annex.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b) Annex C may be used; however, the Purchaser shall identify all materials of construction. The nominal deck
thickness using duplex stainless steel shall not be less than 2.5 mm (0.094 in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c) Annex F is modified as outlined in X.3.6 of this Annex.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d) Annex H may be used: however the Purchaser shall identify all materials of construction. The nominal deck
thickness using duplex stainless steel shall not be less than 2.5 mm (0.094 in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e) Annex J may be used, except the nominal shell thickness for all tank diameters shall not be less than 5 mm ( 3 / 16  in.).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Annex K is not applicable to tanks built to this Annex.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g) Annex M is modified as outlined in X.3.7 of this Annex.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>14<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h) Annex N is not applicable.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>i)
Annex O may be used; however, the structural members of Tables O.1a and O.1b shall be of an acceptable grade
of material.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>15<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>j)
All other Annexes may be used without modifications.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_524>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_525>>
<<HEADING level=2>>Annex Y
(informative)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=2>>API Monogram<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Y.1 Introduction<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The API Monogram Program allows an API Licensee to apply the API Monogram to products.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The use of the Monogram on products constitutes a representation and warranty by the Licensee to purchasers of the
products that, on the date indicated, the products were produced in accordance with a verified quality management
system and in accordance with an API product specification. The API Monogram Program delivers significant value to
the international oil and gas industry by linking the verification of an organization's quality management system with
the demonstrated ability to meet specific product specification requirements.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>When used in conjunction with the requirements of the API License Agreement, API Specification Q1, including
Annex A, defines the requirements for those organizations who wish to voluntarily obtain an API license to provide
API monogrammed products in accordance with an API product specification.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>API Monogram Program licenses are issued only after an on-site audit has verified that the Licensee conforms to the
requirements described in API Q1 in total.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>For information on becoming an API Monogram Licensee, please contact API, Certification Programs, 1220 L Street,
NW, Washington, DC 20005 or call 202-682-8000 or by email at certification@api.org.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Y.2 API Monogram Marking Requirements<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The following marking requirements apply only to those API Licensees wishing to mark their products with the API
Monogram.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The complete API Monogram marking consists of the following:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— the letters “API 650”;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— the manufacturer’s API license number;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— the API Monogram;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>— the date of manufacture (defined as the month and year when the Monogram is applied by the manufacturer).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Y-1<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
